A chirp, peep, or squeak, as of a young: A throw; a toss; a cast, as of something from the hand; as, a good pitch in quoits.
Veneration or reverence of the Supreme Being, and love of his character; loving obedience to the will of God, and earnest devotion to his service.
An earthwork; a mound; a raised work.

Leprosy.
The female of the ruff.
A young hog. Same as Shote.

One of the chief divisions of a long poem; a book.

Helmsman. See 6th Steer.

The act of entering or passing into or upon; entrance; ingress; hence, beginnings or first attempts; as, the entry of a person into a house or city; the entry of a river into the sea; the entry of air into the blood; an entry upon an undertaking.

A midwife.
A reprimand; a rebuke.

The Pawnees, a tribe of North American Indians whose principal totem was the wolf.

An instrument used by the ancients in writing on tablets covered with wax, having one of its ends sharp, and the other blunt, and somewhat expanded, for the purpose of making erasures by smoothing the wax.
The east wind.

That elevation of voice now called metrical accentuation, or the rhythmic accent.
The side of the face below the eye.

The language of the Osci.

Any sharp organ of offense and defense, especially when connected with a poison gland, and adapted to inflict a wound by piercing; as the caudal sting of a scorpion. See Illust. of Scorpion.
A small inlet or bay, narrower and extending further into the land than a cove; a recess in the shore of the sea, or of a river.
Proof.
See Cuish.
The mountain linnet (Linota flavirostris).
a trade name for simvastatin.
A Jewish cabalistic book attributed by tradition to Rabbi Simon ben Yochi, who lived about the end of the 1st century, a. d.  Modern critics believe it to be a compilation of the 13th century.
An arch, or ceiling, of boards, placed over the men's heads in a mine.
any doglike animal of the family canidae.
A stately and formal Spanish dance for which full state costume is worn; -- so called from the resemblance of its movements to those of the peacock.
A crossbeam; a lay of joists.

A white to gray volcanic tufa, formed of decomposed trachytic cinders; -- sometimes used as a cement. Hence, a coarse sort of plaster or mortar, durable in water, and used to line cisterns and other reservoirs of water.
the principles of right and wrong that are accepted by an individual or a social group; as, the Puritan ethic.

A genus of rosaceous trees and shrubs having pomes for fruit. It includes the apple, crab apple, pear, chokeberry, sorb, and mountain ash.
Weather.

The edge, margin, or border of a steep place, as of a precipice; a bank or edge, as of a river or pit; a verge; a border; as, the brink of a chasm. Also Fig.
That which is feigned; an assumed or false appearance; a pretense; a stratagem; a fetch.

The act of shoving; a forcible push.

The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being the external or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares, the openings of the nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.
The handle of a scythe; a snead.
One of an order of priests which in ancient times existed among certain branches of the Celtic race, especially among the Gauls and Britons.
An Indo-European people, allied to the Lithuanians and Old Prussians, and inhabiting a part of the Baltic provinces of Russia.

One who nourishes; a person who supplies food, tends, or brings up; as: (a) A woman who has the care of young children; especially, one who suckles an infant not her own. (b) A person, especially a woman, who has the care of the sick or infirm.
A line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle; -- called also rhumb line, and loxodromic curve. See Loxodromic.
A candlestick with many branches, each of which bears the name of some one of the descendants of Jesse; -- called also  tree of Jesse.
A spirituous liquor or drink distilled from potatoes; -- used in the Barbadoes.
A saint.
A thrust.
A noisy quarrel; loud, angry contention; a wrangle; a tumult; as, a drunken brawl.
Wine boiled and mingled with honey.

A drama, either tragic or comic, of which music forms an essential part; a drama wholly or mostly sung, consisting of recitative, arias, choruses, duets, trios, etc., with orchestral accompaniment, preludes, and interludes, together with appropriate costumes, scenery, and action; a lyric drama.
A pagoda.

To pierce slightly with a sharp-pointed instrument or substance; to make a puncture in, or to make by puncturing; to drive a fine point into; as, to prick one with a pin, needle, etc.; to prick a card; to prick holes in paper.
Ready money; cash; -- commonly with the; as, he was well supplied with the ready.
The act of smiling; a peculiar change or brightening of the face, which expresses pleasure, moderate joy, mirth, approbation, or kindness; -- opposed to frown.
A person, animal, or plant grown to full size and strength; one who has reached maturity.
An electro-negative atom or group of atoms, or the element which, in electro-chemical decompositions, is evolved at the anode; -- opposed to cation.
Half a shekel.
Involving haste; done, made, etc., in haste; as, a hasty retreat; a hasty sketch.
The manta ray.  See also Cephaloptera and Sea devil.
A cloth used for wiping, especially one used for drying anything wet, as the person after a bath.

The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestines just after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in the intestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle.
A hump; a protuberance.
A religious sect noted for warlike traits, founded in the Punjab at the end of the 15th century.
A feeling of discomfort or vexation caused by what one dislikes; also, whatever causes such a feeling; as, to work annoy.
Moisture, especially, the moisture or fluid of animal bodies, as the chyle, lymph, etc.; as, the humors of the eye, etc.
A thin board; a billet of wood; a splinter.
The Lake herring (Coregonus Artedi), valuable food fish of the Great Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to Coregonus Hoyi, a related species of Lake Michigan.
A native or resident of Croatia.
A sudden causeless change or turn of the mind; a whim of fancy; a capricious prank; a vagary or caprice.
A tribe of Indians which formerly occupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.
A fabric resembling velvet, but having the nap flat and less close.
Realm.
Same as Drilling.

An official diviner who foretold events by the singing, chattering, flight, and feeding of birds, or by signs or omens derived from celestial phenomena, certain appearances of quadrupeds, or unusual occurrences.
A tropical American tree (Melicocca bijuga) bearing a small edible fruit with green leathery skin and sweet juicy translucent pulp.
A guillemot.
The floating dust in flour mills caused by the operation or grinding.
A knife or short dagger, esp. that in use among the Highlanders of Scotland. [Variously spelt.]

One fully skilled or well versed in anything; a proficient; as, adepts in philosophy.
The coalfish (Pollachius carbonarius).
A European marine fish (Zeus faber), of a yellow color. See Illust. of John Doree.
The scum or refuse matter which is thrown off, or falls from, metals in smelting the ore, or in the process of melting; recrement.
A tropical tree of Central America and the West Indies and Puerto Rico (Inga laurina) having spikes of white flowers; it is used as shade for coffee plantations.
The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustani language which is chiefly spoken by native Hindus. In employs the Devanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written.
A fibrous and muscular band lying within the longitudinal axis of the tongue in many mammals, as the dog.
Milk sickness.

A gripe or seizure of the hand; a seizure by embrace, or infolding in the arms.
A person who serves to provide medical care.

The blind mole rat (Spalax typhlus), native of Eastern Europe and Asia. Its eyes and ears are rudimentary, and its fur is soft and brownish, more or less tinged with gray. It constructs extensive burrows.
The covering of a flower. See Flower.
The magpie.

A sacred song; a poetical composition for use in the praise or worship of God.
One of a fabulous race of dwarfs who waged war with the cranes, and were destroyed.
A purse; also, a vesicle; a pod; a hull.
Liquid to be swallowed; any fluid to be taken into the stomach for quenching thirst or for other purposes, as water, coffee, or decoctions.
Whatever is produced for the nourishment or enjoyment of man or animals by the processes of vegetable growth, as corn, grass, cotton, flax, etc.; -- commonly used in the plural.
An Eskimo snow house.
An offensive weapon, having a long and usually sharp-pointed blade with a cutting edge or edges. It is the general term, including the small sword, rapier, saber, scimiter, and many other varieties.
A fainting fit; syncope.
To cover, decorate, or invest with a crown; hence, to invest with royal dignity and power.
Groats.

A West African long-tailed monkey (Cercopithecus ruber); the red monkey.

The cheetah.

A clasp for fastening garments in front.
Press; throng.

Among Muslims, the last imam or leader of the faithful.  The Sunni, the largest sect of the Muslims, believe that he is yet to appear.

The science or art of exact reasoning, or of pure and formal thought, or of the laws according to which the processes of pure thinking should be conducted; the science of the formation and application of general notions; the science of generalization, judgment, classification, reasoning, and systematic arrangement; the science of correct reasoning.

A metal spike having a sharpened point on one end, and a hole through which a rope can be passed on the other; it is driven into the face of a rock cliff during climbing, and used as an anchor point for a rope.
A line of grass or grain cut and thrown together by the scythe in mowing or cradling.
A native of Sind, India, esp. one of the native Hindoo stock.

A game at dice, properly called novem quinque (L., nine five), the two principal throws being nine and five.

A sauce made of small fish. It was prized by the ancients.

A genus of lichens, most of the species of which have long, gray, pendulous, and finely branched fronds. Usnea barbata is the common bearded lichen which grows on branches of trees in northern forests.
To run with a winding course; to double; to crook; to wind and turn.
A sweet viscid fluid, esp. that collected by bees from flowers of plants, and deposited in the cells of the honeycomb.

A total prohibition of intercourse with, use of, or approach to, a given person or thing under pain of death, -- an interdict of religious origin and authority, formerly common in the islands of Polynesia; interdiction.
Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit; energy.

Half-rotten straw, or any similar light, porous, organic substance strewn on the ground, as over the roots of plants, to protect from heat, drought, etc., and to hinder weed growth and preserve moisture.

A sudden and energetic effort, as in an emergency; an increased exertion for a brief space.
Week.

A wooden or metal pin, set in the gunwale of a boat, to serve as a fulcrum for the oar in rowing.

Russian pancakes of buckwheat flour and yeast, sometimes made from white flour; they are usually served folded over, with caviar and sour cream on the inside; -- properly, it is a plural word (from the Russian plural of blin) but in America, often used as singular; thus the common plural blinis.

Any one of several species of sparoid fishes belonging to Sargus, Pomadasys, and related genera; -- called also sar, and saragu.

To regard with kindness; to support; to aid, or to have the disposition to aid, or to wish success to; to be propitious to; to treat with consideration or tenderness; to show partiality or unfair bias towards.

A unit of work which is equal to 107 ergs (the unit of work in the C. G. S. system of units), and is equivalent to one watt-second, the energy expended in one second by an electric current of one ampere in a resistance of one ohm; also called the absolute joule.  It is abbreviated J or j.  The international joule is slightly larger, being 1.000167 times the absolute joule.  The absolute joule is approximately equal to 0.737562 foot pounds, 0.239006 gram-calories (small calories),  and 3.72506 x 10-7 horsepower-hours, and 0.000948451 B.t.u.

To hold in extreme contempt; to reject as unworthy of regard; to despise; to contemn; to disdain.

A liquor made of rum and molasses.

A bitter, brownish yellow, amorphous substance, extracted from vegetable mold, and also produced by the action of acids on certain sugars and carbohydrates; -- called also humic acid, ulmin, gein, ulmic or geic acid, etc.
Virtue; power.  See Virtue.
A support for the spear when couched for the attack.
A red color used by painters.
The brother of one's father or mother; also applied to an aunt's husband; -- the correlative of aunt in sex, and of nephew and niece in relationship.
A summons to arms, as on the approach of an enemy.
Obs. pl. of Flea.
A breaking or dashing to pieces; utter destruction; wreck.
A short candle end used for igniting a fuse.
Amount yielded; product; -- applied especially to products resulting from growth or cultivation.
The Egyptian sycamore (Ficus Sycamorus). See Sycamore.
A disease of the glands under the ear in horses; the vives.
See Jorum.
A number of hermitages or cells in the same neighborhood occupied by anchorites who were under the same superior.
A coarse umbelliferous plant (Ligusticum actaeifolium) with a large aromatic root.  It is found chiefly in the Alleghany region.  Also called Angelico.
See Uncle.
One of a race inhabiting the valleys of the Pyrenees, who until 1793 were political and social outcasts (Christian Pariahs). They are supposed to be a remnant of the Visigoths.
Judea; also, a district inhabited by Jews; a Jews' quarter.
A ring for fastening a hawk's leash to the jesses; also, a ring affixed to the collar of a dog, etc.
A vagrant; an idle, sturdy beggar; a vagabond; a tramp.
The common perch. See 1st Bass.
Same as Borrel.
A hard, heavy, and durable wood, which admits of a fine polish or gloss. The usual color is black, but it also occurs red or green.
Noise; confusion; uproar.
The common mallow.
The whole body of salt water which covers more than three fifths of the surface of the globe; -- called also the sea, or great sea.
One who raves.
To pelt, beat, or kill with stones.

Any plant of the genus Carex, perennial, endogenous, innutritious herbs, often growing in dense tufts in marshy places. They have triangular jointless stems, a spiked inflorescence, and long grasslike leaves which are usually rough on the margins and midrib. There are several hundred species.
The black vulture (Catharista atrata). It ranges from the Southern United States to South America. See Vulture.
A stubble field left unplowed till late in the autumn, that it may be cropped by cattle.
A small Italian coin worth a sou or a cent; the twentieth part of a lira.
Dainty.
To eat sumptuously; to dine or sup on rich provisions, particularly in large companies, and on public festivals.
A copious gummy secretion of the humor of the eyelids, in consequence of some disorder; blearedness; lippitude.
A vital part; one of the vitals.
See Cultch.
A fine sieve; a searce.
A very short time; an instant; a moment; -- now used only in the phrase in a trice.
A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and often covered.
A mullet (Mugil capito) found in the rivers of Southern Europe and in Africa.
Mist; fog; vapors.
The pressure of one dyne per square centimeter; -- used as a unit of pressure.
Sap green.
To be ashamed; to feel shame.
A small, inclosed field, adjoining a house; a small farm.
any of the threadlike filaments forming the mycelium of a fungus.  See hyphae.
A South American striped frog (Pseudis paradoxa), remarkable for having a tadpole larger than the adult, and hence called also paradoxical frog.
an intricate traditional dance in India performed by professional dancing girls.

Any one of numerous species of small clamatorial birds belonging to Pipra and allied genera, of the family Piprid<ae/. The male is usually glossy black, varied with scarlet, yellow, or sky blue. They chiefly inhabit South America.
a special loved one; a darling; -- used as a term of endearment.
See Fogy.
pl. of Radius.
One of three sea nymphs, -- or, according to some writers, of two, -- said to frequent an island near the coast of Italy, and to sing with such sweetness that they lured mariners to destruction.

The act of visiting, or going to see a person or thing; a brief stay of business, friendship, ceremony, curiosity, or the like, usually longer than a call; as, a visit of civility or respect; a visit to Saratoga; the visit of a physician.
A species of Magnolia (Magnolia conspicua) with large white blossoms that open before the leaves.  See the Note under Magnolia.
essential oil or perfume obtained from flowers.
Olefiant gas or ethylene; -- so called by Berzelius from its forming an oil combining with chlorine. [Written also elayle.] See Ethylene.
The act of fainting, or the state of one who has fainted; a swoon. [R.] See Fainting, n.

An atom whose valence is six, and which can be theoretically combined with, substituted for, or replaced by, six monad atoms or radicals; as, sulphur is a hexad in sulphuric acid. Also used as an adjective.
The human body, as distinguished from the head and limbs; in sculpture, the trunk of a statue, mutilated of head and limbs; as, the torso of Hercules.
Same as Socle.
Among leather dealers, the thickest and stoutest tanned hides.
In India, a dependent person occupying a position between that of a servant or slave and a disciple; hence, a disciple or novice.
The Hebrew prophet, who was cast overboard as one who endangered the ship; hence, any person whose presence is unpropitious.
That point of the heavens, or lower hemisphere, directly opposite the zenith; the inferior pole of the horizon; the point of the celestial sphere directly under the place where we stand.
A privy.
A military headdress or cap, used in the British army. It is of fur, with a bag, of the same color as the facings of the regiment, hanging from the top over the right shoulder.
A kind of bread. See Pone.
The piece by which an object is attached to something, as the frog of a scabbard or the metal loop at the back of a buckle by which it is fastened to a strap.
A genus of tropical plants, with large leaves and often with showy flowers. The Indian shot (Canna Indica) is found in gardens of the northern United States.
A draught or model from which to build; especially, one of the full size of the work to be done; a detailed drawing.
A saddlecloth; a housing.

A game of chance, played with cards or tickets, on which are inscribed numbers, and any contrivance (as a wheel containing numbered balls) for determining a set of numbers by chance.  The player holding a card having on it the set of numbers drawn from the wheel takes the stakes after a certain percentage of them has been deducted for the dealer.  In some systems, lesser prizes are awarded for having some but not all of the numbers selected, such as four or five numbers in a six-number drawing.  A variety of lotto is called keno.  In another variety, the player chooses the numbers for the card or ticket s/he holds.  There may be from three to seven different numbers on a card or ticket.  In a modern computerized lotto system conducted by state authorities, the player chooses numbers, or allows the computer to choose numbers at random, which are then printed on a ticket that the player holds until the winning number is selected.
The mink.
The Amish Mennonites.
A small loop or bow of ribbon used in making hats, boas, etc.

A gentlewoman; -- an appellation or courteous form of address given to a lady, especially an elderly or a married lady; -- much used in the address, at the beginning of a letter, to a woman. The corresponding word in addressing a man is Sir; often abbreviated ma'am when used as a term of address.
the type genus of the Buxaceae.
A village composed of Arab tents arranged in streets.
See Gayal.
To yield fruit.
A scythe.
A shield or protective armor; -- applied in mythology to the shield of Jupiter which he gave to Minerva.  Also fig.: A shield; a protection.
A fine rain; a thick mist; a mizzle; a drizzle.
An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.
One of the ends of weaver's threads; hence, any soft, short threads or tufts resembling these.
A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20 sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.
A genus of cycadaceous plants, having the appearance of low palms, but with exogenous wood.  See Coontie, and Illust. of Strobile.

A weapon of war, consisting of a long shaft or handle and a steel blade or head; a spear carried by horsemen, and often decorated with a small flag; also, a spear or harpoon used by whalers and fishermen.
A piece of wood, usually long and slender, pointed at one end so as to be easily driven into the ground as a support or stay; as, a stake to support vines, fences, hedges, etc.

A long-nosed monkey (Nasalis larvatus, formerly Semnopithecus nasalis), native of Borneo. The general color of the body is bright chestnut, with the under parts, shoulders, and sides of the head, golden yellow, and the top of the head and upper part of the back brown. Called also proboscis monkey.  It is now an endangered species.
A youth or scholar of either sex under the care of an instructor or tutor.
See Rigel.
An opening; a hollow; a bending.
The act of hurling or flinging; a driving or propelling from the hand or an engine; a cast.
Sadness; dismalness.

A serpent or monster in the lake or marsh of Lerna, in the Peloponnesus, represented as having many heads, one of which, when cut off, was immediately succeeded by two others, unless the wound was cauterized. It was slain by Hercules. Hence, a terrible monster.
Labor; toilsome effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural in form, but used with a singular or plural verb, commonly the former.
A small shield.
an East Indian annual erect herb (Sesamum indicum); the source of sesame seed or benniseed and sesame oil.  Same as benne

A demise or letting of lands, tenements, or hereditaments to another for life, for a term of years, or at will, or for any less interest than that which the lessor has in the property, usually for a specified rent or compensation.

A mode of expressing words and phrases by pictures of objects whose names resemble those words, or the syllables of which they are composed; enigmatical representation of words by figures; hence, a peculiar form of riddle made up of such representations.
The shag.
The foundation of anything; that on which a thing rests.
Plaster as used in Persian architecture and decorative art.
See Labium.
A muraena.
A European owl (Syrnium aluco) of a tawny color; -- called also uluia.
An oceanic fish of large size (Elacate canada); the crabeater; -- called also bonito, cubbyyew, coalfish, and sergeant fish.
One of a Dravidian race of men native of Northern Ceylon and Southern India.
Var. of Chica.
The deposit of slime at the mouth of a river; slime.
A shaft or gallery to drain a mine.
A mournful or plaintive poem; a funereal song; a poem of lamentation.
A level; a working.
A tilting match; a mock combat on horseback between two knights in the lists or inclosed field.
Same as Knop, 2.
A diminutive of Ann or Anne, the proper name.
A plaited, quilled, or goffered strip of lace, net, ribbon, or other material, -- used in place of collars or cuffs, and as a trimming for women's dresses and bonnets.
a French garlic-flavored mayonnaise.  It is often served with fish and other seafood, and sometimes with vegetables.
A panegyrical funeral oration.
Existence, as opposed to nonexistence; state or sphere of existence.
one of a pair of attached small drums, each tuned to a different pitch, played by striking with the hands.
Same as Fumage.
A cast from the hand; a throw; also, a flounce; a kick; as, the fling of a horse.

Any of a variety of oily or greasy organic compounds found as major structural components of living cells; they are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents such as alcohol and ether, and include the common fats, cholesterol and other steroids, phospholipids, sphingolipids, waxes, and fatty acids; some of the lipids, together with proteins and carbohydrates, form an essential structural component of living cells, as in the cell walls and membranes.  The term lipid refers to its solubility in nonpolar solvents, and has no significance with regard to chemical structure.
See Shah.
One of the two long pieces of wood, extending before a vehicle, between which a horse is hitched; a shaft.
A low, moaning sound; usually, a deep, mournful sound uttered in pain or great distress; sometimes, an expression of strong disapprobation; as, the remark was received with groans.
One of the minute apertures between the cells in many serous membranes.
the first decisive battle of the Hundred Years' War; in 1346 the English under Edward III defeated the French under King Philip of Valois.
A ring fitted upon the head of a lance to prevent wounding an adversary in tilting.
A mill for grinding grain, the upper stone of which was turned by hand; -- used before the invention of windmills and watermills.
A kick; a blow with the foot.
See Faker.
Same as Ousel.
An article of food; provisions; food; victuals; -- used chiefly in the plural.
Any aquatic mammal of the order Cetacea, especially any one of the large species, some of which become nearly one hundred feet long. Whales are hunted chiefly for their oil and baleen, or whalebone.
A compound radical, regarded as butane, less one atom of hydrogen.
A trifle.
The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; the person named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, the amount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange, under Bill.
Relic.
A choice taw or marble.

Water saturated or strongly impregnated with salt; pickle; hence, any strong saline solution; also, the saline residue or strong mother liquor resulting from the evaporation of natural or artificial waters.
Debeige.
A saying or utterance; especially, one that is short and frequently repeated; a theme.

An instrument for threshing or beating grain from the ear by hand, consisting of a wooden staff or handle, at the end of which a stouter and shorter pole or club, called a swipe, is so hung as to swing freely.
Fetters.

A rigid piece which is capable of turning about one point, or axis (the fulcrum), and in which are two or more other points where forces are applied; -- used for transmitting and modifying force and motion. Specif., a bar of metal, wood, or other rigid substance, used to exert a pressure, or sustain a weight, at one point of its length, by receiving a force or power at a second, and turning at a third on a fixed point called a fulcrum. It is usually named as the first of the six mechanical powers, and is of three kinds, according as either the fulcrum F, the weight W, or the power P, respectively, is situated between the other two, as in the figures.

The name of two plants (Sesamum orientale and Sesamum indicum), originally Asiatic; -- also called oil plant. From their seeds an oil is expressed, called benne oil or sesame oil, used mostly for making soap. In the southern United States the seeds are used in candy.
A race or variety of men or other animals (or of plants), perpetuating its special or distinctive characteristics by inheritance.
That with which one is gifted or endowed; endowment; gift.
A trinket; a jewel; -- a word applied to anything small and of elegant workmanship.
The four of cards or dice.

A kind of theater in ancient Greece, smaller than the dramatic theater and roofed over, in which poets and musicians submitted their works to the approval of the public, and contended for prizes; -- hence, in modern usage, the name of a hall for musical or dramatic performances.
A short, stout post used for any purpose, a to mark a boundary.
See sloakan.
the American Society of Cinematographers.
To try; to attempt; to apply.

To obstruct so as to prevent passage or progress; to prevent passage from, through, or into, by obstructing the way; -- used both of persons and things; -- often followed by up; as, to block up a road or harbor; to block an entrance.
A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua, allied to the raccoon, having a ringed tail but with a longer body, tail, and nose; -- called also coati mondi and coati mundi.

A partaker; a person having an interest in any action or thing; one who has an interest in an estate created by another; a person having an interest derived from a contract or conveyance to which he is not himself a party.  The term, in its proper sense, is distinguished from party.
All; -- a direction for all the singers or players to perform together.
A plaintive cry of, or like that of, a sheep.
A tract of land, over which boats or goods are carried between two bodies of navigable water; a carrying place; a portage.
A variety of rum.
A rapier; a sword; so named from Bilbao, in Spain.
A market place or public place in Rome, where causes were judicially tried, and orations delivered to the people.
Any pied animal; esp., a pied or <ldquo/painted<rdquo/ horse.
To go; to fare.
A weaver's reed; a sley.

The organ formed by the combination or union into one body of stem and leaf, and often bearing the fructification; as, the frond of a fern or of a lichen or seaweed; also, the peculiar leaf of a palm tree.
The blindworm.
Same as Sewen.
A dark blue scombroid food fish (Acanthocibium solandri or Acanthocibium petus) of Florida and the West Indies.
same as camass.
The whiteweed (Chrysanthemum Leucanthemum), the plant commonly called daisy in North America; -- called also oxeye daisy. See Whiteweed.
A pearly substance which lines the interior of many shells, and is most perfect in the mother-of-pearl.
An East Indian Weight of 1<frac13/ pounds.
The rotating part of a generator or motor.  Contrasted with stator, the stationary part.
A small New Zealand owl (Sceloglaux albifacies). It has short wings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
An African genet (Genetta pardina). See Genet.
One of several upright slender calcareous processes which surround the central part of the calicle of certain corals.
A fragment; -- now used only in composition, as in potsherd. See Shard.
Something drawn out or extended; expanse.
Ill luck; misfortune.
A twelfth part, as of the Roman as; an ounce.
One of a race of filthy brutes resembling men but subject to the Houyhnhnms in Swift's <ldquo/Gulliver's Travels.<rdquo/  See in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction.
A caldron of boiling water into which an accused person plunged his forearm as a test of innocence or guilt.
A jester; a buffoon.
Any species of marine gastropods, of the genera Nassa, Tritia, and other allied genera of the family Nassidae; a dog whelk. See Illust. under Gastropoda.
One of certain narrow, crooked valleys seen, by aid of the telescope, on the surface of the moon.
Potential energy; negative value of the force function.
One chosen or set apart.
A green vegetable dye imported from China.
A large basket or hamper of wickerwork, used for the transportation of china, crockery, and similar wares.
Stucco.
A lunar distance.
See Mucedin.
same as beanie.
See Fox, n., 7.
School.
Tophus.
Any leguminous plant of the genus Vicia, some species of which are valuable for fodder. The common species is Vicia sativa.
A sudden and capricious inclination of the mind.
A tall drinking cup.
The back part of the neck; the scruff.
Solace.
In mammals, a fluid excretion from the kidneys; in birds and reptiles, a solid or semisolid excretion.
One who puts out, ousts, or expels; also, an ouster; dispossession.
A lariat.
The upper part of a duet, trio, etc., either vocal or instrumental; -- so called because it generally expresses the air, and has a pre<eum/minence in the combined effect.
Goddess of the seasons, or of the hours of the day.
Any bird of the genus Junco, which includes several species of North American finches; -- called also snowbird, or blue snowbird.
A framework, trough, or tube, upon or through which objects are made to slide from a higher to a lower level, or through which water passes to a wheel.
To drive, as cattle or sheep, esp. on long journeys; to follow the occupation of a drover.
A whirlpool.
The capital city of Tibet; it is the sacred city of Lamaism.
One who tries; one who makes experiments; one who examines anything by a test or standard.

A large cervine mammal (Alces alces syn. Alces machlis, syn Alces Americanus), native of the Northern United States and Canada. The adult male is about as large as a horse, and has very large, palmate antlers. It closely resembles the European elk, and by many Zoologists is considered the same species. See Elk.
One who makes a vow.
A particular method or pattern of weaving; as, the cassimere weave.
Sir; -- a title of respect used by the French.
The female of the canine kind, as of the dog, wolf, and fox.
Song; melody.
A monatomic, hydrocarbon radical, C2H5 of the paraffin series, forming the essential radical of ethane, and of common alcohol and ether.
Smell; odor.
Plural form of mare, a dark region of considerable extent on the surface of the moon.
A little bag or budget.
A burning of the surface; a slight burn.
See Slant.
Any opinion, principle, dogma, belief, or doctrine, which a person holds or maintains as true; as, the tenets of Plato or of Cicero.

A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonance in the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving to each several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound of speech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whether made with or without vocality, derives its character in every case from some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, a letter or character which represents such a sound.  See Guide to Pronunciation, <sect/<sect/ 5, 146-149.

Any one of several small, fresh-water, cyprinoid fishes of the genera Cobitis, Nemachilus, and allied genera, having six or more barbules around the mouth. They are found in Europe and Asia. The common European species (Nemachilus barbatulus) is used as a food fish.
Possibility; uncertainty.
The ahu, or jairou.
A yeoman.
Report; rumor; fame.
A plant (Salvia sclarea) of the Sage family, used in flavoring soups.
A contemptuous speech or piece of conduct; a gibe or flout.
A harsh nasal noise made in sleep.
The years of one's age having the termination -teen, beginning with thirteen and ending with nineteen; as, a girl in her teens.
See Ankle.
A person of rank above a commoner; a nobleman; a peer.
A South American armadillo (Dasypus sexcinctus). Called also sixbanded armadillo.
Scattered or ejected spittle.
An article of food made from flour or meal by moistening, kneading, and baking.
A genus of longeared South American monkeys, including numerous species of marmosets. See Marmoset.
A pear tree.
See Sneck.
A snath.
One who adheres to or believes the doctrines of Arius.
The breast of a human being; the part, between the arms, to which anything is pressed when embraced by them.
An inclosed place; especially, a small field or piece of land surrounded by a wall, hedge, or fence of any kind; -- specifically, the precinct of a cathedral or abbey.
A player at dice; a dice player; a gamester.
The young of a beast brought forth prematurely, esp. a calf brought forth before its time.
A waif; a castaway.
A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound. See Foot pound.
A leaf bud, as distinguished from a flower bud.
The apartments or portion of the house allotted to females in Muslim families.
A region; country.
An unshaped piece or mass of wood or other substance.
See Cymry.
A hermit.
An explosive consisting of ammonium nitrate, a derivative of nitrobenzene, chlorated napthalene, and wood meal.
A visitor; a person received and entertained in one's house or at one's table; a visitor entertained without pay.
A term of endearment; darling; -- corrupted from honey.
A suffusion of the cheeks or face with red, as from a sense of shame, confusion, or modesty.
To possess or exercise sovereign power or authority; to exercise government, as a king or emperor;; to hold supreme power; to rule.
Tread; footing.
A step or stepping; pressure with the foot; a footstep; as, a nimble tread; a cautious tread.

A note or character of time, equivalent to two semibreves or four minims. When dotted, it is equal to three semibreves. It was formerly of a square figure (as thus: <?/ ), but is now made oval, with a line perpendicular to the staff on each of its sides; -- formerly much used for choir service.

A composition, in prose or poetry, accommodated to action, and intended to exhibit a picture of human life, or to depict a series of grave or humorous actions of more than ordinary interest, tending toward some striking result. It is commonly designed to be spoken and represented by actors on the stage.
A South American butterfly (Ithonia phono) having nearly transparent wings.
A fir pole of from four to seven inches diameter, and twenty to forty feet long, sometimes roughly hewn, used for scaffoldings, and sometimes for slight and common roofs, for which use it is split.
A male waiting servant; a servant who attends on a gentleman's person; a body servant.
Anything which is laid, set, or spread, upon, about, or over, another thing; an envelope; a lid; as, the cover of a book.
To form a group of; to arrange or combine in a group or in groups, often with reference to mutual relation and the best effect; to form an assemblage of.
A sudden, overpowering fright; esp., a sudden and groundless fright; terror inspired by a trifling cause or a misapprehension of danger; as, the troops were seized with a panic; they fled in a panic.

Plaster combined with fibrous and other materials so as to be suitable for sculpture in relief or in the round, or for forming flat plates or boards of considerable size which can be nailed to framework to make the exterior of a larger structure, forming joints which may afterward be repaired and concealed with fresh plaster.

That which terminates, circumscribes, restrains, or confines; the bound, border, or edge; the utmost extent; as, the limit of a walk, of a town, of a country; the limits of human knowledge or endeavor.
A reel used in dyeing, steeping, or washing cloth; a winch. It is placed over the division wall between two wince pits so as to allow the cloth to descend into either compartment. at will.
The boce; -- called also bogue bream. See Boce.
Brightness or luster of a body proceeding from a smooth surface; polish; as, the gloss of silk; cloth is calendered to give it a gloss.
Good-humored raillery.
A Chaldean astronomical period or cycle, the length of which has been variously estimated from 3,600 years to 3,600 days, or a little short of 10 years.

Any one of numerous species of small rodents belonging to the genus Mus and various related genera of the family Muridae.  The common house mouse (Mus musculus) is found in nearly all countries.  The American white-footed mouse, or deer mouse (Peromyscus leucopus, formerly Hesperomys leucopus) sometimes lives in houses.  See Dormouse, Meadow mouse, under Meadow, and Harvest mouse, under Harvest.
One who hires.
Husband.
The fossil resin of the kauri tree of New Zealand.
Amall shrubby African tree (Brachystegia speciformis) having compound leaves and racemes of small fragrant green flowers.
A machine for fanning a room, usually a movable fanlike frame covered with canvas, and suspended from the ceiling. It is kept in motion by pulling a cord.
The wild radish.
In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burden bearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
An immigrant.

A graceful and swift South African antelope (Pelea capreola).  The hair is woolly, and ash-gray on the back and sides.  The horns are black, long, slender, straight, nearly smooth, and very sharp.  Called also rheeboc, rhebuck, rhebok, and rehboc.
The inner, or preaxial, and usually the larger, of the two bones of the leg or hind limb below the knee.
One of the largest African antelopes (Hippotragusnasomaculatus or Oryx nasomaculatus).
The breeze fly. See Breeze.
See Bots.
One of a series of series of complex nitrogenous substances, represented by methyl ketol and related to indol.
One who, or that which, rides.

Lit., skilled mechanical work, such as that required in wood carving; trade work; hence, a system (usually called the sloyd system) of manual training in the practical use of the tools and materials used in the trades, and of instruction in the making and use of the plans and specifications connected with trade work. The  sloyd system derives its name from the fact that it was adopted or largely developed from a similar Swedish system, in which wood carving was a chief feature. Its purpose is not only to afford practical skill in some trade, but also to develop the pupils mentally and physically.

The fluid which is excreted from the skin of an animal; the fluid secreted by the sudoriferous glands; a transparent, colorless, acid liquid with a peculiar odor, containing some fatty acids and mineral matter; perspiration. See Perspiration.
A winding or zigzag trench forming a path or communication from one siegework to another, to a magazine, etc.
A slow unwieldy trading vessel.
One of several species of European thrushes, especially the blackbird (Merula merula, or Turdus merula), and the mountain or ring ousel (Turdus torquatus).

A house or room artificially warmed or heated; a forcing house, or hothouse; a drying room; -- formerly, designating an artificially warmed dwelling or room, a parlor, or a bathroom, but now restricted, in this sense, to heated houses or rooms used for horticultural purposes or in the processes of the arts.
Same as Quipu.
The Indian antelope (Antilope bezoartica syn.  Antilope cervicapra), noted for its beauty and swiftness. It has long, spiral, divergent horns.
Exchange of commodities; barter.
The whortleberry, or bilberry.  See Whortleberry (a).
The fluid which descends from the clouds in rain, and which forms rivers, lakes, seas, etc.
An implement consisting of a small bowl (usually a shallow oval) with a handle, used especially in preparing or eating food.
Wine produced on the island of Capri, commonly a light, dry, white wine.
A variety of cabbage (Brassica oleracea), cultivated for its seeds, which yield an oil valued for illuminating and lubricating purposes; summer rape.
The collection of attributes which make up the nature of a god; divinity; godhead; as, the deity of the Supreme Being is seen in his works.
A wrinkling of the face in displeasure, rebuke, etc.; a sour, severe, or stern look; a scowl.
A bugbear; false terror.
A keen-edged knife of peculiar shape, used in shaving the hair from the face or the head; also called a straight razor.
Realm.
A flake; a thread or twist.
See Alarum, and Alarm.
See Poise.
A track left by man or beast; a track followed by the hunter; a scent on the ground by the animal pursued; as, a deer trail.
Adherence; attachment; devotion.
The scab or itch in cattle, dogs, and other beasts.
See Scutum.
Willow.
See Peony.
The grasscloth plant (B<oe/hmeria nivea); also, its fiber, which is very fine and exceedingly strong; -- called also China grass, and rhea. See Grass-cloth plant, under Grass.
See Waft, n., 4.
An empty box, crate, cask, etc.; -- used in commerce, esp. in transportation of freight; as, <ldquo/special rates for empties.<rdquo/

A great flow of water; a body of moving water; the flowing stream, as of a river; especially, a body of water, rising, swelling, and overflowing land not usually thus covered; a deluge; a freshet; an inundation.
War.
Noise; din; esp.; confused noise, clamor, or hum of many voices, notes of birds, or the like.

A substance found in great abundance on some coasts or islands frequented by sea fowls, and composed chiefly of their excrement. It is rich in phosphates and ammonia, and is used as a powerful fertilizer.
A genus of herbs with compound white or bluish flowers; starwort; Michaelmas daisy.
A pet name for a rabbit or a squirrel.
A note upon an author.
The act of seeing; perception of objects by the eye; view; as, to gain sight of land.
A flight of wild fowl (wild geese or the like).
See Calk.

A contagious disease of horses, associated with painful ulcerating enlargements, esp. upon the head and limbs. It is of the same nature as glanders, and is often fatal. Called also farcin, and farcimen.
A pie consisting usually of meat wholly surrounded with a crust made of a sheet of paste, and often baked without a dish; a meat pie.
One of the segments of the abdomen or post-abdomen of arthropods.
A bitter purgative principle in aloes.
A crystallized substance of the composition C4I4NH, technically tetra-iodo-pyrrol, used like iodoform.
A bale of raw silk.
To balance; to make of equal weight; as, to poise the scales of a balance.
See Coif.

The fronds of certain marine alg<ae/ used as food, and for making a sauce called laver sauce.  Green laver is the Ulva latissima; purple laver, Porphyra laciniata and Porphyra vulgaris. It is prepared by stewing, either alone or with other vegetables, and with various condiments; -- called also sloke, or sloakan.
A fight in which the combatants are mingled in one confused mass; a hand to hand conflict; an affray.
The bottom part of a mold or of a flask, in distinction from the cope; the drag.
See Paunch.
A surplice, in England and America usually one shorter and less full than the ordinary surplice and with short sleeves, or sometimes none.
See Gobbet.
A very venomous snake of India (Bungarus coeruleus), allied to the cobra.  Its upper parts are bluish or brownish black, often with narrow white streaks; the belly is whitish.

Anything used for catching and retaining or communicating fire, made of some substance which takes fire readily, or remains burning some time; esp., a small strip or splint of wood or cardboard dipped at one end in a substance which can be easily ignited by friction, as a preparation of phosphorus or chlorate of potassium.
See Pavan.

the process by which objects or materials acquire desirable qualities by being left undisturbed for some time under specific conditions.  It is used mostly for foods snd beverages, but also for other materials.
To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow ceremoniously, or courtesy.
The vitreous coating of pottery or porcelain; anything used as a coating or color in glazing. See Glaze, v. t., 3.
A foister; a sharper.
A vulture; the griffin.

A person who is held in bondage to another; one who is wholly subject to the will of another; one who is held as a chattel; one who has no freedom of action, but whose person and services are wholly under the control of another.
A large species of barbel (Barbus bynni), found in the Nile, and much esteemed for food.
A narrow piece, or one comparatively long; as, a strip of cloth; a strip of land.
A place dug; a pit; a ditch; a den; a cave.
Forced separation from one's native country; expulsion from one's home by the civil authority; banishment; sometimes, voluntary separation from one's native country.
A genus of robust East Asian clump-forming perennial herbs having racemose flowers: plantain lilies; sometimes placed in the family Hostaceae.
The hartbeest.
Lager beer.
The local environment; as, he hasn't been seen around these parts in years.
the people of Great Britain.
See Grilse.
A genus of American herbs, having showy red, white, or purple flowers.
A premium given for a loan, or for a charter or other privilege granted to a company; as the bank paid a bonus for its charter.
An adjustable catch, bent plate, or hook, for holding together two objects or the parts of anything, as the ends of a belt, the covers of a book, etc.
A Hebrew weight for gold or silver, being one hundred shekels of gold and sixty shekels of silver.
A rubber of hard wood used in smoothing marble to be polished.
A white tablet on which anything was inscribed, as a list of names, etc.
A boy's game played with large marbles.
The rump of beef; esp., the lower and back part of the rump.
A solid resembling an egg in shape.

Sound uttered by the mouth, especially that uttered by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character; as, the human voice; a pleasant voice; a low voice.
A kind of fur prepared from lambskin dressed with the wool on; -- used formerly as an edging and ornament, esp. of scholastic habits.
Any spider crab of the genus Maia, or family Maiadae.
A spiral; a curl; a whorl; a twist.
A small boom, pole, or spar, which crosses the sail of a boat diagonally from the mast to the upper aftmost corner, which it is used to extend and elevate.
A thick, viscid fluid; a clot, as of blood.
One of the genus Aphis; an aphidian.
A register of daily events or transactions; a daily record; a journal; a blank book dated for the record of daily memoranda; as, a diary of the weather; a physician's diary.
A fall or falling band.
Apparel.
Same as Sewen.
A debt; an entry on the debtor (Dr.) side of an account; -- mostly used adjectively; as, the debit side of an account.
The proximal segment of the hind limb containing the thigh bone; the thigh. See Coxa.
That which is void or empty.

A dish made by boiling any article of food to a pulp and then blending it or rubbing it through a sieve; as, a pur<eacute/e of fish, or of potatoes; especially, a soup the thickening of which is so treated.
A small shoot or twig of a tree or other plant; a spray; as, a sprig of laurel or of parsley.
A sieve, or strainer, made of a kind of woolen cloth.
The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or love deified.
The inward part of a building; the interior.
To break in a stave or the staves of; to break a hole in; to burst; -- often with in; as, to stave a cask; to stave in a boat.
A light or luminary formed of some combustible substance, as of resinous wood; a large candle or flambeau, or a lamp giving a large, flaring flame.
A South American carnivore (Galera barbara) allied to the grison. The tail is long and thick. The length, including the tail, is about three feet.
Sullenness; silent displeasure; the sulks.
One of a certain description of militia among the Tartars.
A kind of fine sand from the banks of the Trent, used as a polishing powder.

One of a class of basic substances derived from ammonia by replacement of one or more hydrogen atoms by an alkyl or aryl group.  Compare amide, in which an acyl group is attached to the nitrogen.  Hydroxylamine and hydrazine, which are not an organic compounds, are also basic and may also be considered amines.
a tropical American palm (Acrocomia vinifera) having edible nuts and yielding a useful fiber.
Property; -- often used by Chaucer in contrast with rent, or income.
Like a miss, or girl.
Sword.
A spangle or shining ornament.
Same as Bourr<eacute/e.
An abyss; a gulf.
One who idles; one who spends his time in inaction; a lazy person; a sluggard.
One of the long, pliable twigs of this plant, or of other similar plants.
A gay or sportive action; a ludicrous, merry, or mischievous trick; a caper; a frolic.

An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whose sides are equal and the opposite sides parallel.  The angles may be unequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the angles may be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.

A native double salt, consisting of a combination of neutral and acid sodium carbonate, Na2CO3.2HNaCO3.2H2O, occurring as a white crystalline fibrous deposit from certain soda brine springs and lakes; -- called also urao, and by the ancients nitrum.
A fluid state.

A diseased state of the system, marked by increased heat, acceleration of the pulse, and a general derangement of the functions, including usually, thirst and loss of appetite.  Many diseases, of which fever is the most prominent symptom, are denominated fevers; as, typhoid fever; yellow fever.
A catkin or ament. See Ament.

A form of dark matter in distant outer space unobservable except by its gravitational effect, and believed to be at least part of the <ldquo/missing matter<rdquo/ which is unobservable as ordinary stars, but helps keep galaxies from flying apart; MACHOS are massive but compact objects such as neutron stars or brown dwarfs, which can be detected (with difficulty) by their effect in bending light from distant light sources, such as other galaxies.  This can occur if by rare chance a MACHO passes in front of a more distant visible object, and the light from that object becomes temporarily amplified by the MACHO acting as a gravitational lens.  Some MACHOs have been discovered in the halo of dark matter that surrounds our milky way.  It is, however, questionable whether the amount of such matter is sufficient to explain the ability of galaxies to stay together in spite of rotation rates that would cause them to fly apart if the only matter present was that observable as visible stars.
A volatile liquid obtained by boiling sulphur with linseed oil.  It has an unpleasant garlic odor.
A little mass or weight of lead, or the like, attached to a line, and used by builders, etc., to indicate a vertical direction; a plummet; a plumb bob. See Plumb line, below.
A dog with long hair or shag; -- called also shockdog.

A carpenter's tool for boring holes larger than those bored by a gimlet. It has a handle placed crosswise by which it is turned with both hands. A pod auger is one with a straight channel or groove, like the half of a bean pod. A screw auger has a twisted blade, by the spiral groove of which the chips are discharge.
A tap or stamp of the foot as a warning of intent to attack; -- called also attack.
See Good, n., 3.
A hautboy or oboe.
A line, ridge, furrow, or band of fibers, especially in the median line; as, the raphe of the tongue.
One who wakes.
The characteristic fluid of any vegetable or animal substance; the sap or part which can be expressed from fruit, etc.; the fluid part which separates from meat in cooking.
The quotient of one divided by nine; one of nine equal parts of a thing; the next after the eighth.
That which draws along; especially, persuasion, artifice, or enticement; allurement.
A genus of venomous ticks which attack men and animals.  The famous Persian Argas, also called Miana bug, is Argas Persicus; that of Central America, called talaje by the natives, is Argas Talaje.
A battle; an engagement; a contest in arms; a combat; a violent conflict or struggle for victory, between individuals or between armies, ships, or navies, etc.
The zebra.
To injure, mar, spoil, or harm.
A kind of millet, cultivated throughout Asia, and introduced into the south of Europe; a variety of Sorghum vulgare; -- called also Indian millet, and Guinea corn.
One who collects bees into a hive.
A short, precise step; an affected manner.
The act of trying or testing in any manner.

A member of the sect of the Babis consisting of the adherents of Baha (Mirza Husain Ali, entitled <ldquo/Baha 'u 'llah,<rdquo/ or, <ldquo/the Splendor of God<rdquo/), the elder half brother of Mirza Yahya of Nur, who succeeded the Bab as the head of the Babists.  Baha in 1863 declared himself the supreme prophet of the sect, and became its recognized head.  There are upwards of 20,000 Bahais in the United States.
A property depending on the relations of light to the eye, by which individual and specific differences in the hues and tints of objects are apprehended in vision; as, gay colors; sad colors, etc.
A hunch.
One who owns; a rightful proprietor; one who has the legal or rightful title, whether he is the possessor or not.
The entire thing; the entire assemblage of parts; totality; all of a thing, without defect or exception; a thing complete in itself.
A gummy substance of the pentosan class, present in woody tissue, and yielding xylose on hydrolysis; wood gum.
To effect as an agent; to produce; to be the occasion of; to bring about; to bring into existence; to make; -- usually followed by an infinitive, sometimes by that with a finite verb.
A lock of wool or hair.
A small flat loaf or thick cake; also, a fagot.
Work varnished and figured in the Japanese manner; also, the varnish or lacquer used in japanning.
Proof.
A silk cloth, of a thick, close texture, and overshot woof, which has a glossy surface.
Purpose; determination.
Forbearance to inflict harm under circumstances of provocation, when one has the power to inflict it; compassionate treatment of an offender or adversary; clemency.
The back.
A person having a common right or privilege with another; a partner.

A peculiar mammal (Okapia johnstoni) closely related to the giraffe, discovered in the deep forests of Belgian Congo in 1900.  It is smaller than an ox, and somewhat like a giraffe, except that the neck is much shorter.  Like the giraffe, it has no dewclaws.  There is a small prominence on each frontal bone of the male.  The color of the body is chiefly reddish chestnut, the cheeks are yellowish white, and the fore and hind legs above the knees and the haunches are striped with purplish black and cream color.
One of the minute grains in flowerless plants, which are analogous to seeds, as serving to reproduce the species.
One of the small bulbs developed in the axils of the scales of a large bulb, as in the case of garlic.
A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.
Gain in money or goods; profit; riches; -- often in an ill sense.
A high, proud, stately step or walk.
An involuntary and unnatural contraction of one or more muscles or muscular fibers.
A colloquial or humorous appellation for a negro; sometimes, the offspring of a black person and a mulatto; a zambo.
A brown amorphous substance found in decaying vegetation.  Cf. Humin.
The branch of a tree partly cut or bent, and bound to, or intertwined with, other branches.
Circuit or compass.
a genus comprising the squash bugs.
a battle in the War of the Grand Alliance in Ireland in 1690, where William III of England defeated the deposed James II and so ended Stuart Catholicism in England.
A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate their aproach to a place.
An evergreen leguminous tree (Ceratania Siliqua) found in the countries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; -- called also carob tree.
a dividend, especially one paid by a cooperative society.
A bay, recess, or inlet of the sea, or the mouth of a river, which affords anchorage and shelter for shipping; a harbor; a port.

Any one numerous species of large marine gastropods belonging to Buccinum and allied genera; especially, Buccinum undatum, common on the coasts both of Europe and North America, and much used as food in Europe.
pl. of Woman.
A burning piece of wood; or a stick or piece of wood partly burnt, whether burning or after the fire is extinct.
One who hides or conceals.
Scorn; derision; abusive talk.
A pack sack to be swung on either side of a packsaddle.
A long, pointed weapon, used in war and hunting, by thrusting or throwing; a weapon with a long shaft and a sharp head or blade; a lance.
A choir or chorus.
A sterile transformed stamen.
A fertile or green spot in a waste or desert, esp. in a sandy desert, where the water table approaches the surface.
An irregular, narrow, projecting part of a field.
A slice; as, a shive of bread.
A fried, or sometimes baked, turnover made from a round or square sheet of dough containing a filling, usually of meat or potatoes.
The language spoken in the Isle of Man. See Manx.
the rapid shut down of a nuclear reactor, as in an emergency.
A pillow.
Same as Almug (and etymologically preferable).
A loose outer garment, extending from the neck downwards, and commonly without sleeves. It is longer than a cape, and is worn both by men and by women.
A genus of hemipterous insects of which the bedbug is the best known example. See Bedbug.
A holiday.
A grove.
A channel or hollow worn in the earth by a current of water; a short deep portion of a torrent's bed when dry.
A movement or piece in largo time.

An instrument, usually of metal, consisting of two parts, or long shafts, jointed together at or near one end, or united by an elastic bow, used for handling things, especially hot coals or metals; -- often called a pair of tongs.
The carrion crow.
A little elf or urchin.
A physician or surgeon; a professor of the art of healing.
A four-wheeled truck, having a certain amount of play around a vertical axis, used to support in part a locomotive on a railway track.
A shelter. Same as Beild.
A prison cell; a lockup; -- probably orig. the name of the noted prison in Southwark, England.
a negro; an African-American; -- an older term now considered offensive.
A cord; specifically, the umbilical cord or navel string.
A Venetian coin, worth about three English farthings, or one and a half cents.
A room or rooms behind that part of the exterior; all the rooms immediately below the roof.
A species of wild goose (Branta bernicla) -- called also brent and brand goose. The name is also applied to other related species.
The lading or freight of a ship or other vessel; the goods, merchandise, or whatever is conveyed in a vessel or boat; load; freight.
A wandering; a roving or irregular course.

A shrub or small tree of the genus Corylus, as the Corylus avellana, bearing a nut containing a kernel of a mild, farinaceous taste; the filbert.  The American species are Corylus Americana, which produces the common hazelnut, and Corylus rostrata.  See Filbert.
A kind of toy or rude musical instrument, as a tube inside of which is a stretched string or membrane made to vibrate by singing or humming into the tube.
Any of several thermoplastic polyamide plastics, comprising a family of high-strength resilient synthetic materials, used mostly in fibers.
A broken gait of a horse, between an amble and a gallop; -- commonly called a Canterbury gallop.
One who, or that which, bites; that which bites often, or is inclined to bite, as a dog or fish.
The tender leaves or leafstalks of the artichoke, white beet, etc., blanched for table use.
A Dravidian of a group of tribes of Orissa, India, a section of whom were formerly noted for their cruel human sacrifices to the earth goddess, murder of female infants, and marriage by capture.
See Nix.
A sort of gold or silver lace.

The quality or state of being proud; inordinate self-esteem; an unreasonable conceit of one's own superiority in talents, beauty, wealth, rank, etc., which manifests itself in lofty airs, distance, reserve, and often in contempt of others.
An edible fish of the Nile (genus Chromis).
To perform in a hasty, neglectful, or imperfect manner; to do superficially.
A step, or set of steps, for ascending and descending, in passing a fence or wall.
To hasten; to hurry.
A plant, and its flower, of the ranunculaceous genus P<ae/onia.  Of the four or five species, one is a shrub; the rest are perennial herbs with showy flowers, often double in cultivation.
The quotient of a unit divided by six; one of six equal parts which form a whole.
The slope of the ditch nearest the parapet; the escarp.
A kick, as of a beast, from impatience or uneasiness.

A light and elegantly furnished vessel, used either for private parties of pleasure, or as a vessel of state to convey distinguished persons from one place to another; a seagoing vessel used only for pleasure trips, racing, etc.
The expressed juice of apples. It is used as a beverage, for making vinegar, and for other purposes.
A person of mixed blood.
One who loses by sloth or neglect; a worthless person; a lorel.
See Meros.
A fool; a simpleton.
A plain.  See pampas.

A blowing apparatus, in which air, drawn into the upper part of a vertical tube through side holes by a stream of water within, is carried down with the water into a box or chamber below which it is led to a furnace.
In the old Norse mythology, the gods Odin, Thor, Loki, Balder, Frigg, and the others.  Their home was called Asgard.
The course or way which is traveled or passed, or is to be passed; a passing; a course; a road or path; a march.
A mark left by anything passing; a track; a path; a course; a footprint; a vestige; as, the trace of a carriage or sled; the trace of a deer; a sinuous trace.
one of several units of heat, especially one equivalent to 1000 large calories, or 100,000 British thermal units.
A corruption of the word faith.
Invocation of evil spirits; witchcraft.
To drop from a high place upon sharp stakes or hooks, as the Turks dropped malefactors, by way of punishment.

Any of a variety of edible unleavened doughey preparations made from flour, eggs and water, originating in Italy, and shaped into various forms, such as solid strings (as spaghetti), hollow tubes, or layered squares (ravioli).  They may be mixed with various sauces, often having a tomato base, or filled with meat or cheese fillings.

A faculty, possessed by animals, of perceiving external objects by means of impressions made upon certain organs (sensory or sense organs) of the body, or of perceiving changes in the condition of the body; as, the senses of sight, smell, hearing, taste, and touch. See Muscular sense, under Muscular, and Temperature sense, under Temperature.
A bean-shaped coin of Siam, worth about sixty cents; also, a weight equal to 236 grains troy.
A name applied to various skin diseases, but especially to ringworm. See Ringworm, and Sycosis.
An untimely birth.
A genus which in some classifications considered a genus of the subfamily Lutrinae.
To cover with cloth, leather, or other material; to bandage; patch, or mend, with a clout.
A station, as for collection of customs, for palanquin bearers, police, etc.
The order of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sawfishes, skates, and rays; -- called also Rajae, and Rajii.
A tinsmith's stake, or small anvil.
One who cites.
Any one of numerous marine gastropods of the genus Turbo or family Turbinidae, usually having a turbinate shell, pearly on the inside, and a calcareous operculum.
In the German army, one belonging to a body of light infantry armed with rifles, resembling the chasseur of the French army.
The first letter in the Greek alphabet, answering to A, and hence used to denote the beginning.
A tropical American tree (Annona diversifolia) grown in the southern U. S. having a whitish pink-tinged fruit.
See Saker.
The method in which the parts of a plant are arranged; also, the position of the parts.
Spelter.
The fourth month of the year.
One of the hereditary classes into which the Hindu are divided according to the laws of Brahmanism.
A detent, pawl, or ratchet, as that which catches the cogs of a ratchet wheel to prevent backward motion. See Illust. of Ratched wheel.

The aforesaid thing; the same (as before). Often contracted to do., or to two <ldquo/turned commas<rdquo/ (<rdquo/), or small marks.  Used in bills, books of account, tables of names, etc., to save repetition.
A fountain.
Cider.
A fruit tree (Durio zibethinus, the only species known) of the Indian Archipelago.  It bears the durian.

One dispatched upon an errand or mission; a messenger; esp., a person deputed by a sovereign or a government to negotiate a treaty, or transact other business, with a foreign sovereign or government; a minister accredited to a foreign government. An envoy's rank is below that of an ambassador.
A morbid swelling, prominence, or growth, on any part of the body; especially, a growth produced by deposition of new tissue; a neoplasm.
Nonsecretion or defective secretion of urine; ischury.
See Favus, n., 2.
A convoluted ridge between grooves; a convolution; as, the gyri of the brain; the gyri of brain coral.  See Brain.
See Shawm.

A colorless, odorless gas occurring in the air (of which it constitutes 0.93 per cent by volume), in volcanic gases, etc.; -- so named on account of its inertness by Rayleigh and Ramsay, who prepared and examined it in 1894-95. Symbol, A; at. wt., 39.9. Argon is condensible to a colorless liquid boiling at -186.1<deg/ C. and to a solid melting at -189.6<deg/ C. It has a characteristic spectrum. No compounds of it are known, but there is physical evidence that its molecule is monatomic. Weight of one liter at 0<deg/ C. and 760 mm., 1.7828 g.
A puppet.
A whirling motion; an eddy, as of water; a whirl.
See 2d Settee.
A woman's long dress or robe; also light covering; a scarf.
a small South American spiny tree (Erythrina crista-galli) with dark crimson and scarlet flowers solitary or clustered.
A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introduced at a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and a reddish brown color.
The common newt; -- called also asker, eft, evat, and ewt.
Matter or pieces of wood, ivory, etc., inlaid, or prepared for inlaying; that which is inserted or inlaid for ornament or variety; as, ornamented with ivory inlay.
A branch; a projecting part or prominent process; a ramification.
Rising.
A bird; the flicker.
A coal broker.
A choice or select body; the flower; as, the <eacute/lite of society.
Any similar wind, as the chinook, in other parts of the world.
A vitreous compound, used by potters in glazing, consisting of lime, silica, borax, lead, and soda.
In the East Indies, a princess or lady of high rank.
A nun of the order of St. Clare.
See Divot.
One of a race or tribe that has no fixed location, but wanders from place to place in search of pasture or game.
A series.
To twist together; to form by twisting or winding of threads; to wreathe; as, fine twined linen.
A grape of an oval shape and whitish color.
The city and tower in the land of Shinar, where the confusion of languages took place.
See 1st Frieze.
See Tucum.
A beef; a beef creature.
Nightshade; -- so called from its blackish purple berries.
A native or inhabitant of Scio.
Violent derangement of mind; madness; insanity.  Cf. Delirium.
One who, or that which, pares; an instrument for paring.
Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa.  Many varieties are cultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers.
A small roll of tobacco, used for smoking.
A duel; also, the rules of dueling.
A cuplike spoon, often of large size, with a long handle, used in lading or dipping.
A copper coin, used in the Ionian Islands, about one cent in value.
That which is roasted; a piece of meat which has been roasted, or is suitable for being roasted.
The snow goose.
Same as Buddha.
A gambling game with dice.  It is one of the more popular games in casinos.

Any one of numerous species of large, flat elasmobranch fishes of the genus Raia, having a long, slender tail, terminated by a small caudal fin. The pectoral fins, which are large and broad and united to the sides of the body and head, give a somewhat rhombic form to these fishes. The skin is more or less spinose.
Want of wit or understanding; ignorance.
A filament of a stamen.
A conical chamber at the breech of the bore in heavy ordnance, especially in mortars; -- named after the inventor.
A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of many kinds.
A sphere.
See 1st Stupe.
The fruit of the oak, being an oval nut growing in a woody cup or cupule.

A thong of leather, or a long cord, by which a person may hold or restrain an animal, such as a falconer holding his hawk, or a courser his dog.  For dogs and cats, the leash is commonly attached to a collar around the neck of the animal.
A narrow piece of timber which holds together large pieces; a slat; as, the sloats of a cart.

A solution of continuity in any of the soft parts of the body, discharging purulent matter, found on a surface, especially one of the natural surfaces of the body, and originating generally in a constitutional disorder; a sore discharging pus. It is distinguished from an abscess, which has its beginning, at least, in the depth of the tissues.
A semipellucid, uncrystallized variety of quartz, presenting various tints in the same specimen. Its colors are delicately arranged in stripes or bands, or blended in clouds.
One who, or that which, makes an end of something; as, the ender of my life.

A genus of large percoid fishes, of which one species (Lates Niloticus) inhabits the Nile, and another (Lates calcarifer) is found in the Ganges and other Indian rivers. They are valued as food fishes.

A shrub of the genus Syringa. There are six species, natives of Europe and Asia.  Syringa vulgaris, the common lilac, and Syringa Persica, the Persian lilac, are frequently cultivated for the fragrance and beauty of their purplish or white flowers. In the British colonies various other shrubs have this name.
A paddock, or toad.
A shell or pod.

A dignitary under the Anglo-Saxons and Danes in England.  Of these there were two orders, the king's thanes, who attended the kings in their courts and held lands immediately of them, and the ordinary thanes, who were lords of manors and who had particular jurisdiction within their limits.  After the Conquest, this title was disused, and baron took its place.
A clinkerbuit, narrow boat for sculling.
A small South American deer (Furcifer Chilensis), with simple forked horns.
Strong desire; passion; especially, lust.
The path described by a heavenly body in its periodical revolution around another body; as, the orbit of Jupiter, of the earth, of the moon.

A frame of two strong timbers fixed perpendicularly in the fore part of a ship, on which to fasten the cables as the ship rides at anchor, or in warping. Other bitts are used for belaying (belaying bitts), for sustaining the windlass (carrick bitts, winch bitts, or windlass bitts), to hold the pawls of the windlass (pawl bitts) etc.
One who pries; one who inquires narrowly and searches, or is inquisitive.
The fennec.

a game commonly used for low-stakes gambling, in which numbered balls or slips are drawn at random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards, called Bingo cards, which have square arrangement of such numbers.  Each card has a different arrangement of the numbers, and the first player to cover all numbers in one row (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal) is the winner, usually announcing that fact by a cry of <ldquo/Bingo!<rdquo/
See Fogy.
A light color of the iris in horses; wall-eye.
A striving; an effort; a conatus.
One of the nymphs of mountains and grottoes.
Skin of bacon.
A vexillum.
A bracelet.
The heat, or utmost violence, of an onset; the strength or greatest fury of any contention; as, the brunt of a battle.
A drunken condition; a spree.
Moldiness.
An ultimate atom, or simple, unextended point; something ultimate and indivisible.
The hard, amber-colored resin left after distilling off the volatile oil of turpentine; colophony.
The short, thick first digit of the human hand, differing from the other fingers in having but two phalanges; the pollex. See Pollex.

A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; the proclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by the very act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Roman emperors; the edicts of the French monarch.
A diaper{4}.
A gown or case of skin, or one trimmed or lined with fur.
The signs, abbreviations, letters, or characters standing for words, shorthand, etc., in ancient manuscripts, or on coins, medals, etc.
A turf.
A structure on the hurricane deck of a steamer, containing the pilot house, officers' cabins, etc.
Same as Bolty.

A figure in which a word is separated or repeated by way of emphasis, so as not only to signify the individual thing denoted by it, but also its peculiar attribute or quality; as, <ldquo/His wife's a wife indeed.<rdquo/

A vessel having one mast and fore-and-aft rig, consisting of a boom-and-gaff mainsail, jibs, staysail, and gaff topsail. The typical sloop has a fixed bowsprit, topmast, and standing rigging, while those of a cutter are capable of being readily shifted.  The sloop usually carries a centerboard, and depends for stability upon breadth of beam rather than depth of keel.  The two types have rapidly approximated since 1880.  One radical distinction is that a sloop may carry a centerboard. See Cutter, and Illustration in Appendix.
The Canada porcupine. See Porcupine.
A thick stew made with chicken (chicken gumbo), or seafood (seafood gumbo), thickened with okra or file, and also containing greens and often hot spices; it is particularly popular in Louisiana.
A minnow.
A landing place or wharf.
Color; tinge; tincture; tint.
A cuirass or breastplate.
A machine of great antiquity, used in Bengal for raising water to irrigate land.
A gentle push, or jog, as with the elbow.
The becoming stiff or rigid; the state of being rigid; rigidity; stiffness; hardness.

A slender marine fish (Scomberesox saurus) of Europe and America. It has long, thin, beaklike jaws. Called also billfish, gowdnook, gawnook, skipper, skipjack, skopster, lizard fish, and Egypt herring.

a specific type of complex ecological community characterized by specific environmental conditions and a distinctive group of plants and animals, maintained in a relatively stable equilibrium, such as a rain forest biome or prairie biome.
the 3rd letter of the Hebrew alphabet.
A nest: a repository for the eggs of birds, insects, etc.; a breeding place; esp., the place or substance where parasites or the germs of a disease effect lodgment or are developed.
An exchange for the transaction of business.
A kind of carp (Cyprinus gibelio); -- called also Prussian carp.
A marine in the English navy.
One who, or that which, races, or contends in a race; esp., a race horse.
A spinning wheel.
A radical, C16H33, not yet isolated, but supposed to exist in a series of compounds homologous with the ethyl compounds, and derived from spermaceti.
the hospital ward or clinic in which patients are detoxified; -- often used attributively.
An island. See Eyot.
The main body; the chief part, bulk, or mass.
Shortened form of statistics{2} (b).
A thin, broad piece cut off; as, a slice of bacon; a slice of cheese; a slice of bread.
Same as Saki.

The cutting tool of an engraver on metal, used in line engraving. It is made of tempered steel, one end being ground off obliquely so as to produce a sharp point, and the other end inserted in a handle; a graver; also, the similarly shaped tool used by workers in marble.
A live coal. See Gleed.
See Uhlan.
A little pie.
A puff, as of smoke from a pipe, or of dust from a puffball; a slight explosion, as of a small quantity of gunpowder.
A weight; a poise.
A writhing, as in anguish; a twisting; a griping.
a sauce prepared from butter creamed with white wine, shallots, parsley and fish stock; -- also called Bercy sauce.
Same as Conine.
The magpie.
One who paves; one who lays a pavement.
The act of stooping, or bending the body forward; inclination forward; also, an habitual bend of the back and shoulders.
See Salep.

Any of a large class of compounds characterized by a five-membered ring which contains an atom of nitrogen and at least one other noncarbon atom (nitrogen, oxygen, sulphur). The prefixes furo-, thio, and pyrro- are used to distinguish three subclasses of azoles, which may be regarded as derived respectively from furfuran, thiophene, and pyrrol by replacement of the CH group by nitrogen; as, furo-monazole. Names exactly analogous to those for the azines are also used; as, oxazole, diazole, etc.
A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat.
A large drinking vessel; also, its contents.
