A boy; especially, a boy servant.
A color of a delicate purple, violet, or lilac.
A beacon tower; a lighthouse.
The poke (Phytolacca decandra); -- called also pocan bush.
The distal segment of the fore limb, including the carpus and fore foot or hand.

A yellowish translucent resin resembling copal, found as a fossil in alluvial soils, with beds of lignite, or on the seashore in many places. It takes a fine polish, and is used for pipe mouthpieces, beads, etc., and as a basis for a fine varnish. By friction, it becomes strongly electric.
A smaller group of trees than a forest, and without underwood, planted, or growing naturally as if arranged by art; a wood of small extent.
an energetic American dance that was popular in the 1930s (probably named for the aviator Charles Lindbergh).
Freedom from restraint.
To have a particular smell or taste; -- with of.
The quality of being wide; extent from side to side; breadth; wideness; as, the width of cloth; the width of a door.
A coin of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden, of the value of about twenty-eight cents (in 1913). See Crown, n., 9.
The grand adversary of man; the Devil, or Prince of darkness; the chief of the fallen angels; the archfiend.
A kind of wooden shoe worn by the peasantry in France, Belgium, Sweden, and some other European countries.
A little teat; a nipple.
a Russian country house, especially a cottage used in the summer.
An object that is a conscious or living object, and hence not a direct object, but an inferred object or act of a subject, not myself; -- a term invented by W. K. Clifford.
a country at the northeastern corner of Africa.  At one time it was joined with Syria to form the United Arab Republic.
A boy or young man; a waiter; a servant; especially, a man or boy who has charge of horses, or the stable.
One who pules; one who whines or complains; a weak person.
Ill-will or hatred toward another, accompanied with the disposition to irritate, annoy, or thwart; petty malice; grudge; rancor; despite.
A sharp tool or weapon.
A person who is tough{7}; a ruffian; a thug; as, a cluster of neighborhood toughs hanging out on the corner.
A hood, or cape with a hood, made of lined with gray fur, formerly worn by the clergy; -- written also amess, amyss, and almuce.
The head of an Arab family, or of a clan or a tribe; also, the chief magistrate of an Arab village. The name is also applied to Mohammedan ecclesiastics of a high grade.
The sound made by the sudden fall or blow of a heavy body, as of a hammer, or the like.
A braid, knot, or curl, of hair; a ringlet.
See Camis.

The faculty by which the mind forms an image or a representation of anything perceived before; the power of combining and modifying such objects into new pictures or images; the power of readily and happily creating and recalling such objects for the purpose of amusement, wit, or embellishment; imagination.
Same as Emir.
An implacable or malicious foe; one who is diabolically wicked or cruel; an infernal being; -- applied specifically to the devil or a demon.
A fair or market.

To protect from danger; to secure against surprise, attack, or injury; to keep in safety; to defend; to shelter; to shield from surprise or attack; to protect by attendance; to accompany for protection; to care for.
A place where the water of a sea, lake, river, pond, etc., is shallow; a shallow.
The quotient of a unit divided by three; one of three equal parts into which anything is divided.
The Poland marmot (Arctomys bobac).
An old ewe.
A pair of shears; -- now always used in the plural, but formerly also in the singular. See Shears.
Straw.
A secret.
A layer of earth between coal seams.
The white poplar (Populus alba).
See Hose.
A blacksmith's fuller or chisel, having a square shank for insertion into a square hole in an anvil, called the hardy hole.
A work in the Persian tongue, being a summary of the Zend-Avesta, or sacred books.
A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part of spermaceti.
A long, narrow, pliable strip of leather, cloth, or the like; specifically, a strip of thick leather used in flogging.
The rate or degree of movement in time.
A breeze fly.
A sword.
The deadly nightshade (Atropa Belladonna), having stupefying qualities.
A callous tumor on the leg of a horse, below the hock.
The top of the head; the head or noll.
The teasel.
See Tucket, a steak.
Same as Xylene.
The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion of coagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
One who hopes.
A hood. See Houve.
See Eagre.
The carcass of a whale after the blubber has been removed.
Fine clay or ocher made up into balls, used for marking sheep.
A vinedresser.
The offspring of animals, either a single animal or offspring collectively.
An ask; a water newt.
A genus of herbs (Blitum) with a fleshy calyx. Blitum capitatum is the strawberry blite.
One who dozes or drowses.
A massive, somewhat impure variety of quartz, in color usually of a gray to brown or nearly black, breaking with a conchoidal fracture and sharp edge. It is very hard, and strikes fire with steel.
Same as Acrita.
A state of holding on in a continuous course; manner of continuity; constant mode; general tendency; course; career.
The head or leader of any body of men; a commander, as of an army; a head man, as of a tribe, clan, or family; a person in authority who directs the work of others; the principal actor or agent.
A rent, service, tribute, custom, tax, impost, or duty; an excise.
See Weld.
Same as Dorsal, n.
a native or inhabitant of Iran.
The fainter part of a sun spot; -- now more commonly called penumbra.
Liquid in which flesh (and sometimes other substances, as barley or rice) has been boiled; thin or simple soup.
A carouse; a drinking bout; a booze.
A sty on the eye. See Styan.
A narration or recital of that which has occurred; a description of past events; a history; a statement; a record.
Gentle heat; moderate warmth; tepidness.
A similar garment worn formerly by gentlemen.
A tuft, or other excrescence or natural ornament, growing on an animal's head; the comb of a cock; the swelling on the head of a serpent; the lengthened feathers of the crown or nape of bird, etc.
The lead glaze used for pottery.
An expression of mirth peculiar to the human species; the sound heard in laughing; laughter. See Laugh, v. i.
A small copper coin formerly current in Scotland, worth less than a cent.
A sharp appendage to any of a plant; a thorn.
The gate of a mold, through which the melted metal is poured; runner, geat.
Blameworthiness.
A lyric poem; a lyrical composition.

The old theory that the egg contains the whole embryo of the future organism and the germs of all subsequent offsprings and is merely awakened to activity by the spermatozoon; -- opposed to spermism or animalculism.
The parting of the hair on the head.
Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food; delicacies; dainties.
A feeling of hurt, vexation, or resentment, awakened by a social slight or injury; irritation of the feelings, as through wounded pride; stinging vexation.
A serous or mucous discharge, especially one from the eves or nose.
The waste piece of metal cast in this hole; hence, dross.
A love of the fine arts; a taste for curiosities.
A voyage; a journey.
Orig., blithesomeness; gladness; now, the highest degree of happiness; blessedness; exalted felicity; heavenly joy.
A sudden, noisy, and violent expulsion of air from the chest, caused by irritation in the air passages, or by the reflex action of nervous or gastric disorder, etc.
A sojourner; an immigrant; an alien resident in a Grecian city, but not a citizen.
That which is new or unusual; a novelty.
An oilskin hat or southwester; -- a fisherman's name.
A lengthened, slow monotonous utterance.
A fleet; especially, a <?/eet of Spanish ships which formerly sailed every year from Cadiz to Vera Cruz, in Mexico, to transport to Spain the production of Spanish America.
Any carnivore of the genus Mellivora, allied to the weasels and the skunks; -- called also honey badger.
See Shittim.
A mixture of oleomargarine with lard or other fatty ingredients. It is used as a substitute for butter. See Butterine.
Any one of numerous species of sand wasps of the genus Sphex and allied genera. These wasps have the abdomen attached to the thorax by a slender pedicel. See Illust. of Sand wasp, under Sand.
An anvil; a stithy.
Strife; contention; controversy.
A favorite; a paramour; an ingle.
Same as Trier, 2 and 3.
A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance; a pennon.
One who takes or receives; one who catches or apprehends.
a sudden unexpected piece of good fortune.
See Boatswain.
A compressed mass of paper sheets, forming a matrix or mold for stereotype plates.
a large quantity.  See heap, senses 2 and 3; as, he made heaps of money in the stock market.
A gun so placed as to rake an enemy's ship.
To take out or up with, a scoop; to lade out.
See Trode.
An alarm from a real or threatened attack; a sudden attack; also, a bugle sound to give warning.
Something or someone that fries.
The twisting of a rope or cable, as it is running out.
Something or someone that is phony.
A small plug or wooden pin, used to stop a vent, as in a cask.
Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa; as, the oak eggar (L. roboris) of Europe.
A case or bag. See Housewife, 2.
The third month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year; -- supposed to correspond nearly with our month of June.
The stem, or main body, of a tree or plant; the fixed, strong, firm part; the trunk.
A nobleman on the continent of Europe, equal in rank to an English earl.
A short spoon.
An ancient instrument of music with six strings; a kind of violin, being the oldest known stringed instrument played with a bow.
A celebrated Athenian lawmaker, born about 638 b. c.; hence, a legislator; a publicist; -- often used ironically.
Poison; venom; corrupt matter from a sore.
The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbow to wrist.

A genus of chilognathous myriapods. The body is long and round, consisting of numerous smooth, equal segments, each of which bears two pairs of short legs. It includes the galleyworms. See Chilognatha.
A contrivance, often consisting of a noose of cord, or the like, by which a bird or other animal may be entangled and caught; a trap; a gin.
Tapestry; formerly, the cover of a council table.

A brown or reddish pigment used in both oil and water colors, obtained from certain natural clays variously colored by the oxides of iron and manganese. It is commonly heated or burned before being used, and is then called burnt umber; when not heated, it is called raw umber. See Burnt umber, below.
The framework or skeleton upon which a regiment is to be formed; the officers of a regiment forming the staff.

A fluctuation of mind arising from defect of knowledge or evidence; uncertainty of judgment or mind; unsettled state of opinion concerning the reality of an event, or the truth of an assertion, etc.; hesitation.
Tape or braid; an ornament.
The little wheel of a spur, with sharp points.
The erd shrew.

Any one of several species of American musteline carnivores of the genus Mephitis and allied genera. They have two glands near the anus, secreting an extremely fetid liquid, which the animal ejects at pleasure as a means of defense.
A little pipe, or hollow cylinder of paper, filled with powder or combustible matter, to be thrown into the air while burning, so as to burst there with a crack.
A dance performed by two persons in circular figures with a whirling motion; also, a piece of music composed in triple measure for this kind of dance.
A genus of insects belonging to the order Hemiptera and family Aphid<ae/, including numerous species known as plant lice and green flies.
A funeral feast.
Refuse timber, from which the best part has been culled out.
The drain on the land side of a sea embankment.
The leaping, tripping, or measured stepping of one who dances; an amusement, in which the movements of the persons are regulated by art, in figures and in accord with music.
The chief city of France.
A moment.
Notice of a proposed marriage, proclaimed in a church, or other place prescribed by law, in order that any person may object, if he knows of just cause why the marriage should not take place.
a coarse, tough, twilled cotton fabric used for uniforms or sports clothes.
A French copper coin of one fourth the value of a sou.

A tree of the genus Acer, including about fifty species. Acer saccharinum is the rock maple, or sugar maple, from the sap of which sugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, by evaporation; the red maple or swamp maple is Acer rubrum; the silver maple, Acer dasycarpum, having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple, Acer Pennsylvanium, called also moosewood.  The common maple of Europe is Acer campestre, the sycamore maple is Acer Pseudo-platanus, and the Norway maple is Acer platanoides.
To search for; to examine.
A horse, especially a spirited horse for state or war; -- used chiefly in poetry or stately prose.
The act of reducing to powder, or of sharpening, by friction.

A thicket of bushes, usually thorn bushes; especially, such a thicket planted as a fence between any two portions of land; and also any sort of shrubbery, as evergreens, planted in a line or as a fence; particularly, such a thicket planted round a field to fence it, or in rows to separate the parts of a garden.
A line of persons waiting anywhere.
Cold; chilliness.
Leprosy.
A medusa, or jellyfish.
A bushman's blanket; -- named from its color.
Debt.
Same as Donat. Piers Plowman.
A council; a convention; a tribunal; an assembly; esp., the grand council of state in Spain.
Something scraped off; hence, a small piece; a bit; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.
A scarecrow, generally made of feathers tied to a string, hung up to prevent deer from breaking into a place.
The act of stamping, as with the foot.
A rapid in some rivers; as, the Sault Ste. Marie.
Loss; disadvantage; defeat.

A tailless furry marsupial (Phascolarctos cinereus), found in Australia. The female carries her young on the back of her neck. Called also Australian bear, koala bear, native bear, and native sloth.  The koala lives almost all of its life in trees, moves sluggishly like a sloth, and eats eucalyptus leaves almost exclusively.
A carnivorous animal of the Weasel family (Mustela zibellina) native of the northern latitudes of Europe, Asia, and America, -- noted for its fine, soft, and valuable fur.
A drudge.
The dorsal one of the three principal bones comprising either lateral half of the pelvis; the dorsal or upper part of the hip bone. See Innominate bone, under Innominate.
A norm; a principle or rule; a model; a standard.
Upbraiding language; bitter or sarcastic reproach; insulting invective.
The child of a mulatto and a negro; also, the child of an Indian and a negro; colloquially or humorously, a negro; a sambo.
the other world; land of fairies.
The devil; a demon.

A surface, real or imaginary, in which, if any two points are taken, the straight line which joins them lies wholly in that surface; or a surface, any section of which by a like surface is a straight line; a surface without curvature.
A small whale.
The writ by which such persons are summoned.
Scotland; esp. the Highlands of Scotland.
An organic radical, C3H5, existing especially in oils of garlic and mustard.
To turn aside, or away; as, to avert the eyes from an object; to ward off, or prevent, the occurrence or effects of; as, how can the danger be averted?  <ldquo/To avert his ire.<rdquo/
A short bar used by thieves to wrench doors open.
A pledge.
A harsh scraping or cutting; a grating.

That part of the natural day when the sun is beneath the horizon, or the time from sunset to sunrise; esp., the time between dusk and dawn, when there is no light of the sun, but only moonlight, starlight, or artificial light.
One who, or that which, aids.
A law or rule.
The resolution or favorable termination of a disease, coming on gradually and not marked by abrupt change.
See Querl.
To betoken.
An Australian boomerang, having one side flat and the other convex.
One's acts considered as fixing one's lot in the future existence.
One who names, or calls by name.
The iron lap used by diamond polishers in finishing the facets of the gem.
A soft twilled silk fabric much used for women's dresses; -- called also surah silk.
A genus of evergreen trees, thickly branched, remarkable for the distichous arrangement of their branches, and having scalelike, closely imbricated, or compressed leaves.
A raised structure (as a square or oblong erection of stone or wood) on which sacrifices are offered or incense burned to a deity.

A nonplane curve whose tangents are all equally inclined to a given plane. The common helix is the curve formed by the thread of the ordinary screw. It is distinguished from the spiral, all the convolutions of which are in the plane.
A Brazilian name for the lofty myrtaceous tree (Bertholetia excelsa) which produces the large seeds known as Brazil nuts.
Same as Meine.
A marsupial of Australia (Dasyurus macrurus), about the size of a cat.
A genus of minute flagellate Infusoria of which there are many species, both free and attached. See Illust. under Monad.
naked freshwater or marine or parasitic protozoa that form temporary pseudopods for feeding and locomotion.  Same as amoeba.
One that bores; an instrument for boring.
A weight used in certain parts of the East Indies, varying considerably in different localities, the range being from 223 to 625 pounds.
A beginning or first attempt; hence, a first appearance before the public, as of an actor or public speaker.
A crowd, a rabble.
The gazelle.
See Litchi.
Same as Moodir.
Same as Salmis.
A pipe, funnel, or chimney, as for smoke.
A right; law in its aspect of the foundation of rights; also, in old law, the writ of right.
A South American bird (Psophia crepitans), allied to the cranes, and easily domesticated; -- called also the gold-breasted trumpeter. Its body is about the size of the pheasant. See Trumpeter.
An abacus.
To arrange in classes; to classify or refer to some class; as, to class words or passages.
A hoop or band.
Soft, moist earth or clay, having an adhesive quality; viscous mud.
A notch or incision; especially, one that is made as a tally mark; hence, a mark, or line, made for the purpose of account.
The berries of a species of cypress in the East Indies.
Flattery; cajolery; deceit.
A river of Hades whose waters when drunk caused forgetfulness of the past.
A curassow (Ourax pauxi), which, in South America, is often domesticated.
The upper leather for a shoe; a vamp.
Goodwife; -- a low term of civility or sport.
Something to hinder sight or keep out light; a screen; a cover; esp. a hinged screen or shutter for a window; a blinder for a horse.
A carouse; a drinking.
a lesbian who is noticeably masculine.

A variety of auction pitch in which a draw to improve the hand is added, and the five of trumps (called right pedro) and the five of the same color (called left pedro, and ranking between the five and the four of trumps) each count five on the score. Fifty-one points make a game. Called also double pedro and high five.
a cup of tea.
A kind of triangular spade.
A sort of flat custard or pie.
One who loves; one who is in love; -- usually limited, in the singular, to a person of the male sex.
A kind of silk lace or light netting, used for veils, etc.
A small European river fish (Leuciscus alburnus), of the family Cyprinid<ae/; the blay.
An Egyptian race thought to be descendants of the ancient Egyptians.
A slip or piece.
Pious; reverencing God, and his character and laws; obedient to the commands of God from love for, and reverence of, his character; conformed to God's law; devout; righteous; as, a godly life.
A sylvan deity or demigod, represented as part man and part goat, and characterized by riotous merriment and lasciviousness.

A fine, strong fiber obtained from the young leaves of a Brazilian palm (Astrocaryum vulgare), used for cordage, bowstrings, etc.; also, the plant yielding this fiber. Called also tecum, and tecum fiber.
Contagious or poisonous matter, as of specific ulcers, the bite of snakes, etc.; -- applied to organic poisons.
A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar.
Short for A<eum/rodrome.
A kind of inferior cigar of a long slender shape, tapered at one end.
a demigod or first man: "seed of mankind"; sometimes identified with Adam.
A servant at a hotel or elsewhere, who cleans and blacks the boots and shoes.
To draw or keep near; to approach.
A fief. See Fief.

A fat, liquid at ordinary temperatures, but solidifying at temperatures below 0<deg/ C., found abundantly in both the animal and vegetable kingdoms (see Palmitin).  It dissolves solid fats, especially at 30-40<deg/ C.  Chemically, olein is a glyceride of oleic acid; and, as three molecules of the acid are united to one molecule of glycerol to form the fat, it is technically known as triolein.  It is also called elain.
The right-hand page; -- opposed to verso.

Any one of numerous species of small silvery salmonoid fishes of the genus Osmerus and allied genera, which ascend rivers to spawn, and sometimes become landlocked in lakes. They are esteemed as food, and have a peculiar odor and taste.
See Bromine.

The unit for estimating the weight of a<eum/riform substances; -- the weight of a liter of hydrogen at 0<deg/ centigrade, and with a tension of 76 centimeters of mercury. It is 0.0896 of a gram, or 1.38274 grains.
Tribute; toll; custom. [Obs.] See Gabel.
Disturbance; annoyance; care.
a taxonomic group, or the name of a taxonomic grouping.
A small stream of water.
A tract of ground laid out for the game of golf; a golfing green.
See 1st Pink.
To show insolent ridicule or mockery; to manifest contempt by derisive acts or language; -- often with at.

Any one of numerous species of fishes belonging to Salmo, Salvelinus, and allied genera of the family Salmonidae.  They are highly esteemed as game fishes and for the quality of their flesh.  All the species breed in fresh water, but after spawning many of them descend to the sea if they have an opportunity.
A muscle; flesh.
Any object which is a very large example of its class.
A stone.
Act or sound of plunking.
A wrinkle; a rimple.
See Sweep, n., 12.
a game in which numbered balls are drawn and random and players cover the correponding numbers on their cards.
A paint; a dye; also, false show.
A point in which the rays of light meet, after being reflected or refracted, and at which the image is formed; as, the focus of a lens or mirror.
A wig; -- so called, perhaps, from being made of, or resembling, Jersey yarn.
One deputed or authorized to perform the functions of another; a substitute in office; a deputy.
A small shaft sunk from one level to another, as for the purpose of ventilation.
A stout, coarse boot or shoe; a brogan.
A chicken.
An empty, immeasurable space; a yawning chasm.

A game played on a board having 256 squares, by two persons with 19 men each, or by four with 13 men each, starting from different corners and striving to place each his own set of men in a corresponding position in the opposite corner by moving them or by jumping them over those met in progress.

A large species of American grass of the genus Zea (Zea Mays), widely cultivated as a forage and food plant; Indian corn, commonly called corn.  Also, its seed, growing on cobs, and used as food for men and animals.
A beverage made of wine, water, sugar, nutmeg, and lemon juice; -- so called, it is said, from its first maker, Colonel Negus.
A fixed pin or short axis, on the end of which a wheel or other body turns.
Sward.
A conic section.
A stoppage or irritation of the windpipe, producing the feeling of strangulation.
Same as Piraya.

A form of croquet modified for greater accuracy of play. The court has a wood border often faced with rubber, used as a cushion in bank shots. The balls are 3<frac14/ in. in diameter, the cage (center arches or wickets) 3<frac38/ in. wide, the other arches 3<frac12/ in. wide.
The Abyssinian or Arabian ibex (Capra Nubiana). It is probably the wild goat of the Bible.
The leaves of an orchid (Angraecum fragrans), of the islands of Bourbon and Mauritius, used (in France) as a substitute for Chinese tea.
A person who leads or directs another in his way or course, as in a strange land; one who exhibits points of interest to strangers; a conductor; also, that which guides; a guidebook.
A piece of ordnance, consisting of a number of musket barrels arranged so that a match or train may connect with all their touchholes, and a discharge be secured almost or quite simultaneously.
A drab; a strumpet; a harlot; a trollop.
Ant<ae/. See Anta.
Same as Britzska.
The Doric dialect.
One of an Oriental religious sect which worships Satan or the Devil.
A luncheon; specifically, a light repast between breakfast and dinner, most commonly about noontime.
Harm; damage; injury; hurt; waste; misfortune.
A gold coin of Rome, worth 64 shillings 11 pence sterling, or about $ 15.70.
A game at cards; whist.
To place or dispose in order, as troops for battle; to marshal.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.
Writing; document; scroll.
A British trout usually regarded as a variety (var. Cambricus) of the salmon trout.
A scarf joint.
The slender, smooth stem of an arrow; hence, an arrow.
A kind of cap worn in the 16th century, and copied in modern fashions; -- called also toquet.
mother and earth goddess in Gilgamish epic; identified with Sumerian Ki and Ninkhursag (Mama; Nintu).
A dead body embalmed and dried after the manner of the ancient Egyptians; also, a body preserved, by any means, in a dry state, from the process of putrefaction.
See Cigar.
One who is conversant with, or who favors adoption of, Volap<uum/k.
A large South American serpent (Boa aboma).
The territory or dominions of a duke; a dukedom.
The people, as distinguished from the clergy; the body of the people not in orders.
The food supplied to the Israelites in their journey through the wilderness of Arabia; hence, divinely supplied food.
An Asiatic.
A wading bird of the genus Grus, and allied genera, of various species, having a long, straight bill, and long legs and neck.
A kind of wild goose, by a flock of which a virtuoso was fabled to be carried to the lunar world.
Proof.
One who rules; one who exercises sway or authority; a governor.
The front compartment of a French diligence; also, the front compartment (usually for three persons) of a car or carriage on British railways.
A wave, or two or three successive waves, of great height and violence, at flood tide moving up an estuary or river; -- commonly called the bore or tidal bore. See Bore.
See Pillau.
The posture of one that sits on his heels or hams, or close to the ground.
See Zenick.
A dear; a darling.
The block through which a messenger passes.

One of the group of shooting stars which come into the air in certain years on or about the 19th of April; -- so called because the apparent path among the stars if traced backwards crosses the constellation Lyra.
The last letter of the Greek alphabet. See Alpha.
Stock; race; family.
Place; situation.
An organic body or cell having locomotion, as a spermatic cell or spermatozooid.
A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
A giant.
An awkward, clumsy fellow; a lubber.
The beating or throbbing of the heart or blood vessels, especially of the arteries.
Unreasonableness; absurdity.

A tree of several species, constituting the genus Betula; as, the white or common birch (Betula alba) (also called silver birch and lady birch); the dwarf birch (Betula glandulosa); the paper or canoe birch (Betula papyracea); the yellow birch (Betula lutea); the black or cherry birch (Betula lenta).
The cobra de capello.
A secret council to deliberate on affairs of government or politics; a number of men combined for party intrigue; a faction; a cabal; as, a junto of ministers; a junto of politicians.
A summary account.
Weapon.
A measure of distance, varying from four to ten miles, but usually about five.
A poll tax paid by peasants absent from their lord's estate.
A series of close parallel runnings which are drawn up so as to make the material between them set full by gatherings; -- called also shirring, and gauging.
A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.
See 1st Fluke.
A sudden flowing; a rush which fills or overflows, as of water for cleansing purposes.
A heddle.
The marriage knot.

A feline quadruped (Felis irbis syn. Felis uncia) resembling the leopard in size, and somewhat in color, but it has longer and thicker fur, which forms a short mane on the back.  The ounce is pale yellowish gray, with irregular dark spots on the neck and limbs, and dark rings on the body.  It inhabits the lofty mountain ranges of Asia. Called also once.
The act of driving; a trip or an excursion in a carriage, as for exercise or pleasure; -- distinguished from a ride taken on horseback.
A wood. See Hurst.
A word of doubtful meaning, occuring frequently in the Psalms; by some, supposed to signify silence or a pause in the musical performance of the song.
See Taenia.
To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison.

the candlewood of Mexico and couthwestern California (Idria columnaris or Fouquieria columnaris), having tall columnar stems and bearing honey-scented creamy yellow flowers; -- called also the boojum tree.
One of a people and religious sect dwelling chiefly in the Lebanon mountains of Syria.
A suborder of struthious birds including the rheas.

A mineral occurring in rhombic prisms, generally yellowish and pellucid, also colorless, and of greenesh, bluish, or brownish shades. It sometimes occurs massive and opaque. It is a fluosilicate of alumina, and is used as a gem.
A country bumpkin.
The California white oak (Quercus lobata).
To perforate or stamp with an instrument by pressure, or a blow; as, to punch a hole; to punch ticket.
An argillaceous rock which readily splits into thin plates; argillite; argillaceous schist.
An antelope (Saiga Tartarica) native of the plains of Siberia and Eastern Russia. The male has erect annulated horns, and tufts of long hair beneath the eyes and ears.
A small yellow singing bird, with an ash-colored head; the European siskin. Called also tarin.
The sound produced by anything that creaks; a creaking.
Tradition; occult doctrine. See Cabala.
a workman who dresses things up.
A member of one of the German tribes that in the fifth century overran and conquered Gaul, and established the kingdom of France.
A small genus of hairy herbs with yellow flowers.
See Pontee.
The long, projecting nose of a beast, as of swine.
Any plant of the Arum family (Arace<ae/); -- have small flowers massed on a spadix surrounded by a large spathe.
A vibrant or whirring noise such as that made by some insects, as the cockchafer, or by some birds, as the nightjar, the partridge, etc.
The act of draining, or of drawing off; gradual and continuous outflow or withdrawal; as, the drain of specie from a country; the project is a drain on resources.
Nap or down; flue[2]; soft, downy feathers.
A husband's brother; -- used in reference to levirate marriages.
A breed of dog.
A composition in the fine arts which is intended, or may serve, for a study.
A kind of small turnip, a variety of Brassica campestris. See Brassica.
See Piece.
A block or clay tempered with water, sand, etc., molded into a regular form, usually rectangular, and sun-dried, or burnt in a kiln, or in a heap or stack called a clamp.
Pieces of timber bolted to certain parts of a mast to support the trestletrees.

A genus of edentates, covered with large, hard, triangular scales, with sharp edges that overlap each other like tiles on a roof.  They inhabit the warmest parts of Asia and Africa, and feed on ants. Called also Scaly anteater. See Pangolin.
The rhinocerous bird (a).
See Tarn.

originally, a cutaneous disease with the appearance of the skin having been gnawed, and occurring under two distinct forms.  Now used as a generic term for over ten distinguishable diseases having visible cutaneous symptoms.
Spike lavender. See Lavender.
See Jougs.
A large African forest tree (Nauclea diderrichii) yielding a strong hard yellow to golden brown lumber; sometimes placed in genus Sarcocephalus, and then called Sarcocephalus diderrichii.

A nonmetallic element occurring abundantly in borax. It is reduced with difficulty to the free state, when it can be obtained in several different forms; viz., as a substance of a deep olive color, in a semimetallic form, and in colorless quadratic crystals similar to the diamond in hardness and other properties. It occurs in nature also in boracite, datolite, tourmaline, and some other minerals. Atomic number 5. Atomic weight 10.81. Symbol B.
A Cuban timber tree (Malpighia obovata) with hard wood very resistant to moisture.
A small, light boat.
A vegetarian who does not eat any animal products, not even fish, eggs, or milk.
The lapis lazuli.
A maniple.
See Lamaism.
An accompanied dramatic recitative, interspersed with passages of melody, or followed by a full aria.
A mean flatterer; a toadeater; a sycophant.
A bear; -- so called in popular tales and fables.
Leprosy.
A seaport town of Yemen, on the Red Sea, also spelled Mukha.
The close linen or muslin cap of an old woman.
A corruption of pair royal. See under Pair, n.
A round-up. See Round-up.
A mud volcano, the water of which is often impregnated with salts, whence the name.
A natural stream of water smaller than a river or creek.

A word of warning denoting that the king is in danger; such a menace of a player's king by an adversary's move as would, if it were any other piece, expose it to immediate capture. A king so menaced is said to be in check, and must be made safe at the next move.
A collection of twelve objects; a tale or set of twelve; with or without of before the substantive which follows.
A wretch; a rascal.
The cry of a horse; a whinny.
a genus of elk or moose.
A relative, in general; especially, a descendant, whether male or female; a granddaughter or a grandson.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance (C2H4N4); -- called also dicyandiamide.
The part of anything that hangs loose, having no strain upon it; as, the slack of a rope or of a sail.
One of an important religious sect in India which regards Siva with peculiar veneration.
That which is accumulated, or massed together; a source from which supplies may be drawn; hence, an abundance; a great quantity, or a great number.
See Siren.
A region of Western Asia Minor colonized by the Ancient Greeks.
The act of swelling.
Meat, especially beef, that has been cut in strips and dried; meat that has been jerked; see first jerk, v.; as, beef jerky
A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.
Millet.
The forehead or brow, the part of the face above the eyes; sometimes, also, the whole face.

The back or upper part of the neck; the nape.
The lowest deck of a vessel, esp. of a ship of war, consisting of a platform laid over the beams in the hold, on which the cables are coiled.
A shard or fragment.
Peace; security; agreement.
One of the great divinities of the ancient Romans, identical with the Greek Hestia. She was a virgin, and the goddess of the hearth; hence, also, of the fire on it, and the family round it.
Daniel Boone, a noted American frontiersman, 1734-1820.
A glimpse or glance.

A series of links or rings, usually of metal, connected, or fitted into one another, used for various purposes, as of support, of restraint, of ornament, of the exertion and transmission of mechanical power, etc.
Not firmly woven; that ravels.
A kind of gaiter of waterproof cloth wrapped around the leg, used by soldiers, etc.
A small drain.

A self-evident and necessary truth, or a proposition whose truth is so evident as first sight that no reasoning or demonstration can make it plainer; a proposition which it is necessary to take for granted; as, <ldquo/The whole is greater than a part;<rdquo/  <ldquo/A thing can not, at the same time, be and not be.<rdquo/
aggravation or aggression.
See Dictum.
One who eggs or incites.
A slight depression or pit; a fossa.
A person sanctified; a holy or godly person; one eminent for piety and virtue; any true Christian, as being redeemed and consecrated to God.
A Burman measure of twelve miles.
Bouche (see Bouche, 2); food and drink; provisions.
A kind of red pepper. See Capsicum

Any wading bird of the genus Ardea and allied genera, of the family Ardeidae. The herons have a long, sharp bill, and long legs and toes, with the claw of the middle toe toothed. The common European heron (Ardea cinerea) is remarkable for its directly ascending flight, and was formerly hunted with the larger falcons.
The redfin, or shiner.
A fishing line, often extending a mile or more, having many short lines bearing hooks attached to it. It is used for catching cod, halibut, etc.; a boulter.
An inferior kind of veneration or worship, given to the angels and saints as the servants of God.
A large African antelope (Alcelaphus Lichtensteini), allied to the hartbeest, but having shorter and flatter horns, and lacking a black patch on the face.
a single computer instruction which symbolizes, and is converted at the time of program execution or by a compiler into, a series of instructions in the same computer language.
A woman who has lost her husband by death, and has not married again; one living bereaved of a husband.
A gift begged; a present.
A breach; ruin; downfall; peril.
the young of a herring or sprat or similar fish.
An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamed base and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which dries up, forming a blackish crust.
See Cadre.
A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
See Dermis.
A dark red crystalline substance, isomeric with and resembling indigo blue, and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.
Sherry.  See Sherry.
A native, or one of the people, of Greece; a Grecian; also, the language of Greece.
That division of elasmobranch fishes which includes the sharks.
The small, troublesome tumors or swellings about the anus and lower part of the rectum which are technically called hemorrhoids. See Hemorrhoids. [The singular pile is sometimes used.]
Pagan.
A billet of wood; a piece of timber used as a prop.
The number greater by one than six; seven units or objects.
pl. of Beau.
See Queest.
Raspings of ivory, hartshorn, metals, or other hard substance.
Same as Wegotism.
A term of contempt for a worthless, dissipated fellow.
Miasma.
A point or hit.
A fixed star of the first magnitude in the left foot of the constellation Orion.
One who acts, or takes part in any affair; a doer.
Beginning.
A stream of gas or vapor emitting light and heat in the process of combustion; a bright flame.
The juice or other liquid matter that drips from flesh in cooking, made into a dressing for the food when served up.
Union by league; alliance.

A piece of metal, as gold, silver, copper, etc., coined, or stamped, and issued by the sovereign authority as a medium of exchange in financial transactions between citizens and with government; also, any number of such pieces; coin.
An instrument for examining the depth or other circumstances of a wound, ulcer, or cavity, or the direction of a sinus, of for exploring for bullets, for stones in the bladder, etc.
A shell or husk; a cod or pod.

A form of headdress worn by the ancient Persians. According to Xenophon, the royal tiara was encircled with a diadem, and was high and erect, while those of the people were flexible, or had rims turned over.
a Buddhist who has attained nirvana.
an interest followed with exaggerated zeal; a fad.
A train which receives and deposits passengers or freight along the line of the road; a train for the accommodation of a certain district.
A lever or key acted on by the foot, as in the pianoforte to raise the dampers, or in the organ to open and close certain pipes; a treadle, as in a lathe or a bicycle.

An Eskimo house made of material other than snow, esp. one having walls of turf, driftwood, rock, or skin, and a roof of skins of the walrus or seal.  In Alaska it is often partially underground and covered with timber and turf.  Topeks are also used by Indians of the lower Yukon region.
Low, fertile land; a river valley.
A caper; a spring; a whim.
Nothing.
See Pygmy.
Species; kind.
A rush.
Pebbles, collectively; shingle.
Reconciliation; agreement after variance; harmony; concord.
One who engages in rows, or noisy quarrels; a ruffianly fellow.
The next in order after the ninth; one coming after nine others.
One who cures; a healer; a physician.
A woman; a young or unmarried woman; a girl.
A lump; a clod.
A kind of soft tumor, usually of syphilitic origin.
Same as heroin; -- a slang term.
A kind of boat used in Canton. It is about 25 feet long and is often rowed by women. Called also tankia.

A material of short fiber and inferior quality obtained by deviling woolen rags or the remnants of woolen goods, specif. those of felted, milled, or hard-spun woolen cloth, as distinguished from shoddy, or the deviled product of loose-textured woolen goods or worsted, -- a distinction often disregarded.
See Olio.
A pet name for a cat; also, an endearing name for a girl.
The universal ego from whom all individual atmans arise. This sense is a European excrescence on the East Indian thought.
Improper treatment or use; application to a wrong or bad purpose; misuse; as, an abuse of our natural powers; an abuse of civil rights, or of privileges or advantages; an abuse of language.
A granary; a barn.
A flat-bottomed boat or lighter, -- used in Holland and the Baltic, and sometimes armed in case of war.
A punting pole with a broad flange near the end to prevent it from sinking into the mud; a setting pole.
To swallow; especially, to swallow with greediness, or in large mouthfuls or quantities.
The refuse of cattle taken from a drove.
Spermaceti.
A salt of uric acid; as, sodium urate; ammonium urate.
The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.
A projection in a building; also, a pier or mole; a jetty.

One of the twelve portions into which the year is divided; the twelfth part of a year, corresponding nearly to the length of a synodic revolution of the moon, -- whence the name.  In popular use, a period of four weeks is often called a month.
A quantic of the eighth degree.
The act of sliding; as, a slide on the ice.
An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make tea canisters.
A tall, coarse grass (Imperata arundinacea) of the Philippine Islands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
The duykerbok.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barley meal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians.  Called also kvass.
A fabulous deity; according to some, the son of Apollo and Urania, according to others, of Bacchus and Venus. He was the god of marriage, and presided over nuptial solemnities.
A country on the island of Malta.
Skin; covering.
The part of the leg from the knee to the foot; the shin; the shin bone; also, the whole leg.
One who guards, protects, watches over, or has the care of, some person or thing.

Having a low price in market; of small cost or price, as compared with the usual price or the real value.
The dziggetai.
The barn owl; -- called also pudge, and pudge owl.
Rowan tree.
The bearded seal.
A curve of the third degree.
The tincture red, indicated in seals and engraved figures of escutcheons by parallel vertical lines. Hence, used poetically for a red color or that which is red.

A former English coin, originally of copper, then of bronze, the twelfth part of an English shilling in account value, and equal to four farthings, or about two cents; -- usually indicated by the abbreviation d. (the initial of denarius).
Neighborhood; vicinity; venue.  See Venue.
An atom or radical which has a valence of eight, or is octavalent.

A large genus of evergreen coniferous trees, mostly found in the northern hemisphere. The genus formerly included the firs, spruces, larches, and hemlocks, but is now limited to those trees which have the primary leaves of the branchlets reduced to mere scales, and the secondary ones (pine needles) acicular, and usually in fascicles of two to seven. See Pine.
Home-made wines, cordials, metheglin, etc.
One that fumes.
A small singing bird of many genera and species, belonging to the family Fringillid<ae/.
A raft or float, used principally on the Pacific coast of South America.
The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, as distinguished from the open porticoes.
The hard parts or skeleton of various Anthozoa, and of a few Hydrozoa. Similar structures are also formed by some Bryozoa.
A leafless East Indian vine (Sarcostemma acidum); its sour milky juice was formerly used to make an intoxicating drink.
A celebrated Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on the destruction of Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed to Homer.
That which is said, written, or done in answer to what is said, written, or done by another; an answer; a response.

One of a body of students in the universities of Cambridge (Eng.) and Dublin, who, having passed a certain examination, are exempted from paying college fees and charges. A sizar corresponded to a servitor at Oxford.
Abatement.
A round and compact bed of ore, or a distinct bed, not communicating with a vein.
The quality or being true; as: -- (a) Conformity to fact or reality; exact accordance with that which is, or has been; or shall be.
A Russian drink distilled from rye.
One who faces; one who puts on a false show; a bold-faced person.
To catch so as to hold.
A macaw.
a flat heap of moist, crushed silver ore, prepared for the patio process.
any chemical compound containing the azido group -N3, such as sodium azide (ionic and inorganic) or ethyl azide (organic and nonionic).
The first part; the earliest stage; the beginning or opening, as of the day, the year, etc.; hence, the dawn; the spring.
A helmsman; a pilot.
The structure on which a spectacle or play is exhibited; the part of a theater in which the acting is done, with its adjuncts and decorations; the stage.
a gloomy mental state; same as 2nd dump{1}; -- used mostly in the phrase <ldquo/in the dumps<rdquo/.
An eruptive disease (Varicella globularis), allied to the chicken pox.
The twenty-fourth part of a grain; -- a weight used by goldsmiths.

The relation which one quantity or magnitude has to another of the same kind. It is expressed by the quotient of the division of the first by the second; thus, the ratio of 3 to 6 is expressed by <frac36/ or <frac12/; of a to b by a/b; or (less commonly) the second term is made the dividend; as, a:b = b/a.
A tincture, rarely employed, which is considered as an orange color or bright brown. It is represented by diagonal lines from sinister to dexter, crossed by vertical lines.
A line consisting of a certain number of metrical feet (see Foot, n., 9) disposed according to metrical rules.
A large, strong rope or chain, of considerable length, used to retain a vessel at anchor, and for other purposes. It is made of hemp, of steel wire, or of iron links.
A servant.
A neglected and untrained city boy; a young street Arab.
A drinking vessel. See Quaich.
A native of India employed as a soldier in the service of a European power, esp. of Great Britain; an Oriental soldier disciplined in the European manner.

Any plant of the composite genus Tanacetum. The common tansy (Tanacetum vulgare) has finely divided leaves, a strong aromatic odor, and a very bitter taste. It is used for medicinal and culinary purposes.
Strength; might; secret power.
Same as Delftware.
One of the small feathers of a hawk.
A set or sequence of five, as in piquet.
A female; a woman, especially a married woman; a wife; -- in the language of Indian tribes of the Algonquin family, correlative of sannup.
Short for Chaparajos.
A loch or lake; -- so spelt in Ireland.

A white or gray crystalline salt, with a slight alkaline taste, used as a flux, in soldering metals, making enamels, fixing colors on porcelain, and as a soap. It occurs native in certain mineral springs, and is made from the boric acid of hot springs in Tuscany. It was originally obtained from a lake in Thibet, and was sent to Europe under the name of tincal. Borax is a pyroborate or tetraborate of sodium, Na2B4O7.10H2O.
See Cheer.
Coarse, heavy, narrow linen cloth, used esp. for towels.
To have ideas or images in the mind while in the state of sleep; to experience sleeping visions; -- often with of; as, to dream of a battle, or of an absent friend.

A large flatboat, used in the West Indies for taking freight from shore to ship.
Small or portable articles for dress, furniture, or use; goods; luggage; things.

Same as Joust.
The helm or tiller of a vessel or boat; also, the rudder.
A ditcher.
The stem, or body, of a tree, apart from its limbs and roots; the main stem, without the branches; stock; stalk.
The female of the hawk; a falcon-gentil.
The act of sweeping.
The long flower stems of the ribwort plantain (Plantago Lanceolata).
A large and bright constellation on the equator, between the stars Aldebaran and Sirius.  It contains a remarkable nebula visible to the naked eye.
A brush of twigs for sweeping; a broom; anything which sweeps away or destroys.
A double slip of leather by which bells are fastened to a hawk's legs.
A clause added to a document; a rider. See Rider.
The cry of a buck in rutting time.
A high, steep bank, as by a river or the sea, or beside a ravine or plain; a cliff with a broad face.
Eyes.
A kind of flyboat; a storeship.
The game of basketball.

The act of prowling.
