A spot, stain, or blemish.
A sedgelike plant (Cyperus esculentus) producing edible tubers, native about the Mediterranean, now cultivated in many regions; the earth almond.
Hydrophobia.
To dress with, or as with, a preen; to trim or dress with the beak, as the feathers; -- said of birds.
A staff or truncheon, used for various purposes; as, the baton of a field marshal; the baton of a conductor in musical performances.
Ten millions; as, a crore of rupees (which is nearly $5,000,000).

The criminality and consequent exposure to punishment resulting from willful disobedience of law, or from morally wrong action; the state of one who has broken a moral or political law; crime; criminality; offense against right.
A demand of a right or supposed right; a calling on another for something due or supposed to be due; an assertion of a right or fact.
The person to whom a gift or donation is made.
A cake, thinner than a bannock, made of wheat or barley or oat meal.
A short, thick piece of anything.
A kind of litter suspended from men's shoulders, for carrying persons or things; a palanquin.
A mean, sneaking fellow.
Var. of Soldier.
Wheat, or bread made from wheat.
An ancient Greek hymn in honor of Apollo as a healing deity, and, later, a song addressed to other deities.
A slab of stone used as a veneer for coarse masonry.
Manner of approaching or accosting; address.
Same as Achene.

A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic, prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strong acetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals. Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.
A genus of birds including some of the puffins.
A strong tide or current, especially in a narrow channel.
The pygostyle.
The vagus, or pneumogastric, nerve.
A goddess.

the American Standard Code for Information Interchange, a code consisting of a set of 128 7-bit combinations used in digital computers internally, for display purposes, and for exchanging data between computers.  It is very widely used, but because of the limited number of characters encoded must be supplemented or replaced by other codes for encoding special symbols or words in languages other than English.  Also used attributively; -- as, an ASCII file.
A vessel in which milk or cream is stirred, beaten, or otherwise agitated (as by a plunging or revolving dasher) in order to separate the oily globules from the other parts, and obtain butter.
A partial separation of parts, with or without a perceptible opening; a chink or fissure; a narrow breach; a crevice; as, a crack in timber, or in a wall, or in glass.
Deception deliberately practiced with a view to gaining an unlawful or unfair advantage; artifice by which the right or interest of another is injured; injurious stratagem; deceit; trick.
Pulverized sugar candy.
See Visor.
That which is most bad or evil; the most severe, pernicious, calamitous, or wicked state or degree.
A genus of palms, one species of which (Areca catechu) produces the areca nut, or betel nut, which is chewed in India and Southeast Asia with the leaf of the Piper Betle and lime.
See Cloak.
Any substance supposed to be capable of absorbing, retaining, and transporting contagious or infectious germs; as, woolen clothes are said to be active fomites.
The world; a globe as an ensign of royalty.
A puddle; a plash.
The divine energy, personified as the wife of a deity (Brahma, Vishnu, Siva, etc.); the female principle.
The superior or head of an abbey.
A wonder; a marvel.
The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn and tillage.
A white crystalline resinous substance extracted from gutta-percha by the action of alcohol or ether.
A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising or marvelous events.

The formation situated between the Permian and Lias, and so named by the Germans, because consisting of three series of strata, which are called in German the Bunter sandstein, Muschelkalk, and Keuper.
a type of folk song that originated among Black Americans at the beginning of the 20th century; has a melancholoy sound from repeated used of blue notes.
See Manteau.
See Poly.
A contraction of Photograph.
A forced or affected smile; a simper.
Form or mode of construction; general figure; make; as, the build of a ship; a great build on a man.
The moon's age at the beginning of the calendar year, or the number of days by which the last new moon has preceded the beginning of the year.
The general outward form of any solid object, as of a column or a vase.
See Lodge, n.
See Euphroe.
The whimbrel; -- called also May whaup, little whaup, and tang whaup.
trousers made of corduroy cloth; corduroys.
A license for absence from a college or a religious house.
Same as Fulahs.
The wash, or mixture of liquid substances, given to swine; hogwash; -- called also swillings.
The universal remedy of Paracelsus.
Great heat, as of the body in fever.
A cover.
A Romansch dialect spoken in some parts of Switzerland and the Tyrol.
One who rebels.

That through which anything spouts; a discharging lip, pipe, or orifice; a tube, pipe, or conductor of any kind through which a liquid is poured, or by which it is conveyed in a stream from one place to another; as, the spout of a teapot; a spout for conducting water from the roof of a building.
Whatever exists, or is conceived to exist, as a separate entity, whether animate or inanimate; any separable or distinguishable object of thought.
An enemy of the gods, esp. one of a race of demons and giants.
A tribunal or commission having charge of the revenue derived from trade and navigation.
One who fits shoes to the feet; one who furnishes or puts on shoes; as, a shoer of horses.
See Saber.
A species of steel imported from the East Indies, valued for making edge tools; Indian steel. It has in combination a minute portion of alumina and silica.
The act of wresting; a wrench; a violent twist; hence, distortion; perversion.
something remarkable, highly unusual, or exceptionally effective; as, a dilly of a movie; when I make a mistake, it's a dilly.
A rich goblet, esp. one used on state occasions.
One who lines, as, a liner of shoes or clothing.
A hypothetical hydrocarbon radical regarded as an essential residue of octane, and as entering into its derivatives; as, octyl alcohol.
The girdle of a Jewish priest or officer.
That which holds anything tightly or supports it firmly; a bandage or a prop.
The animals of any given area or epoch; as, the fauna of America; fossil fauna; recent fauna.
Also, any species of the genus Erica, of which several are European, and many more are South African, some of great beauty. See Illust. of Heather.
A small, strong-winged European falcon (Falco subbuteo), formerly trained for hawking.
The Richardson's skua (Stercorarius parasiticus);- so called from its cry.
Flattery; adulation; smooth speech.
A sloth.
A continuous noise or murmur.
A series of beds of clay and marl in the South of England, between the upper and lower greensand of the Cretaceous period.
One who hews.
See Peen.
Series.
A certain quantity estimated by weight; an English measure of weight.  See Wey.
Diminutive of Dad.
Cider. See Sicer.
A bit of wood split off; a splinter.
A suspension of arms by agreement of the commanders of opposing forces; a temporary cessation of hostilities, for negotiation or other purpose; an armistice.
A dyed fabric with designs drawn on by applying a removable wax where the dye is not wanted.

A part of the sacerdotal habit among Jews, being a covering for the back and breast, held together on the shoulders by two clasps or brooches of onyx stones set in gold, and fastened by a girdle of the same stuff as the ephod. The ephod for the priests was of plain linen; that for the high priest was richly embroidered in colors. The breastplate of the high priest was worn upon the ephod in front.
The pendulous or overhanging lateral parts of the upper lip of dogs, especially prominent in hounds; -- called also chaps. See Illust. of Bloodhound.
A binary compound of oxygen with an atom or radical, or a compound which is regarded as binary; as, iron oxide, ethyl oxide, nitrogen oxide, etc.
The European crested titmouse.
One who, or that which, wipes.
A sheet of paper, pasteboard, or the like, on which information is exhibited, esp. when the information is arranged in tabular form; as, an historical chart.
The act of freezing; -- applied chiefly to the congelation of water; congelation of fluids.
A tremulous agitation; a quick vibratory movement; a shudder; a quivering.
Same as theave.
Bub; -- a term of familiar or affectionate address to a small boy.
A gap.
A dull, stupid fellow; a drone.
See Mancus.
The wife of a king.
The lower and loose part of a coat, dress, or other like garment; the part below the waist; as, the skirt of a coat, a dress, or a mantle.
A union of three; three objects treated as one; a ternary; a trinity; as, a triad of deities.
The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob.
An early Latin version of the Scriptures (the Old Testament was translated from the Septuagint, and was also called the Italic version).
An ovum.
The under surface of the foot.
A mine.
A cavern.
A slattern; a mawk.
To fill by crowding something into; to cram with something; to load to excess; as, to stuff a bedtick.
A certain quantity; a portion; a part; a division; as, a small share of prudence.
A brant. See Brant.
A species of lyric poem, invented by Archilochus, in which a longer verse is followed by a shorter one; as, the Epodes of Horace. It does not include the elegiac distich.
A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor of spirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium.
a person who uses the left hand with greater skill than the right; a left-handed person.

A Christian priest or monk; used as a term of address for priests in some churches (especially Roman or Orthodox Catholic in Italy, Spain, Portugal, and Spanish America); -- also used in the American military.
One hostile to another; one who hates, and desires or attempts the injury of, another; a foe; an adversary; as, an enemy of or to a person; an enemy to truth, or to falsehood.
Act of gulching or gulping.
A tumor consisting of muscular tissue.
A clump of trees in a prairie.
One placed on watch, or in ambush.
See Steen.
One whose business it is to bake bread, biscuit, etc.
See Krems.
A small wheel formerly fixed to the pan of firelocks for discharging them.
In France, interest payable by government on indebtedness; the bonds, shares, stocks, etc., which represent government indebtedness.
See Berth.
A son or a daughter; a male or female descendant, in the first degree; the immediate progeny of human parents; -- in law, legitimate offspring. Used also of animals and plants.
a rotund, obese individual.
A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of the servile classes; a churl.
One of the twins.

any of several types of protein particle lacking nucleic acid, believed to be the cause of certain slow-developing infectious diseases such as scapie in sheep, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and Kuru in humans.
The garfish.
A degree, usually a slight degree, of some color, taste, or something foreign, infused into another substance or mixture, or added to it; tincture; color; dye; hue; shade; taste.
Any plant of the natural order Cycadace<ae/, as the sago palm, etc.
A young bullock or heifer.
tarsus.
Border; margin; edge; verge.

The fruit of the mango tree. It is rather larger than an apple, and of an ovoid shape. Some varieties are fleshy and luscious, and others tough and tasting of turpentine. The green fruit is pickled for market.
The act of snorting; the sound produced in snorting.
A vessel of clay or stone.
Cerium oxide, CeO2, a white infusible substance constituting about one per cent of the material of the common incandescent mantle.
A short, sharp sound, as of metal struck with a slight degree of violence.
A hangman. See Jack Ketch.

An appearance of diagonal lines or ribs produced in textile fabrics by causing the weft threads to pass over one and under two, or over one and under three or more, warp threads, instead of over one and under the next in regular succession, as in plain weaving.
A small genus of plants constituting the family Batidaceae: low straggling dioecious shrubs.
A flood; a creek or inlet; a bay or estuary; a river; -- obsolete, except as a place name, -- as Fleet Street in London.
A smooth, flat surface, like the side of a board; a thin, flat, smooth piece of anything; a slab.
An adz; a hoe.

A disciple of the philosopher Zeno; one of a Greek sect which held that men should be free from passion, unmoved by joy or grief, and should submit without complaint to unavoidable necessity, by which all things are governed.
the Teutonic god of thunder; counterpart of Norse Thor.
A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the Old World. Many species are known. See Coral snake, under Coral.
A rope or long thong of leather with a running noose, used for catching horses, cattle, etc.
The place of departed spirits; Hades; also, the grave.
A few silk threads or horsehairs, or a strip of linen or the like, introduced beneath the skin by a knife or needle, so as to form an issue; also, the issue so formed.
See Doily.
An end; conclusion. It is often placed at the end of a book.
A preliminary or auxiliary proposition demonstrated or accepted for immediate use in the demonstration of some other proposition, as in mathematics or logic.

A colorless gaseous substance (O3) obtained (as by the silent discharge of electricity in oxygen) as an allotropic form of oxygen, containing three atoms in the molecule.  It is a strong oxidizer, and probably exists in the air, though by the ordinary tests it is liable to be confused with certain other substances, as hydrogen dioxide, or certain oxides of nitrogen.  It derives its name from its peculiar odor, which resembles that of weak chlorine.
A water course; a ditch.
The act of sneering.
A book consisting of sheets each of which is folded into six leaves.

A West Indian dance contest, in which participants must dance under a pole which is lowered successively until only one participant can successfully pass under, without falling. It is  often performed at celebrations, such as weddings.
A genus of birds which includes the common hoopoe.
An alloy (usually yellow) of copper and zinc, in variable proportion, but often containing two parts of copper to one part of zinc. It sometimes contains tin, and rarely other metals.
a valuable fiber plant (Hibiscus cannabinus) of the East Indies now widespread in cultivation.
One who, or that which, paces.
In cards, four successive cards of the same suit.  Cf. Tierce, 4.
A contraction of Supernumerary, in sense  2.
An instrument or machine to break or bruise the woody part of flax or hemp so that it may be separated from the fiber.
An animal destitute of human reason; any animal not human; esp. a quadruped; a beast.
a motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
A genus of coniferous trees, having deciduous leaves, in fascicles (see Illust. of Fascicle).
A small piece of mutton or other meat roasted on a skewer; -- so called in Turkey and Persia.

Any one of the teeth back of the incisors and canines.  The molars which replace the deciduous or milk teeth are designated as premolars, and those which are not preceded by deciduous teeth are sometimes called true molars. See Tooth.
A boggy place.
A European finch (Serinus hortulanus) closely related to the canary.
A share; a part or portion; -- obsolete, except in the colloquial phrase, to go snacks, i. e., to share.
See Wends.
One who dates.
A pharos; a lighthouse.
A kind of military cap or headdress.
One who mines by contract, at so much per ton of coal or ore.
A carucate.
The exercise of love, kindness, mercy, favor; disposition to benefit or serve another; favor bestowed or privilege conferred.
A vat or tub in which the mash is made; a mash tub.
The ventral and anterior of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis; sharebone; pubic bone.
A slick, or smooth and slippery, surface or place; a sleek.
A genus of lizards, one of the few which feed upon vegetable substances; also, one of these lizards.
same as chimpanzee.
Same as 4th Lunge.
The act of sparing; moderation; restraint.
A piece of lively dance music, in two strains which are repeated; also, the dance.
A place in a pagan temple in which the images of the deities were inclosed.
A tree of the genus Fagus.
A wave.
A place; a locality.

A kind of larva, or nurse, which is prroduced within the sporocyst of certain trematodes by asexual generation. It in turn produces, in the same way, either another generation of rediae, or else cercariae within its own body. Called also proscolex, and nurse. See Illustration in Appendix.
Indian millet and its varieties. See Sorghum.
pl. of Wife.
A lofty West African tree (Khaya Senegalensis), related to the mahogany, which it resembles in the quality of the wood. The bark is used as a febrifuge.
A resin exuding from a tropical American tree (Hymen<ae/a courbaril), and much used by varnish makers.
A captious or frivolous objection.
One who holds a feu.
A store, stock, or quantity of anything accumulated or laid up; a hidden supply; a treasure; as, a hoard of provisions; a hoard of money.
A woman's name; also, a popular name for a parrot.
The pole or other support on which fowls rest at night; a perch.
Silver, pounded into ingots of the shape of a shoe, and used as currency. The most common weight is about one pound troy.
To show to be false; to convict of, or charge with, falsehood.
A Feigned story or tale, intended to instruct or amuse; a fictitious narration intended to enforce some useful truth or precept; an apologue.  See the Note under Apologue.
One who seeks for things which gratify merely himself; a selfish person; a selfist.
An Asiatic burrowing rodent (Siphneus aspalax) resembling the mole rat. It is native of the Altai Mountains.
See Capel.
A kind of head covering; a caul.
A diseased condition of rye and other cereals, in which the grains become black, and often spur-shaped. It is caused by a parasitic fungus, Claviceps purpurea.
A hunter.
A native or inhabitant of Switzerland; a Switzer; the people of Switzerland.
Water flying in small drops or particles, as by the force of wind, or the dashing of waves, or from a waterfall, and the like.
A subject or topic on which a person writes or speaks; a proposition for discussion or argument; a text.
an ancient Assyrian city.

Any angle other than a right angle; the angle which one surface makes with another when they are not at right angles; the slant or inclination of such surface; as, to give a bevel to the edge of a table or a stone slab; the bevel of a piece of timber.

Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging to Anthus and allied genera, of the family Motacillid<ae/. They strongly resemble the true larks in habits, colors, and the great length of the hind claw. They are, therefore, often called titlarks, and pipit larks.
A verse, of whatever measure or number of feet.
See Weasand.
See Lack.
One of the fruit dots, or small clusters of sporangia, on the back of the fronds of ferns.
An ornamental cup or vase with a large, flat, shallow bowl, resting on a pedestal and often having handles.
An oily liquid, CI3.CHO, analogous to chloral and bromal.
A fine imposed as a penalty for violation of the law.
The inclosed space near the point where two lines meet; a corner; a nook.

A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in a state of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme by the action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals, and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.

A contrivance employed by the ancient Peruvians, Mexicans, etc., as a substitute for writing and figures, consisting of a main cord, from which hung at certain distances smaller cords of various colors, each having a special meaning, as silver, gold, corn, soldiers. etc. Single, double, and triple knots were tied in the smaller cords, representing definite numbers. It was chiefly used for arithmetical purposes, and to register important facts and events.
the Norse god of poetry and music; a son of Odin.
A coarse woolen stuff with a long nap; -- usually dyed in plain colors.
One who, or that which, inks; especially, in printing, the pad or roller which inks the type.
A motherless calf in a range herd of cattle.
A civil or military authority in Turkey or Egypt; same as Pasha.
A small arboreal tropical American insectivorous lizard (Anolis carolinensis) with the ability to change skin color.
A bigamist.
The name of several evergreen trees.  The wood is remarkable for its durability and fragrant odor.
A head covering of various kinds; a hood; a coif; a cap.
A native prince or king; also, a landholder or person of importance in the agricultural districts.
Truth; reality.
A kind of dog. See Collie.
A frame (commonly) of wood serving to hold a canvas upright, or nearly upright, for the painter's convenience or for exhibition.
A musical note, formerly in use, equal to two longs, four breves, or eight semibreves.
Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now, commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corner is marked.
A lath; a shaving or chip, as of wood or stone.
A female fox.
Any imagined frightful object, especially one supposed to haunt the darkness; a bugbear.
A spirit; a ghost; an apparition; a hobgoblin.
A woman supposed to be endowed with a spirit of prophecy.
A city of France celebrated for certain manufactures.
The inspissated juice of the Papaver somniferum, or white poppy.
The gadwall.

A utensil for separating the finer and coarser parts of a pulverized or granulated substance from each other. It consist of a vessel, usually shallow, with the bottom perforated, or made of hair, wire, or the like, woven in meshes.
A stall or a crib for an ox, cow, or other animal.
The stem of a fungus or mushroom.
Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple.

Any large, rapacious bird of the Falcon family, esp. of the genera Aquila and Hali<ae/etus.  The eagle is remarkable for strength, size, graceful figure, keenness of vision, and extraordinary flight.  The most noted species are the golden eagle (Aquila chrysa<eum/tus); the imperial eagle of Europe (Aquila mogilnik or Aquila imperialis); the American bald eagle (Hali<ae/etus leucocephalus); the European sea eagle (Hali<ae/etus albicilla); and the great harpy eagle (Thrasaetus harpyia).  The figure of the eagle, as the king of birds, is commonly used as an heraldic emblem, and also for standards and emblematic devices.  See Bald eagle, Harpy, and Golden eagle.
Same as <AE/neid.

A brother or member of any religious order, but especially of one of the four mendicant orders, viz: (a) Minors, Gray Friars, or Franciscans. (b) Augustines. (c) Dominicans or Black Friars. (d) White Friars or Carmelites. See these names in the Vocabulary.
Faith personified as a goddess; the goddess of faith.
The sign <flat/; the same as B flat.
See Do<ntil/a.
A genus of plants, mostly perennial, having succulent leaves and cymose flowers; orpine; stonecrop.
One of the ancient Scandinavian poets and historiographers; a reciter and singer of heroic poems, eulogies, etc., among the Norsemen; more rarely, a bard of any of the ancient Teutonic tribes.

Any one of several species of large odd-toed ungulates belonging to Tapirus, Elasmognathus, and allied genera. They have a long prehensile upper lip, short ears, short and stout legs, a short, thick tail, and short, close hair. They have three toes on the hind feet, and four toes on the fore feet, but the outermost toe is of little use.
Extinction.
See Eyelet.
A dance of Polish origin, but now common everywhere. It is performed by two persons in common time.
Treacherous; betraying.
A lord; a landholder, esp. one who holds land directly of the crown.
One of the peculiar stinging cells found in C<oe/lenterata; a nematocyst; a lasso cell.
An association; a league or confederacy.
Stop; halt; hindrance.
A genus of small insectivores including the common European mole.
A mark left by something that has passed along; as, the track, or wake, of a ship; the track of a meteor; the track of a sled or a wheel.
A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
A half.
The last, and usually the longest, division of the small intestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine.
See Payer.
An East India herring (Clupea toli) which is extensively caught for the sake of its roe and for its flesh.
a substance which, in small concentrations, promotes root formation, bud growth, or certain other processes such as fruit ripening or leaf drop in plants.
See 4th Crowd.
A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffen and support them.
One who fries.
Foul matter; dirt, rubbed in; sullying blackness, deeply ingrained.

Any one of a large group of bright-colored clamatorial birds belonging to Pitta, and allied genera of the family Pittid<ae/. Most of the species are varied with three or more colors, such as blue, green, crimson, yellow, purple, and black. They are called also ground thrushes, and Old World ant thrushes; but they are not related to the true thrushes.
The coast or land adjacent to a large body of water, as an ocean, lake, or large river.
See Graft.
A beach; a strand; in the plains and deserts of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona, a broad, level spot, on which subsequently becomes dry by evaporation.
A broad piece of sawed timber, differing from a board only in being thicker. See Board.
The act of twisting; a contortion; a flexure; a convolution; a bending.
A bout; a thrust; a venew.
See Aerie, and Eyrie.

The character, sentiment, or disposition of a community or people, considered as a natural endowment; the spirit which actuates manners and customs; also, the characteristic tone or genius of an institution or social organization.
A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament.  Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
The part of a plow which projects downward beneath the beam, for holding the share and other working parts; -- also called standard, or post.
A waiting for; ambush; watch; watching; heed.
One who is loved.
Any one of several Asiatic birds; as, the Indian robins. See Indian robin, below.
See Sadh.
The hard covering of an egg.
The short run before a leap.
A Muslim title for a ruler; a judge.
An instrument or medium by which some important action is performed, or an important end accomplished; as, legislatures, courts, armies, taxgatherers, etc., are organs of government.
See Annals.
One who, or that which, mixes.
Nozzle.
A pocket.
A true statement; freedom from error of falsehood; adherence to truth or fact.
A sharp or uneven edge on a board that is cut from a log not perfectly squared, or that is made in the process of squaring.  See Wany, a.
One who buys; a purchaser.
Judgment; justice; sentence.
A hypothetical radical of glycerin.
An escape.
A game of cards; -- called also taroc.
A police station.
See Bort.
The color of growing plants; the color of the solar spectrum intermediate between the yellow and the blue.
A scurf or scabby disease, especially of the scalp.
A piece of cane or reed with a knot at each end, or a hollow cylinder of wood with a ridge at each end, used to wind thread or yarn upon.
One who topes, or drinks frequently or to excess; a drunkard; a sot.
In China, the official headquarters or residence of a mandarin, including court rooms, offices, gardens, prisons, etc.; the place where the business of any public department is transcated.
Same as Alewife.
A round dance.
A circle; hence, a diadem.
Same as Yaupon.
Any species or rail of the genera Crex and Porzana; -- so called from its singular cry. See Corncrake.
An earth-covered Navajo lodge; it is traditionally built with the entrance facing east.
See Cabob, n. & v. t.
A Flemish sloop with a castle at each end.
A daring villain; a bandit; one who sets law at defiance; a professional assassin or murderer.
A creel or osier basket.

A trench made in the earth by digging, particularly a trench for draining wet land, for guarding or fencing inclosures, or for preventing an approach to a town or fortress. In the latter sense, it is called also a moat or a fosse.
See Stoat.
One who dares or defies.
a type of rye bread, made using molasses or brown sugar.
The loosely woven substance which lines the chambers within the gleba in certain Gasteromycetes.
A harsh, quick sound, like that made by a stretched string when pulled and suddenly let go; as, the twang of a bowstring.
One who believes in the existence of a God, but denies revealed religion; a freethinker.
The act of moving in any manner; traveling; as, the going is bad.
The service or sacrifice of the Mass.
A feather.
To undergo or exhibit minute difference or variation, as of color, meaning, expression, etc.; to pass by slight changes; -- used chiefly with a preposition, as into, away, off.
A genus of tropical or subtropical plants of the natural order Anonace<ae/, including the soursop.
A train of vein material mixed with rubbish; fragments of ore which have become separated by the action of water or the weather, and serve to direct in the discovery of mines.
Species; kind.
One who, or that which, dives.
A kind of danceable music popular among black South Africans; it includes a whistle among its instruments.
See Motmot.
See Crowd, a violin.
A mantelpiece.
See Gumbo.
The name of Vishnu in his tenth and last avatar.
See Verst.
A waif.
A genus including several species of large marine gastropods having massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on the columella.
A light one horse two-wheeled vehicle.
The act of belching; also, that which is belched; an eructation.
A young lady of superior beauty and attractions; a handsome lady, or one who attracts notice in society; a fair lady.

Any of several valuable estates of the Egyptian khedive or his family. The most important are the Da"i*ra Sa"ni*eh (s<aum/"n<icr/*<ecr/), or Da"i*ra Sa"ni*yeh, and the Da"i*ra Khas"sa, administered by the khedive's European bondholders, and known collectively as the Daira, or the Daira estates.

A polyphonic composition, developed from a given theme or themes, according to strict contrapuntal rules. The theme is first given out by one voice or part, and then, while that pursues its way, it is repeated by another at the interval of a fifth or fourth, and so on, until all the parts have answered one by one, continuing their several melodies and interweaving them in one complex progressive whole, in which the theme is often lost and reappears.
To inhabit.
An inferior olive size having a woody pulp and a large clingstone pit, growing in the mountainous and high-valley districts around the city of Moron, in Spain.

A species of brome grass (Bromus secalinus) which is a troublesome weed in wheat fields, and is often erroneously regarded as degenerate or changed wheat; it bears a very slight resemblance to oats, and if reaped and ground up with wheat, so as to be used for food, is said to produce narcotic effects; -- called also cheat and Willard's bromus.
A wood of small growth; a thicket of brushwood. See Coppice.
A leaf of a book or manuscript.

The tubers of the Mexican plant Ipom<oe/a purga (or Exogonium purga) of the family Convolvulaceae, a climber much like the morning-glory. The abstract, extract, and powder, prepared from the tubers, are well known purgative (cathartic) medicines, and are also called jalap. Other species of Ipom<oe/a yield several inferior kinds of jalap, as the Ipom<oe/a Orizabensis, and Ipom<oe/a tuberosa.
See Leden.

The opening through which an animal receives food; the aperture between the jaws or between the lips; also, the cavity, containing the tongue and teeth, between the lips and the pharynx; the buccal cavity.

A saxicoline singing bird (Kittacincla macroura) of India, noted for the sweetness and power of its song. In confinement it imitates the notes of other birds and various animals with accuracy. Its head, neck, back, breast, and tail are glossy black, the rump white, the under parts chestnut.
A bed or place for repose or sleep; particularly, in the United States, a lounge.
A sharp instrument used for opening veins, lancing gums, etc.; a kind of lancet.
The state of being tilled, or prepared for a crop; culture; as, land is good tilth.
Wool.
The genus of trees including the anchovy pear tree Grias cauliflora, whose fruit is somewhat like the mango.
The benevolent spirits of the dead, especially of dead ancestors, regarded as family deities and protectors.
Any one attached to a Mohammedan mosque, esp. a student of the higher branches of theology in a mosque school.
That which makes smooth; varnish.
An Irish serving woman or girl.

A group of thallophytic plant-like organisms of low organization, destitute of chlorophyll, in which reproduction is mainly accomplished by means of asexual spores, which are produced in a great variety of ways, though sexual reproduction is known to occur in certain Phycomycetes, or so-called algal fungi. They include the molds, mildews, rusts, smuts, mushrooms, toadstools, puff balls, and the allies of each.  In the two-kingdom classification system they were classed with the plants, but in the modern five-kingdom classification, they are not classed as plants, but are classed in their own separate kingdom fungi, which includes the phyla Zygomycota (including simple fungi such as bread molds), Ascomycota (including the yeasts), Basidiomycota (including the mushrooms, smuts, and rusts), and Deuteromycota (the fungi imperfecti).  Some of the forms, such as the yeasts, appear as single-celled microorganisms, but all of the fungi are are eukaryotic, thus distinguishing them from the prokaryotic microorganisms of the kingdon Monera.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.
A wild cat (Felis manul), having long, soft, light-colored fur.  It is found in the mountains of Central Asia, and dwells among rocks.

That which is worthless or useless; rubbish; refuse.

The front of an army. [Obs.] See Van.

The glossy ibis (Ibis falcinellus); -- said to have given its name to the city of Liverpool.

A ratchet wheel, or notched bar, with which a pawl or click works.

An intensely radioactive gaseous element produced by the radioactive decay of radium-226, which is the main isotope of radium found in pitchblende.  Chemically it is an inert noble gas.  Its atomic symbol is Rn. It has an atomic number of 86.  The radon isotope produced by decay of radium has an atomic weight of 222.017, and this isotope decays by alpha emission with a half-life of 3.82 days.  Numerous other isotopes have been observed, all radioactive and all having half-lives shorter than that of radon-222.  Radon was discovered by M. and Mme. Curie, of Paris, in their studies of the radioactive substances in pitchblende.  Radon was originally called  radium emanation or exradio.
A short concise writing or letter; a statement in few words.

An internal muscle arising from the lumbar vertebr<ae/ and inserted into the femur. In man there are usually two on each side, and the larger one, or great psoas, forms a part of the iliopsoas.
Sickness; disease; pestilence; death.

Character or construction of a thing as determining its external appearance; outward aspect; make; figure; form; guise; as, the shape of a tree; the shape of the head; an elegant shape.

Grasp; seizure; fast hold; clutch.

an officer who proclaims the orders or directions of a court, or who gives public notice by loud proclamation; as, a town-crier.
A crag; a cliff; a glen with overhanging sides.
See Kish.
A kind of wild red cherry.
A sapling left standing in a fallen wood.
A porridge or gruel of maize meal and water, milk, or the like.
An East Indian insectivorous mammal (Gymnura Rafflesii), somewhat like a rat in appearance, but allied to the hedgehog.
See Cimbia.

A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif., a compound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or with a monamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which two atoms of hydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or acid radicals; -- frequently used as a combining form; as, succinimide.
A genus of Western U. S. annuals with showy yellow or white flowers.
The act of staring; a fixed look with eyes wide open.
The part of a tree or plant remaining in the earth after the stem or trunk is cut off; the stub.
The radius or ray of a wheel; one of the small bars which are inserted in the hub, or nave, and which serve to support the rim or felly.
A genus of fungi. See Truffle.
The joint or bend of the arm; the outer curve in the middle of the arm when bent.
A part of a harness; a hame.
A colloquial abbreviation of midshipman.
Groats; coarse flour or meal.

A projecting member left by cutting away the wood around it, and made to insert into a mortise, and in this way secure together the parts of a frame; especially, such a member when it passes entirely through the thickness of the piece in which the mortise is cut, and shows on the other side.  Cf. Tooth, Tusk.
A soft and flexible fabric for men's wear, made wholly of wool except in some inferior kinds, the wool being dyed, usually in two colors, before weaving.
A genus of Carnivora including the common bears.
A climate; a tract or region of the earth. See Climate.
The backbone or spine of an animal; the back.
Anything intended to lead into a snare; a lure that deceives and misleads into danger, or into the power of an enemy; a bait.
See Gree, a step.
One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or should be, paid.
See Ribbon.
A kind of dry fruit, consisting of three or more cells, each which at length breaks open at the inner angle.
See Koran.
Same as Amice, a hood or cape.
Headstrong; obstinate.
Tranquil; peaceful; calm.
A word or look of derision or mockery.
A transient glance; an unexpected view of something that startles one; a sudden fear.
The source of electrical power in a building; the wiring system of a building.
Ready money; a loan of money.
A collection of people; a company; a number; a multitude.
A monastery or society of persons of either sex, secluded from the world and devoted to religion and celibacy; also, the monastic building or buildings.
The land belonging to a lord or nobleman, or so much land as a lord or great personage kept in his own hands, for the use and subsistence of his family.
A scoop with a long handle, used to wash the sides of a vessel, and formerly to wet the sails or deck.
A pulling; a disturbance.
A red coloring matter derived from phenol; -- called also, in commerce, yellow corallin.
Clay, or potter's earth; sometimes pure clay, or alumina. See Clay.
To make music upon; to tune.

One of the sonant mutes <beta/, <delta/, <gamma/ (b, d, g), in Greek, or of their equivalents in other languages, so named as intermediate between the tenues, <pi/, <tau/, <kappa/ (p, t, k), and the aspiratae  (aspirates) <phi/, <theta/, <chi/ (ph or f, th, ch). Also called middle mute, or medial, and sometimes soft mute.

The upright post about which the steps of a circular staircase wind; hence, in stairs having straight flights, the principal post at the foot of a staircase, or the secondary ones at the landings.  Also called newel post.  See Hollow newel, under Hollow.
Printing and writing papers of particular sizes. See under paper, n.
A boat; a small vessel.

A college or body composed of the hierarchy (the imams, or ministers of religion, the muftis, or doctors of law, and the cadis, or administrators of justice).  That of Turkey alone now has political power; its head is the sheik ul Islam.
The edges or lower borders of the roof of a building, which overhang the walls, and cast off the water that falls on the roof.

A line or surface to which, at every point, a vertical or plumb line is perpendicular; a line or surface which is everywhere parallel to the surface of still water; -- this is the true level, and is a curve or surface in which all points are equally distant from the center of the earth, or rather would be so if the earth were an exact sphere.
A wrought-iron plate from which a gun barrel or pipe is made by bending and welding the edges together, and drawing the thick tube thus formed.
A detached low mountain, or high rising abruptly from the general level of the surrounding plain; -- applied to peculiar elevations in the Rocky Mountain region.
A noisy, blustering fellow, more insolent than courageous, who threatens, intimidates, or badgers people who are smaller or weaker than he is; an insolent, tyrannical fellow.
Corah silk.
same as Erg.

A medium of great elasticity and extreme tenuity, once supposed to pervade all space, the interior of solid bodies not excepted, and to be the medium of transmission of light and heat; hence often called luminiferous ether.  It is no longer believed that such a medium is required for the transmission of electromagnetic waves; the modern use of the term is mostly a figurative term for empty space, or for literary effect, and not intended to imply the actual existence of a physical medium.  However. modern cosmological theories based on quantum field theory do not rule out the possibility that the inherent energy of the vacuum is greater than zero, in which case the concept of an ether pervading the vacuum may have more than metaphoric meaning.
Among Muslims, a warrior champion or veteran, esp. in the destruction of infidels.

A rude picture, as of a bird, beast, or the like, used by the North American Indians as a symbolic designation, as of a family or a clan; also, the object or animal itself, considered as an symbol of the family.
One who taws; a dresser of white leather.

A kind of canvaslike cotton fabric, used to stiffen and protect the lower part of trousers and of the skirts of women's dresses, etc.; -- so called from Wigan, the name of a town in Lancashire, England.
To exert one's power or faculties upon; to make an effort to perform; to attempt; to endeavor; to make experiment or trial of; to try.
An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.
The same prepared with a vehicle, as oil, water with gum, or the like, for application to a surface.
To lay in a conical or other pile; to make into a large pile; as, to stack hay, cornstalks, or grain; to stack or place wood.
The mangrove; -- so called in the Pacific Islands.
A plain sprinkled with trees or underbrush; a glade.

Any one of numerous species of large shrimplike Crustacea having slender legs and long antenn<ae/. They mostly belong to the genera Pandalus, Pal<ae/mon, Pal<ae/monetes, and Peneus, and are much used as food. The common English prawn is Pal<ae/mon serratus.
Corrupted form Bolt.
A vault wholly or partly under ground; especially, a vault under a church, whether used for burial purposes or for a subterranean chapel or oratory.
See 4th Crowd.
The capelin.
A kind of clay for making melting pots.
The thickest part, or the time when anything is thickest.
The pendent fleshy lobe in the middle of the posterior border of the soft palate.
The name popularly given to the rich man in our Lord's parable of the <ldquo/Rich Man and Lazarus<rdquo/ (Luke xvi. 19-31). Hence, a name for a rich worldling.
The common title of honor in Persia, prefixed to the surname of an individual.  When appended to the surname, it signifies Prince.
See Rhyme.
A violent disturbance of the atmosphere, attended by wind, rain, snow, hail, or thunder and lightning; hence, often, a heavy fall of rain, snow, or hail, whether accompanied with wind or not.
Stay; stop; delay.
The refuse whale blubber, used as a manure, and in the manufacture of Prussian blue.

The peceived object occasioned by the impulse or vibration of a material substance affecting the ear; a sensation or perception of the mind received through the ear, and produced by the impulse or vibration of the air or other medium with which the ear is in contact; the effect of an impression made on the organs of hearing by an impulse or vibration of the air caused by a collision of bodies, or by other means; noise; report; as, the sound of a drum; the sound of the human voice; a horrid sound; a charming sound; a sharp, high, or shrill sound.
The joint which connects the foot with the leg; the tarsus.
The caecum, the cavity in which the large intestine begins and into which the ileum opens.
A genus (Lotus) of leguminous plants much resembling clover.
One of the large feathers of a bird's wing, or one of the rectrices of the tail; also, the stock of such a feather.
A peculiar substance obtained from the wool of sheep, consisting largely of potash mixed with fatty and earthy matters. It is used as a source of potash and also for the manufacture of gas.
The rhinoceros.

A plant having twigs suitable for making brooms to sweep with when bound together; esp., the Cytisus scoparius of Western Europe, which is a low shrub with long, straight, green, angular branches, minute leaves, and large yellow flowers.
See Miter.

A colorless crystalline substance, C6H3.CH3.(OH)2, which is obtained from certain lichens (Roccella, Lecanora, etc.), also from extract of aloes, and artificially from certain derivatives of toluene.  It changes readily into orcein.
The act of uniting or joining two or more things into one, or the state of being united or joined; junction; coalition; combination.
The person creating a wakf.
A violent collision or compression; a crash; destruction; ruin.
A book; esp., a collection of poems written by one author; as, the divan of Hafiz.
The Baltic or variable cod (Gadus callarias), by some believed to be the young of the common codfish.
See Stirk.
A hinge.
To set fire to; to cause to burn; to set burning; to ignite; to kindle; as, to light a candle or lamp; to light the gas; -- sometimes with up.
The gavial.
Sorrow; dole.
A little face; a small, plane surface; as, the facets of a diamond.
A colloquial or humorous name for any science or branch of knowledge.
A flirt.
pl. of Life.
A scroll.

The ceremony observed in conferring the degree of doctor of divinity in some European universities. It begins by a harangue of the chancellor addressed to the young doctor, who then receives the cap, and presides at the disputation (also called the aulic).
The sum of six times ten; sixty units or objects.
A two-footed animal, as man.
See Attar.

A metallic pin with a head, used for uniting two plates or pieces of material together, by passing it through them and then beating or pressing down the point so that it shall spread out and form a second head; a pin or bolt headed or clinched at both ends.
Tonicity, or tone; as, muscular tonus.
Amice, a hood or cape. See 2d Amice.
A collective term for the Welsh race; -- so called by themselves .
A decree of the Sultan.
One who takes notice.
The arch or rib which crosses a Gothic vault diagonally.
A small collection of sheaves set up in the field; a shock; in England, twelve sheaves.

A tenth; the tenth part of anything; specifically, the tenthpart of the increase arising from the profits of land and stock, allotted to the clergy for their support, as in England, or devoted to religious or charitable uses. Almost all the tithes of England and Wales are commuted by law into rent charges.
A donkey.
A rectangular iron frame in which pages or columns of type are imposed.
The proximal segment of the hind limb; the thigh.
See Teyne.
One who deals in oils.
Frothy matter raised on liquids by boiling, effervescence, or agitation; froth; foam; scum.
Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. See Vair.

A genus of American liliaceous, sometimes arborescent, plants having long, pointed, and often rigid, leaves at the top of a more or less woody stem, and bearing a large panicle of showy white blossoms.

A mineral of great hardness, and, when transparent, of much beauty. It occurs in hexagonal prisms, commonly of a green or bluish green color, but also yellow, pink, and white. It is a silicate of aluminum and beryllium. The aquamarine is a transparent, sea-green variety used as a gem. The emerald is another variety highly prized in jewelry, and distinguished by its deep color, which is probably due to the presence of a little oxide of chromium.

Pottage made by pouring some boiling liquid on meal (esp. oatmeal), and stirring it. It is called beef brose, water brose, etc., according to the name of the liquid (beef broth, hot water, etc.) used.

The C.G.S. unit of density of magnetic field, equal to a field of one line of force per square centimeter, being thus adopted as an international unit at Paris in 1900; sometimes used as a unit of intensity of magnetic field. It was previously suggested as a unit of magnetomotive force.
Any Asiatic pheasant of the genus Lophophorus, as the Impeyan pheasant.
A variety of the common cabbage (Brassica oleracea major), having curled leaves, -- much cultivated for winter use.
the genus comprising the most common varieties of shad.  It replaces the older term Clupea.  See also shad.
Minced meat.
Wild oats, brome grass, or darnel grass; -- called also drawk, dravick, and drank.
The breast.
A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer and softer than the nap of velvet.
One of the Aztec race or people.
A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountains of India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger and other wild animals in packs.
A genus of nudibranchiate mollusks having a wreath of branchi<ae/ on the back.
One of several very small species and varieties of African antelopes, of the genus Cephalophus, as the Cape guevi or kleeneboc (Cephalophus pygm<ae/a); -- called also pygmy antelope.
An extensive plain with or without vegetation.
A free and independent person; specif., a lord paramount; a sovereign.

An electronic device that converts electronic signals into sound waves, and sound waves into electronic signals, used to transmit information between computers by the use of ordinary telephone lines; also called modulator-demodulator; as, the latest modems can transmit data at 56,000 baud over a clear telephone line.  The speed of transmission of information by a modem is usually measured in units of baud, equivalent to bits per second.

A sequence of phonemes, often a word fragment, which constitutes the minimum unit of meaning or syntax within a given word.  A morph may be one of several variants of a morpheme, depending for its individal form on the context in which it occurs.  Thus the morphs -s and -es are variants of the morpheme by which the plural form of an English noun is expressed.
A rawhide whip plaited with two thongs of buffalo hide.
Refuge.
A slunk calf.
The sense or faculty by which certain qualities of bodies are perceived through the instrumentally of the olfactory nerves. See Sense.
See Sheik.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as of birch.
a petty officer on a merchant ship who controls the work of other seamen; a contraction of boatswain.
A kind of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in the Philippine Islands.
An extortioner. See Poller.
Same as Sapajou.
See Whort.
The French name for concrete; hence, concrete made after the French fashion.
See Clamp.
Stuffing, or mixture of viands, like that used on dressing a fowl; forcemeat.
A close compression, as with the ends of the fingers, or with an instrument; a nip.
Prey; plunder; booty.

Low, vulgar, unauthorized language; a popular but unauthorized word, phrase, or mode of expression; also, the jargon of some particular calling or class in society; low popular cant; as, the slang of the theater, of college, of sailors, etc.
A ladder; a series of steps; a means of ascending.
A religious devotee or dervish in Persia.
The sound made when a cork is forcibly drawn from a bottle.
A boat used by rude nations, formed of trunk of a tree, excavated, by cutting of burning, into a suitable shape. It is propelled by a paddle or paddles, or sometimes by sail, and has no rudder.
A tablet; a register; hence, a list or scheme inscribed on a tablet.
A black flag with white skull and crossbones, formerly used by pirates; -- called also Jolly Roger and pirate flag.
Same as Tuy<egrave/re.

A species of pepper (Piper betle), the leaves of which are chewed, with the areca or betel nut and a little shell lime, by the inhabitants of the East Indies. It is a woody climber with ovate many-nerved leaves.
A light cape, usually of lace, worn by women, to cover the neck and throat, and extending to the shoulders.
That which is inserted or set in; an insertion.

The chief magistrate of a city or borough; the chief administrative officer of a municipal corporation.  In some American cities there is a city court of which the major is chief judge.  The post is usually elective, its holder chosen by the electorate of the entire city.
Sloppy mud.
The principal rafters of a roof, especially a pair of rafters taken together.
Loins.
A sudden squall. See Pirry.
Any one of numerous species of limicoline game birds of the family Scolopacidae, having a long, slender, nearly straight beak.
One who frees, or sets free.
To form by heating and hammering; to beat into any particular shape, as a metal.

A cylinder, or a cylindrical perforation, having a continuous rib, called the thread, winding round it spirally at a constant inclination, so as to leave a continuous spiral groove between one turn and the next, -- used chiefly for producing, when revolved, motion or pressure in the direction of its axis, by the sliding of the threads of the cylinder in the grooves between the threads of the perforation adapted to it, the former being distinguished as the external, or male screw, or, more usually the screw; the latter as the internal, or female screw, or, more usually, the nut.
The Australian moundbird (Leipoa ocellata); it incubates eggs naturally in sandy mounds.
One of the hereditary nobility among the Tatars, esp. one of the second class.
A garment extending from the waist to the knee or ankle, covering each leg separately.
To put in the ground and cover, as seed for growth; as, to plant maize.
The word or expression so used.

A preparation of vegetables, as lettuce, celery, water cress, onions, etc., usually dressed with salt, vinegar, oil, and spice, and eaten for giving a relish to other food; as, lettuce salad; tomato salad, etc.
Usury.
A legislative council of elders or chiefs; a senate.
A light repast between meals; a lunch.
Same as Lorry, or Lorrie.
A fat herring with undeveloped roe.
See Mulley.
One who steals; one who commits theft or larceny. See Theft.
A long seat, differing from a stool in its greater length.
An inlet from the Gulf of Mexico, from a lake, or from a large river, sometimes sluggish, sometimes without perceptible movement except from tide and wind.
Same as Eagre.
A person affected with leprosy.
A nappy cloth.
A prop. See 3d Shore.
The act of plucking; a pull; a twitch.
Any species of the order Ophidia; an ophidian; a serpent, whether harmless or venomous. See Ophidia, and Serpent.
The leaves of several leguminous plants of the genus Cassia. (Cassia acutifolia, Cassia angustifolia, etc.). They constitute a valuable but nauseous cathartic medicine.

The American bison buffalo (Bison Americanus), a large, gregarious bovine quadruped with shaggy mane and short black horns, which formerly roamed in herds over most of the temperate portion of North America, but by 1900 was restricted to very limited districts in the region of the Rocky Mountains, and was almost hunted to extinction.
See Comb.
A glass vessel or bottle, especially a small bottle for medicines; a vial.
A painful, spasmodic affection of the muscles of some part of the body, as of the neck or back, rendering it difficult to move the part.
A fluid substance; a body whose particles move easily among themselves.
See pansy.
The sound produced by soughing; a hollow murmur or roaring.
See 3d Chase, n., 3.
The siskin.
A name applied to the amorphous or crystalline mass obtained from bile by the action of alcohol and ether. It is composed of a mixture of the sodium salts of the bile acids.
A young hawk, when it begins to leave the nest.
One who utters gibes.
A large drinking bowl; -- originally made of maple.
A mat or screen of fibers, as of the kuskus grass, hung at a door or window and kept wet to moisten and cool the air as it enters.
The whole; the whole sum or amount; as, these sums added make the grand total of five millions.
Gold.
See <Eacute/tui.
The European green woodpecker; -- also called ecall, eaquall, yaffle.
See Gypsum.
The cormorant.
Formerly, an upper servant, or household officer, who set on and removed the dishes at a feast, and who also brought water for the hands of the guests.
A person or thing that moves, stirs, or changes place.
A farewell; commendation to the care of God at parting.
The weight by which precious stones and pearls are weighed.
A very thin, slight, transparent stuff, generally of silk; also, any fabric resembling silk gauze; as, wire gauze; cotton gauze.
A name given to several malvaceous trees (species of Hibiscus, Ochroma, etc.), and to their strong fibrous inner bark, which is used for strings and cordage.

A large water wheel, turned by the action of a stream against its floats, and carrying at its circumference buckets, by which water is raised and discharged into a trough; used in Arabia, China, and elsewhere for irrigating land; a Persian wheel.
A spiral-horned South African antelope (Tragelaphus angasi) with a fringe of white hairs along back and neck.
The way or fashion of people at any particular time; temporary mode, custom, or practice; popular reception for the time; -- used now generally in the phrase in vogue.

A black man; especially, one of a race of black or very dark persons who inhabit the greater part of tropical Africa, and are distinguished by crisped or curly hair, flat noses, and thick protruding lips; also, any black person of unmixed African blood, wherever found.
See Crewel.
A name for a negro.

A yellow or brownish red dyestuff obtained by the action of bromine on fluoresce<ium/n, and named from the fine rose-red which it imparts to silk. It is also used for making a fine red ink. Its solution is fluorescent.
A woman. See Feme, n.
An imaginary evil being among Eastern nations, which was supposed to feed upon human bodies.
A waistcoat or kind of stays for women.

Ordinary civilian dress when worn by persons who serve in a uniformed service, such as the military or police.  It originally was used in reference to British naval or military officers, and originated with the British service in India.
any elderly pompous reactionary.
A society or congregation; a church or religious body.
a country on the island of Hispaniola.
To call by a title; to name; to entitle.
The aggregate of the muscles, fat, and other tissues which cover the framework of bones in man and other animals; especially, the muscles.
See Keeve, n.
A treatise on forms of argument; a system or scheme of forms or commonplaces of argument or oratory; as, the Topics of Aristotle.
A goblin; a bugbear.
See Sourkrout.
Doctor of Philosophy, a British doctorate.
A boatman; an oarsman.
Leaf of lard.

An instrument consisting of a thin blade, usually of steel and having a sharp edge for cutting, fastened to a handle, but of many different forms and names for different uses; as, table knife, drawing knife, putty knife, pallet knife, pocketknife, penknife, chopping knife, etc..
Something peculiar to one's self.
a Philippine dish of marinated vegetables and meat or fish; served with rice.
A woman newly married, or about to be married.
To burn with a flame or blaze; to burn as gas emitted from bodies in combustion; to blaze.
A weight of twelve grains; or, according to some, of ten grains, or half a scruple.
That at which one aims; the thing or end to which the mind directs its view; that which is purposed to be reached or accomplished; hence, ultimate design, aim, or purpose; intention; drift; object.
To arrange or adjust the spaces in or between; as, to space words, lines, or letters.

Customary way of speaking or acting; custom; fashion; manner; behavior; mien; mode; practice; -- often used formerly in such phrases as: at his own guise; that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself.
See Pekoe.
See Pliers.

a unit of frequency equal to one cycle per second; it is abbreviated Hz.  It is commonly used to specify the frequency of radio waves, and also the clock frequencies in digital computers.  For these applications, kilohertz and megahertz are the most commonly used units, derived from hertz.
The white indris of Madagascar. It is regarded by the natives as sacred.
A band or organized company of singers, especially in church service.
An animal or plant which is much below the ordinary size of its species or kind.
Diarrhoea or dysentery among cattle.
The act of shooting; the discharge of a missile; a shot; as, the shoot of a shuttle.
Same as Vugg.
See Gige.
Furze. See Furze.
One who, or that which, lays.
A wandering; a vagary.
Same as kowtow, the more common spellings.
The wife of Balder.
A large South American goatsucker (Nyctibius grandis).
A kind of warm cap winter wear, made from a knit bag with closed tapered ends by pushing one end within the other, thus making a conical cap of double thickness.

A company of Irish herdsmen, or a single herdsman, wandering from place to place with flocks and herds, and living on their milk, like the Tartars; also, a place in the mountain pastures inclosed for the shelter of cattle or their keepers.
A pupil; a student.
The great cowslip (Primula veris, var. elatior).
See Spook.
The glandular organ in which milk is secreted and stored; -- popularly called the bag in cows and other quadrupeds. See Mamma.
Russia leather.
One who gapes.
A cutaneous disease; especially, the itch.
A description or history of the forest trees of a country.
One who teases or plagues.
See 1st Jeer (b).
A chip or fragment, especially a chip of stone as struck off the block by the hammer, having at least one feather-edge.
A tern; the sea swallow.
A transparent mucous discharge from the membrane of the urethra, commonly an effect of gonorrhea.
A unit of force equal to the force which, acting for one second, will give a pound a velocity of one foot per second; -- proposed by J. D. Everett, an English physicist.
The pewee.
That part of the integument of the head which is usually covered with hair.
A kind of waved silk, usually called watered silk, manufactured like taffeta, but thicker and stronger.  The watering is given to it by calendering.
The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet of paper; -- opposed to recto.
See Cider.
One that uses wings.
A ruby.
Originally, a brawling, turbulent, vexatious person of either sex, but now restricted in use to females; a brawler; a scold.
A stuffed jacket worn under the mail, or (later) a jacket plated with mail.
The rich, oily, and yellowish part of milk, which, when the milk stands unagitated, rises, and collects on the surface. It is the part of milk from which butter is obtained.
See Amends.
Intense hatred or dislike; loathing; abhorrence.
A pea.
A conical loaf of sugar.
The track or trail of any wild animal; as, the spoor of an elephant; -- used originally by travelers in South Africa.
One who rises; as, an early riser.
One who saves.
A Treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union which provided for stepwise reductions in the number of nuclear weapons possessed by each country.
The husks and other refuse of rice mills, used to adulterate oil cake, or linseed cake.
A woman of affected modesty, reserve, or coyness; one who is overscrupulous or sensitive; one who affects extraordinary prudence in conduct and speech.
Same as Sora.

The chiefly British equivalent of tuna; any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the Mackerel family, especially the common or great tunny (Thunnus thynnus syn. Albacora thynnus, formerly Orcynus thynnus) native of the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean.  It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is extensively caught in the Mediterranean.  On the American coast it is called horse mackerel. See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.

An ethereal salt, or compound ether, consisting of an organic radical united with the residue of any oxygen acid, organic or inorganic; thus the natural fats are esters of glycerin and the fatty acids, oleic, etc.
One of the pieces of sod used to line or cover parapets and the faces of earthworks.
A Roman measure of land, measuring 28,800 square feet, or 240 feet in length by 120 in breadth.
A thin, sour beer, made by pouring warm water on rye or barley meal and letting it ferment, -- much used by the Russians.
A petty contrivance; a toy; a plaything; a knickknack.
Manliness; dignity; comeliness; civility.
A piece of timber sawed thin, and of considerable length and breadth as compared with the thickness, -- used for building, etc.
A contorted knot in wood; a crossgrained protuberance; a nodule; a boss or projection.

The science and the art of tones, or musical sounds, i. e., sounds of higher or lower pitch, begotten of uniform and synchronous vibrations, as of a string at various degrees of tension; the science of harmonical tones which treats of the principles of harmony, or the properties, dependences, and relations of tones to each other; the art of combining tones in a manner to please the ear.
The dried tubers of various species of Orchis, and Eulophia. It is used to make a nutritious beverage by treating the powdered preparation with hot water.
nonsense; balderdash; humbug; -- usually used in the phrase a crock.
Exodus; withdrawal.
See Corf.
The bracteal covering of the flowers or seeds of grain and grasses; esp., an outer husk or bract of a spikelet.
See Ladykin.
A Linnaean genus of Quadrumana which included the types of numerous modern genera. By modern writers it is usually restricted to the genus which includes the orang-outang.
Same as Taxer, n., 2.
A blow; a stroke with something hard or heavy; a jar.
A stunted shrub, bush, or branch.
See Courche.

A sharp, brief, ringing sound, made by a collision of metallic or other sonorous bodies; -- usually expressing a duller or less resounding sound than clang, and a deeper and stronger sound than clink.
One who cheats or deceives.
A silly fellow; a ninny.

Any animal of the hog kind, especially one of the domestical species. Swine secrete a large amount of subcutaneous fat, which, when extracted, is known as lard. The male is specifically called boar, the female, sow, and the young, pig. See Hog.
One who gives or bestows; one who confers anything gratuitously; a benefactor.  Inverse of recipient.
The chambered sporogenous tissue forming the central mass of the sporophore in puff balls, stinkhorns, etc.
Same as Mazer.
One who makes, forms, or molds; a manufacturer; specifically, the Creator.
A sudden turn; a starting from the point or line; hence, an artful evasion or subterfuge; a shift; a quibble; as, the quirks of a pettifogger.
A collection of visible vapor, or watery particles, suspended in the upper atmosphere.
A tenth; a tenth part; a tithe.
One who hates.

A system of electronic navigation in which a vessel or aircraft determines its latitude and longitude by measuring the time differences between low frequency radio transmissions from two stationary transmitters (slaves) and a stationary master transmitter.  Contrary to the name, Loran is a medium range system, usually effective for no more than a few hundred miles from shore.  The first commercial system was called Loran A; the latest (and final) development is Loran C.
a magician or sorcerer of ancient times.
One who pukes, vomits.
A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U. S. standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons.
A narrow inlet of the sea, penetrating between high banks or rocks, as on the coasts of Norway and Alaska.
The settlings of oil, molasses, etc., at the bottom of a barrel or hogshead.
A kind of sage (Salvia Horminum).
An oblique direction; a line or direction including from a horizontal line or direction; also, sometimes, an inclination, as of one line or surface to another.

A structure appended to a larger edifice for a special purpose, as for a belfry, and then usually high in proportion to its width and to the height of the rest of the edifice; as, a church tower.
A genus of grasses, including the common oat (Avena sativa); the oat grasses.
any of various lithe-bodied round-headed fissiped mammals, many with retractile claws; a member of the Felidae.

One of a family (Lemurid<ae/) of nocturnal mammals allied to the monkeys, but of small size, and having a sharp and foxlike muzzle, and large eyes. They feed upon birds, insects, and fruit, and are mostly natives of Madagascar and the neighboring islands, one genus (Galago) occurring in Africa.  The slow lemur or kukang of the East Indies is Nycticebus tardigradus. See Galago, Indris, and Colugo.

An apparatus or machine by which any substance or body is pressed, squeezed, stamped, or shaped, or by which an impression of a body is taken; sometimes, the place or building containing a press or presses.

A bitch of the hound kind.

The act of granting; a bestowing or conferring; concession; allowance; permission.
Prussian leather.

A sweet white (or brownish yellow) crystalline substance, of a sandy or granular consistency, obtained by crystallizing the evaporated juice of certain plants, as the sugar cane, sorghum, beet root, sugar maple, etc. It is used for seasoning and preserving many kinds of food and drink. Ordinary sugar is essentially sucrose. See the Note below.
A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewel for personal adornment, or like.
A part or portion.

The sum or amount of money at which a thing is valued, or the value which a seller sets on his goods in market; that for which something is bought or sold, or offered for sale; equivalent in money or other means of exchange; current value or rate paid or demanded in market or in barter; cost.

Animal fat; lard.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied to other related species. See Bobwhite.

A native of the Caribbee islands or the coasts of the Caribbean sea; esp., one of a tribe of Indians inhabiting a region of South America, north of the Amazon, and formerly most of the West India islands.
See Lotus.
A prop or shore.
Composition paid by a debtor.

A kind of portable photographic camera, esp. adapted for snapshot work, in which a succession of negatives is made upon a continuous roll of sensitized film; -- originally a trademark name of the Eastman Kodak Company, but from early 1900's through the 1930's it was popularly applied to almost any hand camera.
A young chicken, partridge, grouse, or the like.
A kind of clerical scarf fitted to a collar; as, a black silk rabat.
A meteor or brilliant shooting star, followed by a train of light or sparks; esp. one which explodes.

A subordinary of triangular form having one of its angles at the fess point and the opposite side at the edge of the escutcheon.  When there is only one gyron on the shield it is bounded by two lines drawn from the fess point, one horizontally to the dexter side, and one to the dexter chief corner.
A solid whose bases or ends are any similar, equal, and parallel plane figures, and whose sides are parallelograms.
A gun, the inside of whose barrel is grooved with spiral channels, thus giving the ball a rotary motion and insuring greater accuracy of fire. As a military firearm it has superseded the musket.

A sort of cotton so short and fine that it can not be spun, used in the East Indies to line palanquins, to make mattresses, etc.
To stand at the flank or side of; to border upon.

Putage.
The electric catfish.

The territory governed by a ban.
The act of purging.
Furious; raging; extremely violent.
A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic; a carousal.

The sharp edge or salient angle formed by two surfaces meeting each other, whether plane or curved; -- applied particularly to the edges in moldings, and to the raised edges which separate the flutings in a Doric column.
an outstanding example of its kind; as, when I make a mistake it's a beaut.

A genus of mosquitoes of the family Culicidae, to which most of the North American species belong.  Some members of this genus are exceedingly annoying, as Culex sollicitans, which breeds in enormous numbers in the salt marshes of the Atlantic coast, and Culex pipiens, the common house mosquito, breeding very widely in the fresh waters of North America. (For characters distinguishing these from the malaria mosquitoes, see Anopheles, above).  The yellow-fever mosquito is now placed in another genus, Stegomyia.
To disguise or conceal; to deceive or delude.

A hoofed quadruped of the genus Equus; especially, the domestic horse (Equus caballus), which was domesticated in Egypt and Asia at a very early period.  It has six broad molars, on each side of each jaw, with six incisors, and two canine teeth, both above and below. The mares usually have the canine teeth rudimentary or wanting. The horse differs from the true asses, in having a long, flowing mane, and the tail bushy to the base. Unlike the asses it has callosities, or chestnuts, on all its legs. The horse excels in strength, speed, docility, courage, and nobleness of character, and is used for drawing, carrying, bearing a rider, and like purposes.
The oat; oats.
A variety of the chamois found in the Pyrenees.
One who works as a mason without having served a regular apprenticeship.
The oyster catcher.
An effort to raise something, as a weight, or one's self, or to move something heavy.

The seventh month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering to a part of September with a part of October.

The small, spicy berry of a species of pepper (Piper Cubeba; in (Med.), Cubeba officinalis), native in Java and Borneo, but now cultivated in various tropical countries.  The dried unripe fruit is much used in medicine as a stimulant and purgative.
The blue buck.
Wine, -- chiefly used in Pharmacy in the name of solutions of some medicinal substance in wine; as: vina medicata, medicated wines; vinum opii, wine of opium.
A silver coin of about 86 grains, having the figure of an archer, and hence, in modern times, called a daric.

The unit of electric induction; the induction in a circuit when the electro-motive force induced in this circuit is one volt, while the inducing current varies at the rate of one amp<egrave/re a second.

A mill.
A funeral song; an elegy.
A Southern Asiatic species of wild cattle (Bibos frontalis).
Place, or spot, in general.
Lit., King of Heaven; -- a title of the emperor of Japan as the head of the Shinto religion.
A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork; sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble in alcohol.
A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornblende) in the walls of tin and copper lodes.
See Gonys.
An embankment to prevent inundation; as, the levees along the Mississippi; sometimes, the steep bank of a river.
One who muses.
A river flood; an overflow or inundation.
In the Orkney and Shetland Islands, beef and mutton hung and dried, but not salted.

A well-known edible berry growing in pendent clusters or bunches on the grapevine. The berries are smooth-skinned, have a juicy pulp, and are cultivated in great quantities for table use and for making wine and raisins.
A collection of huts within a stockade; a village; sometimes, a single hut.
Boisterous weather.
A long cut; a cut made at random.
A support or supporter; a stay; a prop.
A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; hence, a lady's flat workbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba.
That which is held as an opinion; a tenet; a doctrine.
An apparatus resembling a Jacquard for weaving small figures (usually about 12 - 16 threads, seldom more than 36 - 40 threads).
That one of the four cardinal points directly opposite to the north; the region or direction to the right or direction to the right of a person who faces the east.
A slope; the inclination of the face of a work.

To sound as a knell; especially, to toll at a death or funeral; hence, to sound as a warning or evil omen.
A sandpiper (Terekia cinerea) of the Old World, breeding in the far north of eastern Europe and Asia and migrating to South Africa and Australia. It frequents rivers.

A blow; whack.
A distinctive mark, token, sign, or cognizance, worn on the person; as, the badge of a society; the badge of a policeman.

An ill-conditioned, ill-fed, or neglected horse; also, a person in a like condition.

English gin.

A kind of heavy colored fabric, either all silk, or silk and worsted, or silk and cotton, often called terry velvet, used for upholstery and trimmings.

That which is crisp or brittle; the state of being crisp or brittle; as, burned to a crisp; specifically, the rind of roasted pork; crackling.
An inclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building, or by different building; also, a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.

A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaves have a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad and antiscorbutic.

Any one of several species of small lemurs of the genus Stenops.  They have long, slender limbs and large eyes, and are arboreal in their habits.  The slender loris (Stenops gracilis), of Ceylon, in one of the best known species.

A genus of composite plants, of which one species (Madia sativa) is cultivated for the oil yielded from its seeds by pressure.  This oil is sometimes used instead of olive oil for the table.
That which, issuing from a body, affects the olfactory organs of animals; odor; smell; as, the scent of an orange, or of a rose; the scent of musk.

To put off; to defer; to procrastinate; to prolong the time of or before.
A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomach by gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany; bloating.
A coating or covering resembling ice, as of sugar and milk or white of egg; frosting.

The material obtained by untwisting and picking into loose fiber old hemp ropes; -- used for calking the seams of ships, stopping leaks, etc.
A large, closed, four-wheeled carriage, having doors in the sides, and generally a front and back seat inside, each for two persons, and an elevated outside seat in front for the driver.
To spot; to streak or stripe; to variegate; to dapple.

In Mexico and the southwestern United States, a kind of plastered house or hut, usually made by planting poles or timber in the ground, filling in between them with screen work or wickerwork, and daubing one or both sides with mud or adobe mortar; also, this method of construction.

Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors of electricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether, alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin (see Rosin).

The inner bark of plants, lying next to the wood. It usually contains a large proportion of woody, fibrous cells, and is, therefore, the part from which the fiber of the plant is obtained, as that of hemp, etc.

An order or subclass of cryptogamous plants; the mosses. See Moss, and Cryptogamia.
A West African gazelle (Gazella redunca).
A public square in a city or town.
A rod or staff, carried as an emblem of authority; as, the verge, carried before a dean.
