a genus of broad-winged soaring hawks.
A naevus.
The members of the national, or king's, council which sat to assist the king in administrative and judicial matters; also, the council.
A foreigner; one owing allegiance, or belonging, to another country; a foreign-born resident of a country in which he does not possess the privileges of a citizen. Hence, a stranger. See Alienage.
A mimeograph.
A bottomless or unfathomed depth, gulf, or chasm; hence, any deep, immeasurable, and, specifically, hell, or the bottomless pit.

Ability to act, regarded as latent or inherent; the faculty of doing or performing something; capacity for action or performance; capability of producing an effect, whether physical or moral: potency; might; as, a man of great power; the power of capillary attraction; money gives power.
See Prize, n., 5. Also Prize, v. t.
Same as Thuja.
See Ajouan.
The ace of clubs in quadrille and omber.
A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age.
A small variety of the Lima bean (Phaseolus lunatus).
A snipe.
One who tames or subdues.
The nest of a bird of prey, as of an eagle or hawk; also a brood of such birds; eyrie. Shak. Also fig.: A human residence or resting place perched like an eagle's nest.
A place of shelter for cattle.
The East Indian leguminous tree Butea frondosa. See Gum Butea, under Gum.
An impure, massive, flintlike quartz or hornstone, of a dull color.
The south wind.
The hydrocarbon radical, CH3.C6H4, regarded as characteristic of certain compounds of the aromatic series related to toluene; as, tolyl carbinol.
One who wooes; one who courts or solicits in love; a suitor.
the Jewish rite of circumcision.
A jest.
Originally, a kind of ruffle worn by men on the bosom of the shirt.
A spy; a scout.
A thin plate of metal.
A fine or penalty, esp. a pecuniary punishment or penalty.
The act of touching, or the state of being touched; contact.
A liquid measure in various countries of Europe. The Dutch anker, formerly also used in England, contained about 10 of the old wine gallons, or 8<frac12/ imperial gallons.
a large tropical American tree (Cordia alliodora) grown for its abundant creamy white flowers and valuable wood.
The fruit of the olive.  It has been much improved by cultivation, and is used for making pickles.  Olive oil is pressed from its flesh.
One who ogles.
Same as Rani.
A tyrant.
Act of seizing; a grasp.
One of the flutings of a column.
The quality or principle of plants or other substances which constitutes their fragrance; agreeable odor; as, the aroma of coffee.
Ninepins. See Kayles.
Paralysis, complete or partial. See Paralysis.

A small Asiatic mammal (Ailurus fulgens) having fine soft fur, which inhabits the mountains of Northern India.  It was once thought to be related to the bears, but is now believed to be more closely related to raccoons.  It has reddish-brown fur on the back and sides, and black fur on the legs and underside.  Called also the lesser panda.
A pommel.
Any one of numerous species of elasmobranch fishes of the order Plagiostomi, found in all seas.
A piece of armor for the thighs, forming an appendage to the ancient corselet.
Violent contest or striving.
Any sac or saclike cavity; especially, one of the synovial sacs, or small spaces, often lined with synovial membrane, interposed between tendons and bony prominences.
Anything done; a deed; an action good or bad; hence, in the plural, conduct; behavior. See Do.

A South American ruminant (Auchenia llama), allied to the camels, but much smaller and without a hump. It is supposed to be a domesticated variety of the guanaco. It was formerly much used as a beast of burden in the Andes, and is also kept on some ranches in the United States.
An annoyer.
A native, or permanent resident, of Rome; a citizen of Rome, or one upon whom certain rights and privileges of a Roman citizen were conferred.
A small discolored place in or on anything, or a small place of a color different from that of the main substance; a spot; a stain; a blemish; as, a speck on paper or loth; specks of decay in fruit.
Baryta.
See Deckle.
A gridiron.
Myopia.
Five hundred; as, a mease of herrings.

A natural and healthy, but temporary and periodical, suspension of the functions of the organs of sense, as well as of those of the voluntary and rational soul; that state of the animal in which there is a lessened acuteness of sensory perception, a confusion of ideas, and a loss of mental control, followed by a more or less unconscious state.
A salt glaze on pottery, made by adding common salt to an earthenware glaze.
A fish allied to the turbot (Rhombus levis), much esteemed in England for food; -- called also bret, pearl, prill. See Bret.
A lighted coal, smoldering amid ashes; -- used chiefly in the plural, to signify mingled coals and ashes; the smoldering remains of a fire.
One who owls; esp., one who conveys contraband goods. See Owling, n.
That which is quick, or alive; a living animal or plant; especially, the hawthorn, or other plants used in making a living hedge.
A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems and whorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
Same as Kaffir.
Liberty granted by which restraint or illegality is removed; permission; allowance; license.
A woody plant of less size than a tree, and usually with several stems from the same root.
A match for firing a charge of powder, as in blasting; a fuse.
Something thin, lean, or rough; a bony piece; especially, a bony neckpiece of meat; hence, humorously or in contempt, the neck.
To mark with, or as with, botches.

A device which produces an intense, usually narrow, monochromatic beam of coherent light; called also optical maser.  It has various forms, and is used in various applications in science and technology.  The beam is produced by boosting the majority of the electrons in specific radiation-absorbing atoms in a medium into a higher energy level, from which they are stimulated by their own emitted radiation to drop back synchronously to their lower energy level, and emit light which is in phase (coherent).
A silver coin, and money of account, in the East Indies.
A shallow wooden vessel for holding milk or cream.
See Dammar.
See Muzzle.
Consumption; phthisis. See Phthisis.
One who, or that which, imparts motion; a source of mechanical power.
The area in the central part of an amphitheater, in which the gladiators fought and other shows were exhibited; -- so called because it was covered with sand.
Information; advice.
A comedian.
A hydro-a<eum/roplane.
See Kurd.
A sweetheart, of either sex; a gallant, or a mistress; -- usually in a bad sense.
The deity who assigns to every man his lot.
A fragment or part of anything separated from the whole, in any manner, as by cutting, splitting, breaking, or tearing; a part; a portion; as, a piece of sugar; to break in pieces.
A kind of script in which the heavy strokes are nearly upright, giving the characters when taken together a round look.
Tincture; hue; color; tinge.

The European shad (Alosa alosa formerly Clupea alosa); -- called also allice shad or allis shad. The name is sometimes applied to the American shad (Alosa sapidissima formerly Clupea sapidissima). See Shad.
Shape; build; form of structure; as, the built of a ship.
A living body or its bulk.

A Latin deity represented with two faces looking in opposite directions. Numa is said to have dedicated to Janus the covered passage at Rome, near the Forum, which is usually called the Temple of Janus. This passage was open in war and closed in peace.
A composition adapted to sacred words in the elaborate polyphonic church style; an anthem.
A flat fold; a doubling, as of cloth; a pleat; as, a box plait.
The orange-colored pulp covering the seeds of the tropical plant Bixa Orellana, from which annotto is prepared. See Annoto.
A walk or passage; -- applied to passages of various kinds.
Ghost; spirit.
an illicitly distilled (and usually inferior) alcoholic liquor.

A large Asiatic antelope (Budorcas taxicolor) native of the higher parts of the Himalayas and other lofty mountains. Its head and neck resemble those of the ox, and its tail is like that of the goat. Called also budorcas.
See Rattan.
That which is destitute of light or whiteness; the darkest color, or rather a destitution of all color; as, a cloth has a good black.
A genus of carnivorous mammals, of the family Canid<ae/, including the dogs and wolves.
See Crare.
The call of a hen to her chickens.
A shot in which the ball struck with the cue comes in contact with two or more balls on the table; a hitting of two or more balls with the player's ball. In England it is called cannon.
Wild oats, or darnel grass. See Drake a plant.
Flexible wood worked into the top of hedge stakes, to bind them together.
That which cores; an instrument for coring fruit; as, an apple corer.

A piece of timber laid horizontally, or nearly so, to which the planks of the floor, or the laths or furring strips of a ceiling, are nailed; -- called, according to its position or use, binding joist, bridging joist, ceiling joist, trimming joist, etc. See Illust. of Double-framed floor, under Double, a.
The sandpiper.
A pantry.
Curved arms of timber or iron, projecting over a ship's side of stern, having tackle to raise or lower a boat, swing it in on deck, rig it out for lowering, etc.; -- called also boat davits.
Any eared seal.
A young salmon two or three years old, when it has acquired its silvery color.
A California surf-fish (Rhacochilus toxotes); -- called also alfione, and perch.
A savory meat jelly containing portions of fowl, game, fish, hard boiled eggs, etc.
One who comes, or who has come; one who has arrived, and is present.
One who plays on a pipe, or the like, esp. on a bagpipe.
A Cretan
The dried hemp plant, used in India for smoking. It is extremely narcotic and intoxicating.
The act of expiring; passage from life to death; loss of life.
An administrative subdivision of a fu, or department, or of an independent chow; also, the seat of government of such a district.
The tolling of a bell; a knell.
someone mentally deranged and possibly dangerous.
To resolve into its elements, as a sentence, pointing out the several parts of speech, and their relation to each other by government or agreement; to analyze and describe grammatically.
A warding off of a thrust or blow, as in sword and bayonet exercises or in boxing; hence, figuratively, a defensive movement in debate or other intellectual encounter.
Master; lord; teacher; -- a Jewish title of respect or honor for a teacher or doctor of the law.
See Edentata.
Dearth; scarcity.
A view; especially, a view through or between intervening objects, as trees; a view or prospect through an avenue, or the like; hence, the trees or other objects that form the avenue.
A question; an inquiry to be answered or solved.
Direct management of public finance or public works by agents of the government for government account; -- opposed to the contract system.
The position of a vessel riding at single anchor and swinging clear of it.

A large ruminant used in Asia and Africa for carrying burdens and for riding.  The camel is remarkable for its ability to go a long time without drinking.  Its hoofs are small, and situated at the extremities of the toes, and the weight of the animal rests on the callous. The dromedary (Camelus dromedarius) has one hump on the back, while the Bactrian camel (Camelus Bactrianus) has two.  The llama, alpaca, and vicu<ntil/a, of South America, belong to a related genus (Auchenia).
A monster capable of assuming a woman's form, who was said to devour human beings or suck their blood; a vampire; a sorceress; a witch.
See 1st Char.
A bottle or vessel; esp., a vial or small glass bottle for holding vinegar, oil, pepper, or the like, for the table; a caster.
The state of being foolish; want of good sense; levity, weakness, or derangement of mind.
A tribe of American Indians including many of the Pueblos of New Mexico and adjacent regions.
The Patriarch, or head of the Abyssinian Church.
See Arrish.
Grog.
A slanting direction or plane; a slope; as, it lies on a slant.
Also (perhaps from confusion with alley), a passage into which the pews of a church open.
A definite summary of what is believed; esp., a summary of the articles of Christian faith; a confession of faith for public use; esp., one which is brief and comprehensive.

A viscid fluid secreted by mucous membranes, which it serves to moisten and protect. It covers the lining membranes of all the cavities which open externally, such as those of the mouth, nose, lungs, intestinal canal, urinary passages, etc.
A water nymph; one of the lower female divinities, fabled to preside over some body of fresh water, as a lake, river, brook, or fountain.
Same as papaya, senses 1 and 2.
See Schorl.
The parts of a piece of house furniture, as a bedstead, packed together.

The god of eloquence and letters among the ancient Egyptians, and supposed to be the inventor of writing and philosophy. He corresponded to the Mercury of the Romans, and was usually represented as a human figure with the head of an ibis or a lamb.
A pen or inclosure of stakes and hurdles on the seacoast, for holding fish.
See Copse.
A stream or spring of fresh water.
a friction match with a large head that will stay alight in the wind.
A brisk, showy, gay man.
A battle or tumult; encounter; combat; disturbance; passion.
A belt or girdle which the Christians and Jews of the Levant were obliged to wear to distinguish them from Mohammedans.

Any lizard of the family Geckonid<ae/.  The geckoes are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and vertical, elliptical pupils.  Their toes are generally expanded, and furnished with adhesive disks, by which they can run over walls and ceilings.  They are numerous in warm countries, and a few species are found in Europe and the United States. See Wall gecko, Fanfoot.
A square or oblong cloth of wool, cotton, silk, or other textile or netted fabric, used, especially by women, as a loose covering for the neck and shoulders.

A very heavy, inert gaseous element of the noble gas group, occurring in the atmosphere in the proportion of one volume is about 20 millions.  It was discovered by Ramsay and Travers in 1898.  It can be condensed to a liquid boiling at -107<deg/ C., and to a solid which melts at -111.9<deg/ C.  Symbol Xe (formerly also X); atomic number 54; atomic weight 131.3.

A tropical tree, or its fruit, of the genus Psidium.  Two varieties are well known, the P. pyriferum, or white guava, and P. pomiferum, or red guava.  The fruit or berry is shaped like a pomegranate, but is much smaller. It is somewhat astringent, but makes a delicious jelly.

A commercial weight varying in different countries and for different commodities. In Borneo it is 135<frac58/ lbs.; in China and Sumatra, 133<frac12/ lbs.; in Japan, 133<frac13/ lbs.; but sometimes 130 lbs., etc. Called also, by the Chinese, tan.
A machine formerly employed for reducing dislocations of the humerus.
An old saying, which has obtained credit by long use; a proverb.
A sudden breaking forth; a violent rending; an explosion; as, a burst of thunder; a burst of applause; a burst of passion; a burst of inspiration.
To turn from a straight line; to bend; to curve.
The act of drawing; also, the thing drawn. Same as Draught.
See Nouch.
A piece of a slender branch or twig cut for grafting.
A low, thorny, suffrutescent, crucifeous plant (Zilla myagroides) found in the deserts of Egypt. Its leaves are boiled in water, and eaten, by the Arabs.
An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiary ridge between two mountain gorges.

A fruit consisting of pulpy, coriaceous, or fibrous exocarp, without valves, containing a nut or stone with a kernel. The exocarp is succulent in the plum, cherry, apricot, peach, etc.; dry and subcoriaceous in the almond; and fibrous in the cocoanut.
The coarse part of flax or hemp; hards.
Shining; bright; resplendent; as, the lucid orbs of heaven.
A primitive word, from which spring other words; a radical; a root; an etymon.
The earth; earth.
A woman who practices unlawful sexual commerce with men, especially one who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; a harlot.
discrimination against middle-aged and elderly people.
A person of the Mongolian race.
To give a point to; to sharpen; to cut, forge, grind, or file to an acute end; as, to point a dart, or a pencil. Used also figuratively; as, to point a moral.
A skeleton.
Same as Inkle.
An apothecium in certain lichens, having a spherical surface marked with spiral or concentric ridges and furrows.
A deputy or viceroy in India; a governor of a province of the ancient Mogul empire.
A tree, as distinguished from a shrub.
Comic, farcical.
A piece of leather crossing the breast, used by the men who drag sledges in coal mines.
Cleaning; afterbirth.
The act of hurrying in motion or business; pressure; urgency; bustle; confusion.
A limehound; a limmer.
See Alma mater, Dura mater, and Pia mater.
A tract of land used for grazing and the rearing of horses, cattle, or sheep. See Rancho, 2.
Half-roasted ore.
Sarsaparilla.
A shoot or sprout from the ground.
Customs; habits; esp., moral customs conformity to which is more or less obligatory; customary law.
Hail or snow, mingled with rain, usually falling, or driven by the wind, in fine particles.
A twig of a tree cut off.
A cow or calf; -- familiarly so called.
A kind of wig.
The act of one who climbs; ascent by climbing.
A step or degree in any series, rank, quality, order; relative position or standing; as, grades of military rank; crimes of every grade; grades of flour.
A low-lying meadow by the side of a river.
An eye, bud, or shoot, as of a plant; an oilet.
a student during his first year in a high school, college, or university; a freshman.
A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes; also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by the cleavage of an albumose.
A quantity; a goodly number.
A blockhead; a dolt; a fool.
A salutation or compliment of ceremony in the east by word or act; an obeisance, performed by bowing very low and placing the right palm on the forehead.
Small particles of ore.
See water buck, under 3d Buck.
See Apsis.

An association of men belonging to the same class, or engaged in kindred pursuits, formed for mutual aid and protection; a business fraternity or corporation; as, the Stationers' Guild; the Ironmongers' Guild. They were originally licensed by the government, and endowed with special privileges and authority.
A child's name for mamma, mother.
Same as Palea.
The American badger.
A kind of candy made of molasses or brown sugar boiled down and poured out in shallow pans.
A sieve.
A plant of the genus Geum, of the rose family, esp. Geum urbanum, or herb bennet.  They may bear red, yellow, or white flowers.
The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant. See Curassow.
A deity corresponding to Odin, the supreme deity of the Scandinavians.  Wednesday is named for him.  See Odin.
Gold and silver, or money.
A house for entertaining strangers or travelers; an inn or public house, of the better class.
The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abode of the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world; the grave.
A genus of herbaceous plants including the flax (Linum usitatissimum).
A toll. See Soc, n., 2.
A drink composed of spirit (usually gin) and water sweetened.
pl. of Shoe.
An iron block, usually with a steel face, upon which metals are hammered and shaped.
A short wooden club having a deeply concave face, seldom used.
A red coloring matter. extracted from the Bignonia Chica, used by some tribes of South American Indians to stain the skin.
The hinge of a bivalve shell.
A flat-floored fishing boat with a lug sail, and a drop rudder extending from two to four feet below the keel. It was originally used on the stormy coast of Yorkshire, England.
See Dun crow, under Dun, a.
See Muset.
See Quaver.
The doctrine or creed of a deist; the belief or system of those who acknowledge the existence of one God, but deny revelation.
The act of demitting; also, a letter, certificate, or the like, certifying that a person has (honorably) demitted, as from a Masonic lodge.
A messenger.
Love; affection.
A genus of coniferous trees, properly called Fir, as the balsam fir and the silver fir. The spruces are sometimes also referred to this genus.
A dryad.
Inward sense; mind; understanding; conscience.

Anything that is quilted; esp., a quilted bed cover, or a skirt worn by women; any cover or garment made by putting wool, cotton, etc., between two cloths and stitching them together; also, any outer bed cover.
A shekel.
Any member of three species of African wild horses remarkable for having the body white or yellowish white, and conspicuously marked with dark brown or brackish bands.
See dickey.
The carved work under the quarter piece at the aft part of the quarter gallery.
Something in addition to what is due, expected, or customary; esp., an added charge or fee, or something for which an additional charge is made; as, at some hotels air conditioning is an extra.
The receiving of stolen goods, or harboring an outlaw.
Poke (Phytolacca decandra).
The country of Arabia.
A short, sharp note, as of a bird or insect.
The chick-pea.
A genus of parasitic insects including the fleas. See Flea.
See Coil.
A leap; an elastic spring; a jump.
Same as Doorga.

A fragrant gum resin obtained chiefly from tropical trees of the genera Amyris and Canarium. Amyris elemifera yields Mexican elemi; Canarium commune, the Manila elemi. It is used in the manufacture of varnishes, also in ointments and plasters.
Cleared land; land suitable for tillage or pasture; cultivated ground; the open country.
The kidneys; also, the region of the kidneys; the loins.
To fix the mind closely upon a subject; to dwell upon anything in thought; to muse; to ponder.
See Agendum.
The eyelashes.
The act of grazing; the cropping of grass.
The armpit; also, the arm.
Same as Pixy.
A number of foxes together.
A disease of the scalp, produced by a vegetable parasite.
A modal auxiliary.
Nitroglycerin.
One of a series of isonitroso derivatives obtained by the action of hydroxylamine on aldehydes or ketones.
See Umber.

The accentual mark placed over n, and sometimes over l, in Spanish words [thus, <ntil/, <ltil/], indicating that, in pronunciation, the sound of the following vowel is to be preceded by that of the initial, or consonantal, y.
A wandering troop or gang; especially, a clan or tribe of a nomadic people migrating from place to place for the sake of pasturage, plunder, etc.; a predatory multitude.
Defensive armor for the thighs.
an object having the shape of the capital <DELTA/.
A salmon in its second year.
A tocsin.
See Vizier.
Craziness; insanity.
The daisy, or mountain daisy.
The process of soaking through anything.
A book.
The kinkajou.
Tin ore freed from earthy matter by stamping.
A magistrate; one of a body of five magistrates chosen by the people of ancient Sparta. They exercised control even over the king.
The Mikania Guaco, of Brazil, used for the same purpose.
The eleventh month of the ancient Hebrew year, approximately corresponding with February.
One of a Malayan race, mainly of central Luzon, next to the Visayans the most numerous of the native peoples of the Philippines. Nearly all are Christians and many are highly educated.
The human body, whether living or dead.
See Didymium.
Same as Hindoo.  This is now the more commonly used spelling.
The round hole in the furnace of a glass manufactory through which the fused glass is taken out.
Negligence or fault, as distinguishable from dolus (deceit, fraud), which implies intent, culpa being imputable to defect of intellect, dolus to defect of heart.
A thin, single-cut file for combmakers.
See Loach.
The ermine in its summer pelage, when it is reddish brown, but with a black tip to the tail. The name is sometimes applied also to other brown weasels.
A screed; a shred; a fragment.
One who loses; as, the loser pays for a round of beer.
A piece of metal in the form of a coin, struck with a device, and intended to preserve the remembrance of a notable event or an illustrious person, or to serve as a reward.
The chigoe.
See Bairn.
One whose practice it is to raise mirth by odd tricks; a jester; a buffoon; a merry-andrew.
Having the rank, pungent, offensive odor and taste which substances of organic origin acquire during warm, moist weather; foul or sour and fetid; moldy; as, musty corn; musty books.
A regular soldier of the Turkish army. See Army organization, above.
A stripe of color.
Tapestry; a rich figured fabric; especially, a screen or hangings of heavy cloth with interwoven figures.
Something annexed or appended; as, an additional stipulation to a writing, a subsidiary building to a main building; a wing.
See Argol.
A game of chance, in which four sea shells, each called a prop, are used instead of dice.
A crossbow. See Prod, 3.
Grieved for the loss of some good; pained for some evil; feeling regret; -- now generally used to express light grief or affliction, but formerly often used to express deeper feeling.
A shrew.
A region or tract of land; esp., the open field, thinly forested or with bushes and shrubs; grass country.
That which is seized by violence or obtained by robbery, especially collective spoil taken in war; plunder; pillage.
A female foal or colt; a young mare.  Cf. Colt, Foal.
Same as Genius{1}.
The third letter (<GAMMA/, <gamma/ = Eng. G) of the Greek alphabet.
An Eskimo.
A gunlock.
The small or slender part of a thing; as, the small of the leg or of the back.
a Russian soup usually containing beet juice as a foundation, and often served with sour cream.  Also, as used in the U.S., a sour cabbage soup, called in Russian shchi.

The finely ground meal of wheat, or of any other grain; especially, the finer part of meal separated by bolting; hence, the fine and soft powder of any substance; as, flour of emery; flour of mustard.
An old English game; -- called also lawn billiards.

Any one of numerous species of ten-armed cephalopods having a long, tapered body, and a caudal fin on each side; especially, any species of Loligo, Ommastrephes, and related genera. See Calamary, Decacerata, Dibranchiata.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part of British America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson's Bay.
Belief; the assent of the mind to the truth of what is declared by another, resting solely and implicitly on his authority and veracity; reliance on testimony.

One of several swimming birds or divers, of the genus Colymbus (formerly Podiceps), and allied genera, found in the northern parts of America, Europe, and Asia. They have strong, sharp bills, and lobate toes.
An old English silver coin, equal to four pence.
A kind of snuff prepared by the natives of Venezuela from the roasted seeds of a leguminous tree (Piptadenia peregrina), thence called niopo tree.
See Fane.
A solution; an explanation.
See Jet.
A strap of leather; especially, one used for fastening anything.
A shoemaker's awl.
Jelly.
A tool used by coopers for smoothing and chamfering rheir work, especially the inside of casks.
A boomerang.

The crested screamer of Brazil (Palamedea chavaria syn. Chauna chavaria), so called in imitation of its notes; -- called also chauna, and faithful kamichi. It is often domesticated and is useful in guarding other poultry. See Kamichi.
Anger; wrath; scorn.
The Arabian name of two trees of the genus Balsamodendron, which yield a gum resin and a red aromatic wood.
A genus of trees, some species of which produce edible fruit; the mulberry. See Mulberry.
One who lives by shifts and tricks; one who avoids the performance of duty or labor.
See Zocco.
A plant of the genus Ajuga of the Mint family, a native of the Old World.

One not inferior or superior to another; one having the same or a similar age, rank, station, office, talents, strength, or other quality or condition; an equal quantity or number; as, <ldquo/If equals be taken from equals the remainders are equal.<rdquo/
Father.
A person who performs in a mime.
A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise, as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc.
A horizontal working forming one of a series, the working faces of which present the appearance of a flight of steps.
A spot or stain; also, a trick.
A red amorphous powder consisting of ferric oxide.  It is used in polishing glass, metal, or gems, and as a cosmetic, etc. Called also crocus, jeweler's rouge, etc.
A buffoon or merry-andrew; one that practices odd gesticulations; the Fool of the old play.
Any void space; a void space on paper, or in any written instrument; an interval void of consciousness, action, result, etc; a void.
The place where the meetings of the senate were held; the senate house.
See Crus.
A false die. See Gord.
Trifles; jests.
A representation of the dead Christ, attended by the Virgin Mary or by holy women and angels.
The namaycush.
Connection; tie.
A paved yard or floor where ores are cleaned and sorted, or where ore, salt, mercury, etc., are trampled by horses, to effect intermixture and amalgamation.
A thin watery fluid, containing more or less albumin, secreted by the serous membranes of the body, such as the pericardium and peritoneum.
Progressive emaciation of the body, accompanied with hectic fever, with no well-marked local symptoms.
An arrest; a legal seizure.
an artificial computer language with a relatively simplified instruction set.
A sudden or irregular incursion in border warfare; hence, any irregular incursion for war or spoils; a raid.
See Croaker, n., 2. (a).
The seed of plants.
A coarse or stupid fellow.
A box; a pyx.

A Slavic tribe which once occupied the northern and eastern parts of Germany, of which a small remnant exists.
A feast or festival; -- called also gaud-day and gaudy day.

The hedge sparrow.

A white (caucasian) person; -- a term used by some African-Americans, intended to be disparaging and often taken as offensive.
A statement; also, a document containing a statement.
A vial.
Want of tone; weakness of the system, or of any organ, especially of such as are contractile.

To assign a place to; to put in a particular spot or place, or in a certain relative position; to direct to a particular place; to fix; to settle; to locate; as, to place a book on a shelf; to place balls in tennis.

An oblong rectangular piece of cloth, worn by Roman ladies, and fastened with brooches.

A species of hickory (Carya oliv<ae/formis), growing in North America, chiefly in the Mississippi valley and in Texas, where it is one of the largest of forest trees; also, its fruit, a smooth, oblong nut, an inch or an inch and a half long, with a thin shell and well-flavored meat.
A small writing, certificate, or schedule; a piece of paper containing a writing.
Rate of exchange; also, the discount on uncurrent coins.
A push from behind, as to one who is endeavoring to climb; help.
A rustic; a countryman or laborer.
A simpleton.

A letter of the Greek alphabet corresponding to th in English; -- sometimes called the unlucky letter, from being used by the judges on their ballots in passing condemnation on a prisoner, it being the first letter of the Greek qa`natos, death.

in Irish legend, chief god of the Tuatha De Danann; father of Angus Og and Brigit.

a cravat with wide square ends, tied so that the ends are laid flat; the ends are often secured with an ornamental pin; -- called cravat in Britain.

The cheek bone, which forms a part of the lower edge of the orbit; that arch of bone beneath the eye that forms the prominence of the cheek; also called the malar bone.

The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
A British Indian gold coin, of the value of fifteen silver rupees, or $7.21 (in 1913).
An anglo-Saxon copper coin of the lowest value, being worth half a farthing.
A quantity of the stalks and ears of wheat, rye, or other grain, bound together; a bundle of grain or straw.
a genus of bivalve mollusks consisting of razor clams.
A friar.
A small owl; especially, the European species (Athene noctua), and the California flammulated owlet (Megascops flammeolus).
A fairy; a goblin; an elf.
An implement for digging or cutting the ground, consisting usually of an oblong and nearly rectangular blade of iron, with a handle like that of a shovel.

The young or embryo of a vertebrate animal in the womb, or in the egg; often restricted to the later stages in the development of viviparous and oviparous animals. showing the main recognizable features of the mature animal, embryo being applied to the earlier stages.
The European throstle or song thrush (Turdus musicus).
A missile weapon of offense, slender, pointed, and usually feathered and barbed, to be shot from a bow.
Full extent; distance between extreme limits; especially; the distance between the nearest surfaces of two bodies, or the space between walls; as, a room ten feet square in the clear.
The pungent grayish green flower bud of the European and Oriental caper (Capparis spinosa), much used for pickles.

any of various species of Dammara; as, the red kauri (Dammara lanceolata).
Sound of any kind.

A stump of a tree.

Liver of sulphur; a substance of a liver-brown color, sometimes used in medicine. It is formed by fusing sulphur with carbonates of the alkalies (esp. potassium), and consists essentially of alkaline sulphides. Called also hepar sulphuris (<?/).
A genus of composite plants (Buphthalmum) with large yellow flowers.
The California poison oak (Rhus diversiloba).  See under Poison, a.
A seal; a signature.
A loud noise resulting from collision; a noisy collision of bodies; a collision.
A spirit, or immaterial being, holding a middle place between men and deities in pagan mythology.

A milky or colored juice in certain plants in cavities (called latex cells or latex tubes). It contains the peculiar principles of the plants, whether aromatic, bitter, or acid, and in many instances yields caoutchouc upon coagulation.  The lattex of the India rubber plant produces the rubber of commerce on coagulation.
A shelf on which articles may be laid; also, that which resembles such a shelf in form or use, as a projecting ridge or part, or a molding or edge in joinery.
A cactaceous plant (Nopalea cochinellifera), originally Mexican, on which the cochineal insect feeds, and from which it is collected.  The name is sometimes given to other species of Cactaceae.
A pole; a long staff; a rod; esp., a pole or other support for fowls to roost on or to rest on; a roost; figuratively, any elevated resting place or seat.
Scythe.

A cordial of brandy, etc., flavored with the kernel of the bitter almond, or of the peach stone, etc.
Soil; tarnish; stain.

Estimation; valuation.
A small shield, especially one of an approximately elliptic form, or crescent-shaped.

Any one of several species of large wading birds of the family Ciconidae, having long legs and a long, pointed bill.  They are found both in the Old World and in America, and belong to Ciconia and several allied genera.  The European white stork (Ciconia alba) is the best known.  It commonly makes its nests on the top of a building, a chimney, a church spire, or a pillar.  The black stork (Ciconia nigra) is native of Asia, Africa, and Europe.
Reverence for animal life or belief in animal powers and influences, as among savages.
The answer to the theme (dux) in a fugue.
Wet, spongy land; soft, low ground saturated with water, but not usually covered with it; marshy ground away from the seashore.
A gutter in a candle.
Happy; fortunate; blessed.
Buckwheat.
A variety of auction pitch in which the five of trumps counts five.
Labor; toil; drudgery.
Any article or separable part of one's assets.
Agonic line.
A ship's carpenter.
A rocking or balanced stone.

Any parrot of the genus Ara, Sittace, or Macrocercus.  About eighteen species are known, all of them found in Central and South America.  They are large and have a very long tail, a strong hooked bill, and a naked space around the eyes.  The voice is harsh, and the colors are brilliant and strongly contrasted; they are among the largest and showiest of parrots.  Different species names have been given to the same macaw, as for example the Hyacinthine macaw, which has been variously classified as Anodorhyncus hyacynthinus, Anodorhyncus maximiliani, and Macrocercus hyacynthinus.
The two anterior of the four lobes on the dorsal side of the midbrain of most mammals; the anterior optic lobes.

A grammar.

An Armenian.

A country in Southern Asia; the two peninsulas of Hither and Farther India; in a restricted sense, Hither India, or Hindostan.

Either one of two asclepiadaceous shrubs (Calotropis gigantea, and Calotropis procera), which furnish a strong and valuable fiber.  The acrid milky juice is used medicinally.
Such as is in common use; such as occurs in ordinary practice, or in the ordinary course of events; customary; ordinary; habitual; common.

A book, especially an early form of book with pages stitched together, contrasting with the earlier scrolls; a manuscript; as, a DaVinci codex.
A variety of white lead. See Krems lead, under Lead, n.
In Spanish America, a wood; forest; timber land; esp., in parts of South America, a comparatively wooden region.
Dung.

A neighborhood or near place; the place or county in which anything is alleged to have happened; also, the place where an action is laid.
Something spoken aside; as, a remark made by a stageplayer which the other players are not supposed to hear.

The fillet which binds the hair of a young unmarried woman, and is emblematic of her maiden character.
Thane. See Thane.
A public shed, or portico, for travelers, worshipers, etc.
A basin.
A piece or fragment of an earthen vessel, or a like brittle substance, as the shell of an egg or snail.
The European starling.
A native or inhabitant of Latium; a Roman.
Water retained by an embankment; a pool of water.
An hermaphrodite.
A large African antelope (Alcelaphus tora). It has widely divergent, strongly ringed horns.
A genus of shrubs (Sambucus) having broad umbels of white flowers, and small black or red berries.
Fretful excitement. [Obs.] See Feaze.
one of the often brightly colored and branching hornlike structures on the backs of nudibranchs and other related mollusks that serve as gills.

Ore selected for excellence.
An old Italian silver coin, worth about ten cents.

A genus of coniferous trees of the northen hemisphere, including the Norway spruce and the American black and white spruces. These trees have pendent cones, which do not readily fall to pieces, in this and other respects differing from the firs.
A key or thing touched to produce a tone.
To insert (a graft) in a branch or stem of another tree; to propagate by insertion in another stock; also, to insert a graft upon.
The act of marching; a movement of soldiers from one stopping place to another; military progress; advance of troops.
A large number or mass of small animals or insects, especially when in motion.

red pear-shaped tropical fruit with poisonous seeds; its flesh is poisonous when unripe or overripe.

One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.
One of the orders of amphibians characterized by the absence of a tail, as the frogs and toads.
That which is educed, as by analysis.
Same as hippopotamus.
A machine for spinning a number of threads at once, -- used in factories.  Also called spinning jenny.
A genus of rosaceous plants, including the raspberry and blackberry.
A sound of quick movement, as of something whirled through the air.
Any one of several species of ruminants of the genus Ovis, native of the higher mountains of both hemispheres, but most numerous in Asia.

A kind of missile weapon consisting of one, two, or more balls of stone, iron, or other material, attached to the ends of a leather cord; -- used by the Gauchos of South America, and others, for hurling at and entangling an animal.
A kind of tape or braid.
A nitrogenous substance resembling gelatin, obtained from certain alg<ae/.

A well-known high-flavored juicy fruit, containing one or two seeds in a hard almond-like endocarp or stone.  In the wild stock the fruit is hard and inedible.
The grain left after harvest or gleaning; also, nuts which have fallen to the ground.

One of the forms which a verb takes by inflection or by adding auxiliary words, so as to indicate the time of the action or event signified; the modification which verbs undergo for the indication of time.
A country seat; a country or suburban residence of some pretensions to elegance.

An officer next in rank above a captain and next below a lieutenant colonel; the lowest field officer.
An itinerant player on the musette, an instrument formerly common in Europe.
The current of a stream.
That which diverts, and makes mirth; pastime; amusement.
The calcined ashes of any coarse seaweed used for the manufacture of soda and iodine; also, the seaweed itself; fucus; wrack.
An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, and rarely for a work of art.
A class of claret wines, including several varieties, from the district of M<eacute/doc in the department of Gironde.
of or pertaining to objects which are pierced or decorated with an openwork pattern.
A pleasure boat; a vessel or boat of state, elegantly furnished and decorated.
A character or point [,] marking the smallest divisions of a sentence, written or printed.

A light canoe, made of skins stretched over a frame, and usually capable of carrying but one person, who sits amidships and uses a double-bladed paddle. It is peculiar to the Eskimos and other Arctic tribes.

A stratagem by which a thing is indirectly brought to pass, or by which one thing seems intended and another is done; a trick; an artifice.

To exert muscular strength; to exert one's strength with painful effort, particularly in servile occupations; to work; to toil.
A native or inhabitant of modern Saxony.

The plea or mode of defense under which a person on trial for a crime proves or attempts to prove that he was in another place when the alleged act was committed; as, to set up an alibi; to prove an alibi.

Gradual failure of health, strength, soundness, prosperity, or of any species of excellence or perfection; tendency toward dissolution or extinction; corruption; rottenness; decline; deterioration; as, the decay of the body; the decay of virtue; the decay of the Roman empire; a castle in decay.
A fragrant kind of green tea.

A trailing grass (Cynodon dactylon) native to Europe, now cosmopolitan in warm regions; used for lawns and pastures especially in the Southern U. S. and India.  Called also Bahama grass and Bermuda grass.
A plain face or plinth at the lower part of a wall.
A small wooden vessel; a pail.
A canelike grass of southern Europe (Arundo Donax), used for fishing rods, etc.
The syntactical or structural form peculiar to any language; the genius or cast of a language.
A little dell or valley; a flat piece of low, moist ground.
The people of Holland; Dutchmen.

A loose outer garment; especially, a gown forming a part of European modern costume for women and children; also, a coarse shirtlike garment worn by some workmen over their other clothes; a smock frock; as, a marketman's frock.
noisy and mischievous merrymaking.
Thread or cloth made of flax or (rarely) of hemp; -- used in a general sense to include cambric, shirting, sheeting, towels, tablecloths, etc.; as, bed linens

A small three-masted vessel, with projecting bow and stern and convex decks, used in the Mediterranean for transporting merchandise, etc.  It carries large square sails, or lateen sails, or both.  Xebecs were formerly armed and used by corsairs.
The erectile external sexual organ of males, used in copulation, and in mammals, also for urination.
Unhusked rice; -- commonly so called in the East Indies.
Soft mud.

An Indian of a linguistic stock of tribes of the Peruvian coast who had a developed agricultural civilization at the advent of the Spaniards, before which they had been conquered by the Incas. They constructed irrigation canals which are still in use, adorned their buildings with bas-reliefs and frescoes, and were skilled goldsmiths and silversmiths.
The daughter of Jupiter and Latona; a virgin goddess who presided over hunting, chastity, and marriage; -- identified with the Greek goddess Artemis.
A gutter.

an indehiscent fruit derived from a single ovary having one or many seeds within a fleshy wall or pericarp: e. g. grape; tomato; cranberry.
A dry measure of four bushels, or half a quarter.
Var. of Soldier.
A place to which one frequently resorts; as, drinking saloons are the haunts of tipplers; a den is the haunt of wild beasts.

Any one of numerous species of small, wingless, suctorial, parasitic insects belonging to a tribe (Pediculina), now usually regarded as degraded Hemiptera. To this group belong of the lice of man and other mammals; as, the head louse of man (Pediculus capitis), the body louse (Pediculus vestimenti), and the crab louse (Phthirius pubis), and many others. See Crab louse, Dog louse, Cattle louse, etc., under Crab, Dog, etc.
pl. of Penny. See Penny.

The giant armadillo (Priodontes gigas) of tropical South America. It becomes nearly five feet long including the tail. It is noted for its burrowing powers, feeds largely upon dead animals, and sometimes invades human graves.

The standard unit of electrical capacity; the capacity of a condenser whose charge, having an electro-motive force of one volt, is equal to the amount of electricity which, with the same electromotive force, passes through one ohm in one second; the capacity, which, charged with one coulomb, gives an electro-motive force of one volt.
A Hebrew patriarch (son of Isaac, and ancestor of the Jews), who in a vision saw a ladder reaching up to heaven (Gen. xxviii. 12); -- also called Israel.
A West Indian name for two large timber trees (Podocarpus coriaceus, and Podocarpus Purdicanus) of the Yew family. The wood, which is much used, is pale brownish with darker streaks.
A genus of nudibranch mollusks having clusters of branchial papill<ae/ along the back. See Ceratobranchia.
A twin crystal.
The claw of a predaceous bird or animal, especially the claw of a bird of prey.
A compensation given to a hired person for services; price paid for labor; recompense; hire.  See Wage, n., 2.
To form into ringlets; to curl; to crimp; to friz; as, to crape the hair; to crape silk.
A child's mane for a doll.
The powder of aloes with canella, formerly officinal, employed as a cathartic.
A fragrant essential oil; esp., a volatile and highly fragrant essential oil obtained from the petals of roses.
An instrument that converts sound into signals that can be transmitted over distances and then converts received signals back into sounds; a telephone; as, I talked to him on the phone.
A small stick or rod used as a spike in thatching; a splinter.

Any living creature; an animal; -- including man, insects, etc.
One who dotes; a man whose understanding is enfeebled by age; a dotard.

a dish composed of well-seasoned rice (with nuts or currants of minced lamb) simmered or braised in stock, stuffed into tomatoes or green peppers, or wrapped in grape leaves; -- popular in the near east.
a hard red wheat (Triticum dicoccum) grown especially in Russia and Germany; also grown in the U. S. as stock feed.
Drink; also, pottage.

Goods sunk in the sea, with a buoy attached in order that they may be found again. See Jetsam and Flotsam.
A slight gleam or glimmer; a glimpse.

One of a primitive people supposed to have lived in prehistoric times, in Central Asia, east of the Caspian Sea, and north of the Hindu Kush and Paropamisan Mountains, and to have been the stock from which sprang the Hindu, Persian, Greek, Latin, Celtic, Teutonic, Slavonic, and other races; one of that ethnological division of mankind called also Indo-European or Indo-Germanic.
To apply a brush to, according to its particular use; to rub, smooth, clean, paint, etc., with a brush.

Money or other valuable thing given to evidence a contract; a pledge or earnest.

A variety of the domestic dog, usually having large, drooping ears, esp. one which hunts game by scent, as the foxhound, bloodhound, deerhound, but also used for various breeds of fleet hunting dogs, as the greyhound, boarhound, etc.

A starch or arrow-root made from the tubes of an East Indian zinziberaceous plant (Curcuma angustifolia); also, the plant itself.
A house or shed built of boards, boughs, or other slight materials, for temporary occupation.
A hopper-shaped box or <?/nortar in which ore is placed for the action of the stamps.
The hyoid bone.

One of the hard, bony appendages which are borne on the jaws, or on other bones in the walls of the mouth or pharynx of most vertebrates, and which usually aid in the prehension and mastication of food.
A mass; a heap.
The oil of the mahwa tree.
Any one of several species of embiotocoids, or surf fishes, of the Pacific coast. The name is also given locally to several other fishes, as the bur fish.
A rosier; a rosebush.
A shell, husk, or pod; especially, the outer covering of such nuts as the hickory nut, butternut, peanut, and chestnut.
A sign. See Al segno, and Dal segno.
A cottage or small house; a hut.
One of the masses of generative tissue primitively alike in both sexes, but giving rise to either an ovary or a testis; a generative gland; a germ gland.
A silver coin of Ecuador, worth 68 cents (ca. 1900).
A large wax candle used in the ceremonies of various churches.
A falcon (Falco sacer) native of Southern Europe and Asia, closely resembling the lanner.

A liliaceous plant of the genus Allium (Allium cepa), having a strong-flavored bulb and long hollow leaves; also, its bulbous root, much used as an article of food.  The name is often extended to other species of the genus.
A swamp.
See Sufi.
A switch or whip.

A colorless liquid, C4H8O2, obtained by condensation of two molecules of acetaldehyde: CH3CHO + CH3CHO = H3CH(OH)CH2CO; also, any of various derivatives of this. The same reaction has been applied, under the name of aldol condensation, to the production of many compounds.
Same as Ambo.
A piece of music of a mournful character, to accompany funeral rites; a funeral hymn.
The forehead; the part of the cranium between the orbits and the vertex.
One who rates or scolds.
A dunce; a blockhead.
See Twill.
A seaweed of a reddish brown color, which is sometimes eaten, as in Scotland. The true dulse is Sarcophyllis edulis; the common is Rhodymenia. [Written also dillisk.]
One of the terminal divisions of a limb appendage; a finger or toe.
(Irish) one of a group of sea demons sometimes associated with the hostile power of nature.
A pool of water to keep fish in; a wear.
That by which anything is hoisted; the apparatus for lifting goods.
One who, or that which, puzzles; a difficult or inexplicable question or fact.
The act of tasting; gustation.
The coarse, harsh sound uttered by a frog or a raven, or a like sound.

A small herbivorous mammal of the genus Hyrax. The species found in Palestine and Syria is Hyrax Syriacus; that of Northern Africa is Hyrax Brucei; -- called also ashkoko, dassy, and rock rabbit. See Cony, and Hyrax.

The most important salmon of Alaska (Oncorhinchus nerka), ascending in spring most rivers and lakes from Alaska to Oregon, Washington, and Idaho; -- called also red salmon, redfish, blueback, and sawqui.
pl. of Villus.
a glazed leavened doughnut-shaped roll with a hard crust.
a genus of plants including the indigo bush.
A genus of small beetles, of which one species (the grapevine Fidia, F. longipes) is very injurious to vines in America.
A bumper in honor of a toast or health.
See Weevil.

a sequence of three nucleotides in a genome or a DNA or messenger RNA molecule, which specifies the incorporation of one amino acid or is a stop signal, during the biosynthesis of proteins.  Codons occur within the protein-coding segments of the DNA or RNA genome of living organisms.  The amino acid sequence of proteins synthesized on ribosomes is thus determined by the sequence of the nucleotides in the genome.
Great fear in view of impending evil; fearful apprehension of danger; anticipatory terror.
Lit., a dean; the senior member of a body or group; as, the doyen of French physicians.
That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animal or vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils.
The external occipital protuberance of the skull.
See 1st Spade.
A secluded, private, or obscure way; a path or road aside from the main one.

The name of several species of herons which bear plumes on the back. They are generally white. Among the best known species are the American egret (Ardea egretta syn. Herodias egretta); the great egret (Ardea alba); the little egret (Ardea garzetta), of Europe; and the American snowy egret (Ardea candidissima).
See Posse comitatus.
A cereal grass (Triticum vulgare) and its grain, which furnishes a white flour for bread, and, next to rice, is the grain most largely used by the human race.
A mound; a hillock.
To sound in harmonious accord, as bells.
The sum of four tens; forty units or objects.
A small tropical American tree (Chrysobalanus icaco) bearing edible plumlike fruit.
The cuckoopint.
